Description: This is the Chinese version of Japan's silken tofu.  Like silken tofu, it's good for making shakes, dips, custards, puddings, and dressings.   Look for plastic tubs with cakes of tofu in the refrigerated sections of supermarkets and health food stores.   Don't freeze this kind of tofu.

Name: soy cheese
Description: Made from soy milk, soy cheese is a boon to those who eschew dairy products.  There are many varieties, including those which mimic cheddar, Parmesan, mozzarella, jack, and Swiss.  Most brands have a mild, ho-hum flavor and a dry texture.   Except for the low-fat varieties, most of them melt fairly well.

Name: soy mayonnaise
Description: This is made from soy milk, and it's a very convincing substitute for those who wish to avoid egg-based mayonnaise. Nayonaise is a well-respected brand.

Name: soy milk
Description: Made from soybeans, soy milk is sweeter and darker than dairy milk, and it has a distinctive beanlike flavor. It comes refrigerated, or in aseptic containers (either full strength or concentrated), or in powdered form, with varying percentages of fat. A fortified version is available that supplies many of the nutrients normally found in cow's milk.Flavored versions are best for drinking, unflavored for cooking. Shake well before using.
Also known as: soy beverage, soya beverage, soya milk, soymilk

Name: soy yogurt
Description: This is made from soy milk, and it's a good alternative for those who wish to avoid dairy products.

Name: soybean paper
Description: These colorful sheets can be used to wrap sushi.  Look for them in Asian markets.

Name: soynut butter
Description: This peanut butter substitute is made from roasted soynuts.  It's got a bit less fat than peanut butter, and much less flavor.

Name: soynuts
Description: These are roasted soybeans that you eat like peanuts.  They're about the shape of corn kernels, and sometimes coated with flavorings.  Baked soynuts are lower in fat than fried.

Name: tempeh
Description: This Indonesian meat substitute is made from soybeans and other grains that have been injected with a mold and allowed to ferment.   It's rich in protein and fiber and has a chewy texture and salty, nutty flavor.   Before using it, steam or simmer it for about twenty minutes.  Then use it just like tofu or  meat--either by marinating it and grilling or by crumbling it into pieces and frying them.   Look for tempeh among the frozen foods in supermarkets or in health food stores.  It will keep in the freezer for a few months, or in the refrigerator for about a week.

Name: textured soy protein
Description: This is a healthy ground meat substitute made from defatted soy flour.  It comes as dried or frozen flakes, granules, or chunks, and it has a chewy, meaty texture when it's cooked.  The flavor's a bit bland, so it works best in well-seasoned dishes like chili and sloppy joes.  Some brands are beef or chicken-flavored.   Look for it in health food stores.
Also known as: plant protein, protein crumbles, textured vegetable protein, texturized soy protein, texturized vegetable protein, TSP, TVP, vegetable protein

Name: tofu
Description: Tofu is cheap, high in protein, low in fat, and very versatile.  You can eat it raw or cooked, but it's bland by itself and tastes best if it's allowed to absorb other flavors.  There are several varieties of raw tofu, each with different moisture contents.   Silken and soft tofu are relatively moist, and best suited for making shakes, dips, and dressings.  Regular tofu has some of the moisture drained away, and it's best for scrambling or using like cheese in casseroles.  Firm, extra-firm, and pressed tofus are even drier, so they absorb other flavors better and hold their shape in stir-fries and on the grill.  Tofu is also available smoked, pickled, flavored, baked, and deep-fat fried.
Also known as: bean curd, doufu, soya cheese, soybean curd

Name: tofu sour cream
Description: This made with tofu, and it's lower in fat and more nutritious than ordinary sour cream.   Look for it in health food stores.

Name: tofurky
Description: A tofu and seitan substitute.

Name: UnTurkey
Description: A seitan-based turkey.

Name: white miso
Description: This pale yellow miso is the sweetest and mildest of them all.   It's used to make light soups, salad dressings, desserts, and marinades for fish.   It's aged only briefly and isn't as salty as other forms of miso.
Also known as: kyoto shiro miso, mellow miso, shiro miso, shiromiso, sweet miso, sweet white miso

Name: yellow miso
Description: This golden yellow miso is made of rice and aged briefly. It's salty but mild and quite versatile. It's a good choice if you only want to store one tub of miso in your refrigerator.

Name: yuba
Description: This is the sweet, protein-rich skin that forms on warm soymilk as it cools.  Japanese and Chinese cooks like to add it to soups or use it as wrappers, and when it's deep-fat fried, it makes a fairly realistic "skin" for a mock holiday turkey.  You can buy very thin fresh sheets of it (called nama yuba) in Kyoto, Japan, and thicker round sheets that look like fruit leather in some Chinese markets.   Elsewhere, you'll have to get it dried or frozen.   Dried yuba comes as sheets, rolls, knots, and many other forms.  It needs to be reconstituted with water before you can use it, unless you're planning to add it to a soup.
Also known as: bean curd sheets, bean curd skins, soy milk skins, uba

Name: acorn squash
Description: This orange-fleshed winter squash is popular because of its small size--it can be cut in half and baked to make two generous servings. The rind, unfortunately, is quite hard and difficult to cut. To avoid injuring yourself, first slice off both the top and the bottom with a sharp knife, and use the stem end as a base for the more treacherous halving cut. Select acorn squash with as much green on the rind as possible, though most will have a single orange spot on one side.
Substitutions: buttercup squash,butternut squash,banana squash,turban squash,Hubbard squash,pumpkin,green papaya,golden nugget squash

Name: Agrinion olives
Description: This is a large, green Greek olive with very tender flesh.

Name: ají panca chili - dried
Description: This reddish-brown dried chili is fruity, mild, and a little smoky.

Name: Aleppo olives
Description: This is a black, dry-cured Middle Eastern olive that's hard to find in the United States.

Name: alfalfa sprouts
Description: These are too wispy to cook, but they're great raw in salads and sandwiches.

Name: Alphonso olives
Description: This large Chilean olive is cured in a wine or wine vinegar solution, which gives it a beautiful dark purple color and tart flavor. Its flesh is very tender and slightly bitter.

Name: American eggplant
Description: This is the familiar large, dark purple, pear-shaped variety. Choose small or medium-sized eggplants (these have fewer bitter seeds) with healthy-looking green stems that are firm to the touch, but not too hard. Avoid mushy ones. Store them in the refrigerator.

Name: Amphissa olives
Description: These are dark purple Greek olives that are hard to find in the U.S. They're great for snacking.

Name: Anaheim chili
Description: These large, mild chiles are perfect for chiles rellenos. Mexican cooks also like to dice or purée them, and then add them to sauces, soups, and casseroles. They have a tough skin, but it peels off easily if you first char the chiles over a flame and then steam them in a paper bag for several minutes. Anaheims are available year-round, but they're best in the summer. You can occasionally find red Anaheims, which are riper and slightly hotter. When dried, this pepper is called a chile Colorado.
Also known as: Anaheim chile, Anaheim chili pepper, Anaheim chilli, California green chili, california red chili (when mature and red), chile colorado (when mature and red), chile verde (CHEE-lay VER-day), long green pepper
Substitutions: New Mexico green chili,poblano pepper ,green chile canned

Name: ancho chili
Description: These mild, dried poblano peppers have a sweet, fruity flavor and are a staple in Mexican cuisine. They're brownish-black and wrinkled, and commonly used in adobos, moles, salsas, and various sauces.
Also known as: ancho chile, ancho chino, chile color, chile colorado, dried poblano, pasilla chile (incorrectly), pasilla rojo
Substitutions: mulato chili ,pasilla chili,poblano pepper ,California chili ,New Mexico red chili

Name: angled loofa
Description: A native of Pakistan, this mild vegetable has a slightly bitter edge that pairs well with sweet and acidic ingredients in stir-fry dishes. You can also eat it raw, or dry it to make a loofa sponge.You can leave the peel on, but some people find the flavor off-putting. Remove any large seeds if you wish to cut the bitterness.
Also known as: angled loofah, angled luffa, Chinese loofah, Chinese okra, dish cloth gourd, luffa angled gourd, luffa gourd, ribbed loofah, ridge gourd, ridged gourd, silk gourd, silky gourd, sinkwa towelsponge, sponge gourd, vegetable gourd

Name: apple green eggplant
Description: These eggplant resemble green apples, and are mild and sweet. You don't need to peel them.

Name: arame
Description: This popular seaweed is very sweet and mild, and it's loaded with iron, calcium, and iodine.

Name: Arauco olives
Description: These are large green Spanish olives flavored with rosemary.

Name: Arbequina olives
Description: These are tiny green Spanish olives with a mild, smoky flavor. They're hard to find in the U.S.

Name: Armenian cucumber
Also known as: snake cucumber, snake melon, This is hard to find, but one of the best-regarded slicing cucumbers.  It's crisp, thin-skinned, and mild-flavored, and it has soft seeds.  Like the English cucumber, it doesn't need to be peeled or seeded.  It's not good for pickling., uri

Name: arracacha
Description: These come from South America. According to the FAO, they taste like a cross between celery, cabbage, and chestnuts.

Name: arrowroot
Description: The name arrowroot is more commonly associated with a thickener that's made from the plant.  A fresh arrowroot tuber looks like a small onion, only without the layers.  It should be peeled, and then it can be boiled or stir-fried.  Look for it in Chinese markets during the winter.
Also known as: arrow root, arrowhead, Chinese arrowhead, Chinese potato ((this name also is used for jicama)), ci gu, goo, seegoo, tse goo, tsu goo

Name: artichoke
Description: Artichokes are the unopened flowers and stems of a kind of thistle. You cook them, then peel off and eat the bases of the thick green petals (called leaves). At the center is the heart, the choicest portion of the artichoke, covered by the choke, a hairy pad that should be peeled off and discarded. Their peak season is early summer.
Also known as: French artichoke, globe artichoke, green artichoke

Name: arugula
Description: With its peppery and slightly bitter flavor, arugula is a terrific green to throw into an otherwise boring salad.  It can be gently braised, too.  Some supermarkets sell it in small bunches, but you're more likely to find it combined with other greens in a spring salad mix.
Also known as: arrugola (in Britain), eruca, garden rocket, Italian cress, Mediterranean rocket, rocket (salad), roquette, rucola, rugola, rugula, tira

Name: Asian eggplants
Description: Include Japanese eggplants and Chinese eggplants, have thinner skins and a more delicate flavor than American eggplants, and not as many of the seeds that tend to make eggplants bitter. They're usually more slender than American eggplants, but they vary in size and shape. They range in color from lavender to pink, green, and white.
Also known as: Chinese eggplants, Japanese eggplants, Oriental eggplants

Name: asparagus
Description:
Asparagus has a wonderfully distinctive flavor and a meaty texture.  It's often served as a side dish, after being steamed or briefly boiled.  Better cooks insist that it be peeled first, but many people skip this step.  To remove the tough base, simply snap the asparagus in half with your hands.  The stalk should break right about at the point where it starts getting too tough to serve to company.   

There's a purple variety, but it turns green when it's cooked and so loses its novelty.  White asparagus, on the other hand, is more tender than green, and more expensive.  Asparagus is often available year-round, but the best time to buy it is in the spring.

Name: Atalanta olives
Description: This is a muddy-green Greek olive with soft flesh.

Name: bacon avocado
Description: This sweet, smooth-skinned variety shows up in the middle of winter.  It's not as flavorful as other avocados.

Name: bamboo shoots
Description: You can buy fresh shoots at some Chinese markets, but you must boil them first to rid them of hydrocyanic acid, a toxin that causes cyanide poisoning.   Canned shoots are safer and more widely available.  Rinse them well before using.  Submerge any unused shoots in fresh water and store them in a sealed container in the refrigerator, changing the water daily.
Also known as: bambo sprouts, choke-sun, chun-sun, take-noko, takenoko, tung sun

Name: banana blossom
Description: These are popular in Southeast Asia and India, where they're boiled in water or coconut milk, then eaten like artichokes

Name: banana pepper
Description: These sweet, mild peppers with a fruity flavor are easily confused with hotter yellow wax peppers. Sample before using.
Also known as: banana chile, banana chili pepper, banana wax pepper, sweet banana pepper

Name: banana squash
Description: This variety is so large that grocers usually cut into smaller chunks before putting it out.  It's tasty, but its biggest virtue is the beautiful golden color of its flesh.

Name: bear's head mushroom
Description: These grow yellow and sour-tasting with age, so buy only white ones.  They're best sautéed or gently boiled.
Also known as: bearded tooth mushroom, satyr's beard mushroom

Name: beet
Description: Beets have a distinctive earthy flavor that's enhanced by roasting, but they can also be steamed, microwaved, or boiled.  A beet will be more flavorful and colorful if you leave the peel and some of the stem on while it's cooking.  After it's cooled down, the peel comes off fairly easily.    Varieties include the familiar red beets, golden beets, which turn a golden orange when cooked and are slightly sweeter than red beets, white beets, and chioggia (pronounced KYAHD-dja) = candy-stripe beets = candy cane beets which have alternating white and red rings inside.  Baby beets are sweeter and faster-cooking than larger beets.   Select beets that are heavy for their size.  Canned beets are a good substitute for fresh.
Also known as: beetroots, garden beet, red beet, table beet

Name: beet greens
Description: Like their close relative, Swiss chard, beet greens have lots of flavor and a good, sturdy texture.  The best ones are young and tender, and sometimes come with small beets attached.

Name: Belgian endive
Description: These crunchy, slightly bitter leaves are often used to make hors d'oeuvres, but they can also be chopped and added to salads, or braised to make an exquisite (and expensive) side dish.  Select heads with yellow tips; those with green tips are more bitter.   Their peak season is the late fall and winter.
Also known as: Belgium chicory, blanching chicory, chicon, chicory, Dutch chicory, French endive, green-leaved blanching chicory, in Britain, witloof, witloof chicory

Name: bell pepper
Description: Red and yellow peppers are riper, more flavorful, and pricier than the more common green ones. You can occasionally find bell peppers in other colors as well, like brown, white, pink, orange, and purple.Bell peppers are the perfect size for hollowing out and stuffing, or you can slice them into strips for snacking or dipping.

Name: Bermuda onion
Description: These bulb-shaped onions have a sweet mild flavor.  They're available in the spring.

Name: Bibb lettuce
Description: This butterhead lettuce has delicate, loose leaves and lots of flavor.  The only downside is that it's usually expensive.

Name: Bintje potato
Description: This is a creamy, yellow-fleshed potato that's especially good for roasting and making fries

Name: bitter melon
Description: This bitter vegetable is believed to have medicinal properties and is widely used throughout Asia.
Also known as: ampalaya, balsam pear, bitter apple, bitter cucumber, bitter gourd, bitter squash, Chinese bitter melon, foo gwa, karela

Name: black garlic
Description: Black garlic results from the aging of regular garlic in a controlled environment. It has a softer milder taste.

Name: black olives
Description: These are olives that have been allowed to ripen on the tree. American recipes that call for black olives are probably referring to the Mission olive. Other varieties of black olives are the Aleppo, Alphonso, Amphissa, black Cerignola, Gaeta, black Greek, Kalamata, Ligurian, Lugano, Moroccan dry-cured, Niçoise, Nyons, Ponentine, and Royal.

Name: black radish
Description: These large, pungent radishes are better known in Eastern Europe than in the United States.   With their black peels and white interiors, they can be fashioned into attractive garnishes, or you can peel and cook them like turnips.  You can also serve them raw, though it helps to tame them down first by salting and rinsing them.

Name: black salsify
Description: When cooked, black salsify has the taste and texture of an artichoke heart. There are two types: salsify (white salsify) and the more highly regarded black salsify. After peeling black salsify, put it into acidulated water right away to prevent it from turning brown. Canned black salsify is a good substitute for fresh, but it's hard to find.
Also known as: black oyster plant, scorzonera, serpent root, Spanish salsify, viper's grass

Name: black trumpet mushroom
Description: This is a very choice, flavorful mushroom.  Dried black trumpets are excellent, too.
Also known as: black chanterelle, horn of plenty, trompette de la mort, trumpet of the dead

Name: blewit mushrooms
Description: These are prized more for their beauty than their flavor, which is pleasant but somewhat mild.  Dried blewits are even less flavorful than fresh.
Also known as: blewitt mushrooms, blue foot mushrooms, blue-leg mushrooms, bluette mushrooms

Name: boiling onion
Description: These are small versions of yellow, white, or red onions.  They're up to two inches in diameter, and usually cooked whole.

Name: boiling potato
Description: Potatoes in this category hold their shape after cooking, so they're great for making potato salads and scalloped potatoes. They're not good for mashing, baking, or making fries. Types of boiling potatoes are new potatoes, fingerling potatoes, round white potatoes, and round red potatoes.

Name: bok choy
Description: Bok choy has crunchy stems and crinkled, spinach-like leaves. It's usually stir-fried with other ingredients, but it can also be steamed or sautéed and served as a side dish. Small heads of bok choy are called baby bok choy (left), and they're more tender than the larger variety. Of the baby bok choys, bok choy sum = Canton bok choy has small yellow flowers (sum is the Chinese word for flower), while Shanghai bok choy is a uniform light green, doesn't have flowers, and isn't as sweet.
Also known as: baak choi, baby bok choy, bai cai, bok choy sum, Canton bok choy, Chinese cabbage, Chinese chard, Chinese mustard cabbage, Chinese white cabbage, pak choi, pak choy, pok choi, Shanghai bok choy, taisai, white celery mustard, white mustard cabbage
Substitutions: Chinese broccoli,yau choy,napa cabbage,broccoli,Swiss chard,celery,collard greens,beet greens,cabbage

Name: Boniato
Description: Boniatos aren't as sweet and moist as other sweet potatoes, but many people prefer their fluffier consistency and more delicate flavor.  Store them at room temperature and use them soon after your purchase them, since they tend to spoil quickly.
Also known as: batata, batata dulce, batiste, camote, Cuban sweet potato, tropical sweet potato, white sweet potato, white-fleshed sweet potato

Name: Boston lettuce
Description: This is a type of butterhead lettuce, with soft, tender leaves.  It's terrific in salads and sandwiches, or the leaves can be used as a bed for other dishes.
Substitutions: Bibb lettuce,corn salad,leaf lettuce,iceberg lettuce,celery leaves

Name: broccoflower
Description: This is a green variety of cauliflower.

Name: broccoli
Description: Broccoli is tasty, good for you, and easy to cook. The florets can be steamed or boiled and served as a side dish, or served raw on a crudité platter, or stir-fried. The stems are good, too, but you should peel them first and cook them a little longer. Select broccoli that's dark green and fresh smelling.

Name: broccoli raab
Description: This slightly bitter cooking green has long been popular in Italy and is now catching on in America.  It's best to just eat the florets and leaves; the stems are quite bitter.
Also known as: broccoli de rabe, broccoli de rape, broccolirab, brocoletti di rape, brocoletto, Chinese flowering cabbage, choy sum, cima di rabe, cima di rapa, raab, rape, rapini, rappi

Name: broccoli Romanesco
Description: This is similar to broccoli, but its florets resemble pine cones.  It's especially good raw.

Name: broccoli sprouts
Description: These are rich in sulforaphane, a cancer-fighting compound.  They also have a pleasant, peppery flavor.

Name: broccolini
Description: Broccolini results from a cross between broccoli and Chinese broccoli.  The slender stems resemble asparagus in flavor and texture.

Name: Brussels sprouts
Description: These look like small cabbages, and they're most often boiled or steamed and served as a side dish. They have a rather strong flavor, so it's best not to pair them with anything that's delicately flavored. They don't store well, so use them within a day or two after purchasing.

Name: bull's horn pepper
Description: This Italian heirloom pepper is shaped like a bull's horn, and many cooks think it's a lot more flavorful than an ordinary bell pepper.
Also known as: Corno Di Toro Pepper, red bull's horn pepper

Name: burdock
Description: Burdock is becoming increasingly popular in the United States, but it's already an important vegetable in Asia. It lends an interesting, earthy flavor to soups, stews, or stir-fried dishes. Select small, firm roots.
Also known as: beggar's button, gobo root, great burdock, kobo root, niúbàng, u-eong, whole burdock

Name: buttercup squash
Description: With sweet and creamy orange flesh, the buttercup is one of the more highly regarded winter squashes.  The biggest shortcoming is that it tends to be a bit dry.  Choose specimens that are heavy for their size.
Substitutions: butternut squash,acorn squash,Hubbard squash,delicata squash,kabocha squash,pumpkin,green papaya

Name: butterhead lettuce
Description: This category includes Bibb lettuce and Boston lettuce.

Name: butternut squash
Description: This variety is very popular because it's so easy to use.  It's small enough to serve a normal family without leftovers, and the rind is thin enough to peel off with a vegetable peeler.  As an added bonus, the flavor is sweet, moist, and pleasantly nutty.
Substitutions: buttercup squash,acorn squash,calabaza,delicata squash,kabocha squash,Hubbard squash,green papaya

Name: cabbage
Description: Cabbage is a nutritional powerhouse that can be eaten raw, usually in slaws, or steamed, boiled, or sautéed.Choose heads that are unblemished, smallish, and heavy for their size. They're cheapest and best in the late fall, winter, and early spring. Store them uncut and unwashed, in a plastic bag in the crisper section of your refrigerator. Many varieties will remain fresh for several weeks.Varieties include green cabbage, which is what recipes often mean when they simply say "cabbage," red cabbage, napa cabbage, savoy cabbage, su choy, Brussels sprouts, and kohlrabi.

Name: cachucha pepper
Description: These small sweet peppers come in different colors and looks like squished bell peppers. They're popular in the Caribbean, where they're often stuffed and roasted.
Also known as: aji cachucha, aji dulce, Ajícito, rocatillo

Name: calabaza
Description: These are popular in Hispanic countries and throughout the Caribbean. They're large, so markets often cut them up before selling them.
Also known as: abóbora, ahuyama, crapaudback, Cuban squash, giraumon, green pumpkin, Jamaican pumpkin, toadback, West Indian pumpkin, zapallo

Name: calcot
Description: This is a large, Spanish variety of green onion.

Name: California chili
Description: These are dried Anaheim chiles, and very mild.

Name: callaloo
Description: These huge leaves are about a foot and a half long, and they're a popular vegetable among Pacific islanders and some Asians.  Many Western cooks steer clear of them, though, since they must be cooked for at least 45 minutes to an hour to rid them of calcium oxalate, a toxin that irritates the throat if swallowed.
Also known as: bhaji, calalou, callau, callilu, elephant's ear, sag, sagaloo, taro leaf
Substitutions: Chinese spinach,Swiss chard,sorrel,spinach,mustard greens,turnip greens,collard greens,meloukhia

Name: cardoon
Description: This vegetable is very likely an early ancestor of the artichoke. Its large, grayish-green stalks are somewhat bitter, but they remain popular in Italy and North Africa. You can find them in large produce markets in late fall.
Also known as: artichoke thistle, cardi, cardoni, chardoon, Texas celery

Name: Caribe potato
Description: These large, starchy potatoes have purple skins and white flesh.  They're great mashed, but they don't hold their shape well, so they shouldn't be used in potato salads or scalloped potatoes.

Name: carrot
Description: Raw or cooked, carrots add sweetness and color to stews, soups, stir-fries, slaws, cakes, and crudité platters, plus they're a great source of Vitamin A. Try to buy them with the greens still attached, they're usually fresher and sweeter that way.

Name: cascabel pepper - dried
Description: These are nicknamed rattle chiles because the seeds rattle when you shake them. They're a rich brown color and moderately hot.
Also known as: bola chile, cascabel chile, chile bola, rattle chile
Substitutions: guajillo chili ,pequin pepper dried,tepin dried,cayenne pepper dried

Name: cassava
Description: People in Hispanic countries use cassavas much like Americans use potatoes. There's both a sweet and a bitter variety of cassava. The sweet one can be eaten raw, but the bitter one requires cooking to destroy the harmful prussic acid it contains. It's often best to buy frozen cassava, since the fresh kind is hard to peel. Look for it in Hispanic markets. It doesn't store well, so use it within a day or two of purchase.
Also known as: agbeli, aipim, Brazilian arrowroot, casava, macaxeira, mandioca, manioc, tapioca root, yuca root, yucca, yucca root

Name: Catarina chili dried
Description: This medium-hot Mexican chili is used to make tamales, marinades, stews and soups. It's got a fruity flavor with just a hint of tobacco.
Also known as: Catarina pepper, chile cora, ladybug chile

Name: cauliflower
Description: Cauliflower florets often wind up in soups, or as a side dish smothered with a cheese sauce, or served raw on a crudité platter.  Select heads that are heavy for their size.

Name: cauliflower mushroom
Description: These are very flavorful, but a bit chewy.  They're good fried, or in soups or stews.   Select small, young-looking heads.

Name: cayenne pepper - fresh
Description: These are often used in Cajun recipes.  Green cayennes appear in the summer, while hotter red cayennes come out in the fall. They are very hot.
Also known as: bird pepper, finger chili, ginnie pepper
Substitutions: chile de árbol dried,Thai chili pepper - fresh,habanero - fresh,jalapeno pepper ,Serrano pepper  ,cascabel pepper - dried,pequin pepper dried,tepin dried,Holland chili,cherry pepper

Name: cayenne pepper dried
Description: These are very hot, bright red chilies. Recipes that call for cayenne pepper are likely referring to a ground powder that goes by the same name, or possibly to the fresh version of the pepper.

Name: celeriac
Description: This underrated vegetable is a relative of celery that's been developed for its root, which has a pleasant celery flavor. It's popular in France and Northern Europe, where it's usually peeled and cooked in stews or grated and served raw. Many large supermarkets carry celeriac; select smallish roots that are heavy for their size.
Also known as: céleri-rave, celery knob, celery root, Germany celery, knob celery, soup celery, turnip celery, turnip-rooted celery

Name: celery
Description: Raw celery is flavorful and wonderfully crunchy, and it's a great vehicle for dips or fillings like peanut butter or cream cheese.  Celery can also be sautéed and used to flavor soups, stews, and sauces.  A bunch or stalk of celery consists of a dozen or so individual ribs, with the tender innermost ribs called the celery heart.

Name: celtuce
Description: This is a kind of lettuce that's grown for its stalk, which can be peeled, sliced, and stir-fried.  Look for it in Asian markets.
Also known as: asparagus lettuce, celery lettuce, Chinese lettuce, stem lettuce, wosun

Name: Cerignola olives
Description: These sweet Italian olives are large enough to stuff. Black Cerignolas are softer than green Cerignolas.

Name: chanar
Description: The fruit and seeds of the chanar tree are edible. In Chile, it is ground up to make a sauce (arrope). It is similar to honey or molasses.

Name: chanterelle
Description: Chanterelles are a whole family of mushrooms, most of which are quite choice, but the name is most often applied to the golden chanterelle = yellow chanterelle.  These yellow mushrooms are highly prized for their exquisite flavor, color, and texture.   Other tasty chanterelle varieties include the yellow foot chanterelle, which is less meaty and less flavorful than other varieties, the black trumpet mushroom, and the white chanterelle, which is similar to the golden chanterelle, but lighter in color.  Fresh chanterelles are best; dried or canned chanterelles are less flavorful and tend to have a rubbery texture
Also known as: egg mushroom, girole, golden chanterelle, pfifferling, white chanterelle, yellow chanterelle, yellow foot chanterelle

Name: chayote
Description: This mild-flavored squash looks like a wrinkled, pale green pear.  It needs to be cooked before serving, and for a longer time than other summer squash.  You should peel a chayote before cooking it, but don't take the seed out--it's edible and tasty.  Cooked chayotes make good low-fat substitutes for avocados.
Also known as: cho-cho, chocho, choko, christophene, christophine, chuchu, custard marrow, mango squash, mirliton (in the South), pear squash, pepinella, pepinello, sousous, vegetable pear, xoxo, xuxu

Name: chepil
Description: Look for this in the produce section of Hispanic markets.

Name: cherry pepper
Description: Along with pepperoncini, this is a good pickling pepper. They are moderately hot, and range in color from orange to bright red.
Also known as: bird cherry pepper, cherry bell pepper, cherry chile, cherry chili, Creole cherry pepper, hot cherry pepper, Hungarian cherry pepper, pimiento pepper, wiri-wiri

Name: cherry tomato
Description: These are less than an inch in diameter, perfect for adding to salads or crudité platters, or grilling on skewers.  There are both red and yellow varieties.

Name: chia sprouts
Description: These resemble alfalfa sprouts, and can be harvested right off that ceramic chia pet you got as a gift.

Name: chicken-of-the-woods mushroom
Description: This got its name because it has the texture of cooked chicken.  You can sauté it or, if you want to make mock chicken, simmer it in chicken stock.

Name: chilaca pepper
Description: When dried, a chilaca pepper is called a pasilla chile. They are mild.

Name: Chilcostle chili
Description: This hard-to-find and moderately hot Mexican chili is used in soups, stews, tamales, and mole sauces. It imparts a yellowish color to dishes.

Name: chile de árbol dried
Description: Unlike many chilies, these remain bright red even after drying, so they're a favorite for making chili wreaths. They're very hot and somewhat acidic. Don't confuse the dried version with the fresh or powdered versions, which go by the same name.
Also known as: arbol chile, bird's beak chili, chile árbol, rat's tail chili, red chile

Name: Chilhuacle negro chile
Description: This excellent Mexican chili is loaded with flavor but hard to find. It's used to make mole negro and bean dishes. It is moderately hot.

Name: Chinese artichoke
Description: These look a bit like caterpillars, and they taste like Jerusalem artichokes. They're popular in France but hard to find in the U.S. Your best bet would be an Asian market.
Also known as: artichoke betony, chorogi, crosne, Japanese artichoke, knotroot

Name: Chinese broccoli
Description: Like rapini, Chinese broccoli has small stems and green heads (which actually are flowers) and lots of leaves. But Chinese broccoli is leafier and less bitter than rapini. It's a great vegetable to stir-fry, but you can also steam or boil it, as you would broccoli.
Also known as: Chinese kale, gai lan, gai lum, kai lan

Name: Chinese celery
Description: This has a stronger flavor than ordinary celery, and it's often used in stir-fries and soups.   Look for it in Asian markets.

Name: Chinese eggplant
Description: Compared to the familiar American eggplant, Chinese eggplants have thinner skins, a more delicate flavor, and not as many of the seeds that tend to make eggplants bitter.

Name: Chinese spinach
Description: This is similar to spinach, only it's prettier, tastier, and more nutritious.  Look for it in Asian markets.
Also known as: amaranth, een choy, hiyu, hon-toi-moi, hsien tsai, red calaloo, yin choy

Name: chipotle negro chile
Description: These are darker, milder versions of the chipotle chile.
Also known as: black chipotle, chipotle mora, mora, red-black chipotle

Name: chipotle pepper
Description: These dried and smoked jalapeño peppers lend a wonderful, complex flavor to sauces. They're usually rehydrated and canned in adobo sauce, but you can also buy them dried in cellophane bags. They are medium hot.
Also known as: chile seco, jalapeno pepper dried, meco, smoked jalapeno pepper

Name: choy sum
Description: This is a general term in Chinese for the tender inner stalks and flowers of green vegetables. White choy sum usually refers to bok choy, while green choy sum refers to yau choy.
Also known as: cai xin, Chinese flowering cabbage, choi sum

Name: chrysanthemum leaves
Description:
This Asian potherb is used to flavor salads, soups, sukiyaki and other dishes.  The leaves are usually blanched briefly to soften them and deepen their color, but young leaves can be served raw.  Add them to cooked dishes at the last minute, as they become bitter if overcooked.
Some people may have an alergic reaction to chrysanthemum leaves.
Also known as: chop suey greens, garland chrysanthemum, shungiku, tong ho, tung ho

Name: cinnamon cap mushroom
Description: Cinnamon cap mushrooms have a firm texture and an earthy flavor.

Name: cipollini onion
Description: These round, flat Italian onions are about one to two inches in diameter.  They're available in the fall.

Name: clamshell mushroom
Description: Varieties include the brown clamshell mushroom (left).  This mushroom goes well with seafood or meats.  Cook them before eating.
Also known as: Beech Mushroom, Brown Beech Mushroom, brown clamshell mushroom, clam shell mushroom

Name: cloud ear mushroom
Description: It's hard to find these fresh, but dried cloud ears are an excellent substitute.  Reconstitute them by soaking or simmering them in lots of water for a few hours.
Also known as: black fungus, black Treasure, bok née, cloud ear fungus, hairy wood ear, jamur kuping, Jelly ear, mo-er mushroom, wood ear fungus

Name: collard greens
Description: This is a favorite of Southern cooks, who often cook them with salt pork or smoked ham hocks.  Frozen collards are an acceptable substitute for fresh.

Name: coriander root
Description: Thai recipes sometimes call for these roots, but they're hard to find in markets. The best source is to pull out a cilantro plant in your garden, or you can use cilantro stems instead.

Name: corn salad
Description: Corn salad has tender leaves and a very mild flavor.
Also known as: doucette, fetticus, field salad, lamb's lettuce, mache, nut lettuce, raiponce

Name: Costeño Amarillo
Description: This yellow Mexican chili is used to make soups, stews, and mole sauces. It's fruity and moderately hot and somewhat hard to find.

Name: cousa squash
Description: This Middle-Eastern summer squash looks a lot like spaghetti squash, only it has a thin, edible skin. It's similar to zucchini, but its larger size makes it a natural for stuffing.

Name: cracked Provencal
Description: These aromatic  green olives are marinated in a solution with herbes de Provence.

Name: cremini mushroom
Description: These are closely related to common white mushrooms, but they're a bit more flavorful.  Large cremini mushrooms are called portobello mushrooms.
Also known as: baby bella, brown mushroom, crimini mushroom, Italian brown mushroom, Italian mushroom

Name: cress
Description: This is a peppery green that's great in salads, sandwiches, and soups.  It's attractive enough to make a good garnish as well.  There are several varieties, including watercress, upland cress, curly cress, and land cress. Cress is highly perishable, so try to use it as soon as possible after you buy it.
Also known as: curly cress, Garden cress, land cress, upland cress

Name: cuaresmeno - fresh
Description: They are moderately hot.

Name: cubanelle
Description: These sweet, mild peppers are usually sold while yellowish-green. They become hotter and redder as they mature.
Also known as: Cuban pepper, cubanelle pepper, Friarelli, Green cubanelle, Italian frying pepper

Name: cucuzza
Also known as: bottle gourd, calabash, cucuzzi, Italian squash, New Guinea bean, suzza melon, Tasmania bean, zucca

Name: curly endive
Description: You can use this crisp, bitter green in salads or cook it as a side dish.  The outer leaves are green and somewhat bitter; the pale inner leaves are more tender and mild.  Don't confuse this with Belgian endive, which the British call chicory and the French call endive.
Also known as: chicorée frisée, chicory, chicory endive, curly chicory, frise, frisee, frisée

Name: currant tomato
Description: These are about half the size of cherry tomatoes.

Name: daikon
Description: Daikon is larger and milder than its relative, the red radish. The Japanese like to grate it and serve it with sushi or sashimi, but you can also pickle it, stir-fry it, or slice it into salads. Japanese daikons tend to be longer and skinnier than their Chinese counterparts, but the two varieties can be used interchangeably. Choose specimens that are firm and shiny. They don't store well, so try to use them right away.
Also known as: Chinese radish, icicle radish, Japanese radish, lo bak, lo pak, loh baak, loh buk, long white radish, mooli, Oriental radish, white radish, winter radish

Name: daikon sprouts
Description: These have a pungent, peppery flavor that works wonders for otherwise bland salads and  sandwiches.  They're too delicate to cook, so always serve them raw.
Also known as: clover radish, kaiware, radish sprouts, tsumamina

Name: dandelions
Description: Dandelions have a somewhat bitter flavor, which Europeans appreciate more than Americans.   Older dandelion greens should be cooked; younger ones can be cooked or served raw as a salad green.  They're available year-round, but they're best in the spring.

Name: delicata squash
Description: This is one of the tastier winter squashes, with creamy pulp that tastes a bit like sweet potatoes.  Choose squash that are heavy for their size.

Name: dragon tongue bean
Description: You can eat these, pods and all, just like green beans.

Name: dried eggplant
Description: Look for these in Middle Eastern markets.

Name: dulse
Description: This is a salty seaweed, so it makes a great salt substitute in soups and stews.  Some people eat it raw, like beef jerky.  It's rich in iron.
Also known as: creathnach, dillisk, red dulse, sea lettuce flakes

Name: edamame
Description: These are fresh soybeans, that are usually sold shelled and frozen, but you can sometimes find them in the produce section, still in their pods. They're rich in protein, fiber, and other nutrients.Fresh edamame pods make great, healthy appetizers. Just steam the pods and have your guests split the pods open and eat the beans inside.Edamame, whether fresh or frozen, is terrific in soups and salads.
Also known as: beer bean, edible soybean, garden soybean, green soybean, immature soybean, sweet bean, vegetable soybean

Name: Eggplants
Description: This is a spongy, mild-tasting vegetable that's meaty yet low in calories. It's never eaten raw, but it can be baked, grilled, or sautéed. The best eggplants are shiny, firm (but not too hard), and heavy for their size, with bright green stems and unbroken skin. Smaller eggplants tend to have fewer bitter seeds, as do "male" ones with round scars at their blossom (non-stem) end. (The scars on "female" eggplants look like dashes.) Freshness is important, so don't store eggplants for very long.
Also known as: aubergine, berenjena, brinjal, egg apple, garden egg, Guinea squash, melanzane, melongene, patlican

Name: elephant garlic
Description: This looks like an overgrown garlic, but it's more closely related to a leek. It's much milder than ordinary garlic, so it's a good choice if you want to impart the flavor of garlic to a delicately flavored dish. It's often sold in a mesh stocking to keep the cloves together.

Name: empeltre olives
Description: These Spanish black olives are soaked in sherry.

Name: endigia
Description: This crunchy new French variety blends sweet and bitter flavors.

Name: endive
Description: This category includes Belgian endive, curly endive, frisee, and escarole.

Name: English cucumber
Description: This foot-long slicing cucumber is pricier and less flavorful than other varieties, but it has less conspicuous seeds, a thinner skin, and a plastic wrapper--instead of a wax coating--to improve shelf life.  All of this saves preparation time, since there's no need to peel or seed the cucumber before slicing it.  This is a good variety if you focused on looks--you can cut it into round, green trimmed slices.
Also known as: burpless cucumber, English cucumber, European cucumber, gourmet cucumber, greenhouse cucumber, hothouse cucumber, seedless cucumber

Name: enoki mushroom
Description: Enoki mushrooms have a delicate fruity flavor.  They're usually served raw.
Also known as: enok, enokidake, enokitake, futu mushroom, golden mushroom, golden needle mushroom, snow puff mushroom, velvet foot mushroom, velvet stem mushroom, winter mushroom

Name: eryngii mushroom
Also known as: ali?i oyster, boletus of the steppes, eringii mushroom, French horn mushroom, king oyster mushroom, king trumpet mushroom

Name: escarole
Description: Escarole has sturdy leaves and a slightly bitter flavor.  Young escarole leaves are tender enough to add to salads, otherwise escarole is best cooked as a side dish or used in soups.
Also known as: Batavia, Batavian endive, Bavarian endive, broad-leaved endive, grumolo, scarole

Name: fennel
Description: Fennel tastes like licorice or anise, and it's commonly used in Italian dishes.  It's very versatile; you can sauté it and add it to sauces, braise it as a side dish, or serve it raw as a crudité.
Also known as: anise (incorrectly), bulb fennel, finocchio (Italian), Florence fennel, garden fennel, sweet anise (incorrectly), sweet fennel

Name: fennel leaves
Description: For more information, see the Wegman's Food Market's page on Fennel.

Name: fiddlehead fern
Description: When a fern first emerges from the ground, its uncoiled frond is called a fiddlehead. Edible varieties of fiddleheads include those from the ostrich fern and the less common wood fern. They're available in the late spring and early summer. Select the smallest, freshest-looking fiddleheads you can find. Warning: Fiddleheads from bracken ferns resemble those from ostrich ferns, but are believed to be carcinogenic. Be very careful if you're gathering fiddleheads from the wild. Undercooked ostrich fern fiddleheads also have been linked to some cases of food poisoning.
Also known as: fern, fiddlehead greens, lady fern, ostrich fern, pohole, royal fern, vegetable fern, western sword fern

Name: fingerling potato
Description: There are many varieties of these small, finger-shaped potatoes, but they all tend to be low in starch, and great for roasting or making potato salads.

Name: fingerroot
Description: This ginger relative is popular in Thailand. It resembles long fingers jutting from a hand.
Also known as: Chinese ginger, Chinese key, ka chai, kra chai, krachai, lesser galangal

Name: flowering kale
Description: This is a beautiful cabbage used more often as a garnish than as a vegetable.
Also known as: flowering cabbage, flowering cole, ornamental kale

Name: fresh beans
Description: Fresh beans appear in the summer and fall, and they're sweeter and more tender than dry beans. You don't need to soak them or cook them as long as dried beans, but they often need to be shelled before using.You can usually substitute them with dried beans pound for pound.

Name: fresh black-eyed pea
Description: In their fresh form, black-eyed peas are pale green and have a wonderful, nutty flavor.  Unlike dried black-eyed peas, they don't need to be soaked, and they cook much faster.  They arrive in markets during the late summer and early fall.
Also known as: fresh black-eye bean, fresh black-eye pea, fresh black-eyed suzy, fresh chawli, fresh China bean, fresh cowpea, fresh crowder pea, fresh lobhia, fresh lombia, fresh poor man's pea, fresh Southern pea

Name: fresh cannellini bean
Also known as: fresh fazolia bean, fresh white kidney bean

Name: fresh cranberry bean
Description: These are available in the summer months.
Also known as: fresh borlotti bean, fresh crab eye bean, fresh fagiolo romano, fresh Roman bean, fresh rosecoco bean, fresh saluggia, fresh shell bean, salugia bean

Name: fresh fava bean
Description: Fresh fava beans are available in the summer and are much better tasting than canned, dried, or frozen ones. Young fava beans need only be shelled, but more mature beans should also be peeled to rid them of the tough, waxy skin that surrounds each bean. The best way to do this is to blanch the shelled beans for a minute in boiling water, plunge them into cold water, and pull off the skins.Select large fava beans that don't have black spots on them, Larger ones are the best.About 400 million people worldwide have favism, an enzyme deficiency. Eating fava beans can cause adverse symptoms in some of them.
Also known as: fresh broad bean, fresh butter bean, fresh English bean, fresh horse bean, fresh Windsor bean

Name: fresh lima bean
Description: These are exquisitely sweet and tender, as long as you get to them soon after they're picked.   The freshest pods are brightly colored and snap crisply when you bend them.   Fresh lima beans don't need to be soaked and you need only cook them about 15 minutes.
Also known as: fresh butter bean, fresh Madagascar bean, fresh wax bean

Name: fresh peas
Description: Fresh peas are sweeter and more tender than their dry counterparts.  To shell one, just pull down the string and squeeze the pod at the seams, then scrape out the peas and discard the pods.  As with corn, freshness is crucial since peas begin converting their sugar into starch as soon as they're picked.  The freshest pods are brightly colored and snap crisply when you bend them.   Fresh peas don't need to be soaked and they cook fairly quickly.

Name: Fresno pepper
Description: These are similar to jalapeno peppers, but with thinner walls. They're great in salsas. Green Fresnos are available in the summer. the hotter red ones come out in the fall.
Also known as: Fresno chile pepper, Fresno chili pepper

Name: Fuerte avocado
Description: This is in season from late fall through spring.  It's not quite as buttery as the Hass avocado, but its flavor is excellent.

Name: fuzzy melon
Description: This sweet and mild squash has a fuzzy feel to it.
Also known as: Chi qua, fuzzy gourd, hairy cucumber, hairy melon, moqua, wax gourd

Name: Gaeta olives
Description: These are small, purple Italian olives are either dry-cured (making them black and wrinkled) or brine-cured (making them dark purple and smooth-skinned).

Name: gai choy
Description: Asian cooks like to pickle this, or else use it in soups or stir-fries.  If you find gai choy too pungent to stir-fry, blanch it first in salted water.
Also known as: Chinese mustard cabbage, Chinese mustard greens, Indian mustard, kai choy, leaf mustard, Oriental mustard, vegetable mustard

Name: galangal
Description: Look for this in Asian markets. It's sold fresh, frozen, dried, or powdered, but use the dried or powdered versions only in a pinch.
Also known as: galanga (ginger), galangale, galingale, greater galangal, Java galangal, Java root, kha, khaa, languas, laos (root or ginger), lengkuas, Siamese ginger, Thai ginger

Name: garden cucumber
Description: You can find these throughout the year at all but the most poorly stocked markets.  The ones you find in supermarkets are usually waxed to hold in moisture and improve shelf-life--these should be peeled or at least scrubbed well before serving.  Unwaxed cucumbers don't need to be peeled, but better cooks often do so since the peels tend to be thick and bitter.  It's also a good idea to remove the seeds from these kinds of cucumbers; just cut them in half lengthwise and scrape them out.   Select cukes that are firm, dark green, and rounded at the tips.
Also known as: field-grown cucumbers, market cucumber, outdoor cucumber, regular cucumber

Name: garden eggs
Description: These are tiny eggplants, the size of an egg or smaller. Their color ranges from white to greenish-yellow.

Name: garden pea
Description: These appear in the summer months, and they're so sweet that it's well worth the trouble to shell them. Freshness is crucial, so look for brightly colored pods that are crisp enough to snap.  Petits pois are a small and tender variety.
Also known as: English pea, fresh pea, green pea, shell pea

Name: garlic
Description: Almost every cuisine on our planet has found an important role for garlic. Europeans mince it raw and add it to salad dressings, or sauté it and use it to flavor their sauces. Asian cooks add it to to their stir-fries; Indian cooks to their curries; Hispanic cooks to meats and vegetables. And Americans have lately taken a fancy to roasting whole bulbs, and then spreading the garlic like a soft cheese on bread or crackers. Garlic's good for you, too. Researchers believe that garlic can bolster the immune system, lower blood pressure and prevent heart disease, and at least some people believe that it can ward off vampires and insects. The only downside is that raw or undercooked garlic tends to linger on the breath, though many people are more than willing to pay that price. Types of garlic include the mild green garlic, the purple-skinned Italian garlic and Mexican garlic, and the common white-skinned garlic = California garlic, which is the most pungent of all.
Also known as: California garlic, green garlic, Italian garlic, Mexican garlic, stinky rose, white-skinned garlic
Substitutions: granulated garlic,garlic flakes,garlic powder,garlic salt,asafetida,rocambole,garlic juice,shallot,onion,garlic chives

Name: garlic flakes
Description: When rehydrated in water, garlic flakes provide much of the flavor and texture of fresh garlic.
Also known as: dehydrated minced garlic, dried garlic flakes

Name: garlic juice
Description: These are sold in spray bottles or in small jars.  Look for them in the spice section of larger supermarkets.  To make your own:  Strain the juice from a jar of minced or pressed garlic.

Name: garlic powder
Description: Garlic powder provides some of the flavor, but not the texture, of fresh garlic.  It disperses well in liquids, so it's a good choice for marinades.

Name: gherkin cucumber
Description: These small, bumpy greed cucumbers are used to make Gherkin pickles or, if pickled while still small, cornichon pickles.

Name: ghost pepper
Description: Ghost peppers are a very hot (over 1,000,000 scovilles) hybrid between Capsicum chinese and Capsicum frutescens. It is grown and used in northern India.
Also known as: bhut jolokia, king chili, king cobra chili, Tezpur chili

Name: ginger root
Description: With its sweet yet pungent flavor, ginger has become a mainstay of many of the world's cuisines.  European cooks like to use dried, ground ginger to flavor gingerbread and other baked goods.  Asian and Indian cooks prefer their ginger fresh, and they use it in spicy sauces and stir-fries.  Ginger not only tastes good, it's also believed to have medicinal properties, and people sometimes use it to soothe their upset stomachs and boost their energy.   Ground ginger isn't a good substitute for fresh, but dried whole ginger will work in a pinch, as will the minced or puréed ginger that's sold in jars.
Also known as: fresh ginger, geung, ginger, gingerroot, khing, shoga

Name: globe squash
Description: You can stuff these and bake them, or slice and sauté them.

Name: golden delicious squash
Description: This is an orange-red variety of Hubbard squash

Name: golden nugget squash
Description: This has a pleasant flavor, but it doesn't have as much flesh as other squashes and the heavy rind makes it hard to cut before cooking.   Select specimens that are heavy for their size, and that have a dull finish.  Those with shiny rinds were probably picked too young, and won't be as sweet.

Name: granulated garlic
Description: Like garlic powder, granulated garlic provides the flavor, but not the texture, of fresh garlic.  It disperses well in liquids.

Name: Greek black olives
Description: A generic black Greek olive is large, dark purple and brine-cured. Popular varieties include Kalamata, Amphissa, and Royal.

Name: Greek green olives
Description: Napfilion and Ionian olives are the most common types of green Greek olives.

Name: green bean
Description: These are meant to be cooked and eaten, pods and all.  They're best if they're steamed or stir-fried just until they're tender but still crisp.  Select bright green beans that snap when broken in half.  Their peak season is in the summer.
Also known as: Baguio beans, French beans, snap bean, string bean
Substitutions: wax bean,Italian flat bean,dragon tongue bean,winged bean

Name: green cabbage
Description: Cabbage is quite versatile. You can cut it into chunks, boil it, and serve it with corned beef or other fatty meats. You can also use cooked leaves as wrappers for meat fillings, or shred raw ones for cole slaw. Select heavy heads of cabbage that have shiny leaves.

Name: green ginger
Description: These pink-tipped, shiny pieces of young ginger are mild and usually don't need to be peeled.   They're easy to find in Asian markets.
Also known as: baby ginger, new ginger, pink ginger, spring ginger, stem ginger, young ginger

Name: green goddess eggplant
Description: This has a very mild flavor.

Name: green olives
Description: Green olives are picked from the tree before they're completely ripened. The most common variety is the Manzanilla olive, which is often pitted and stuffed. Other green olives varieties include the Agrinion, Arauco, Arbequina, Atalanta, green Cerignola, cracked Provençal, Kura, Lucque, Nafplion, Picholine, Sevillano, and Sicilian.

Name: green onion
Description: These are onions that have small bulbs and long green stalks. They're usually eaten raw, but you can also grill or sauté them.  Some people also use the term green onions to refer to onion tops, shallot tops and young leeks.
Also known as: bunching onion, cebollitas, Chinese onion, cibol, scallion, shallot (in Australia), sibies, spring onion (in Britain), stone leek

Name: green tomato
Description: These are picked before they turn red. Southerners like to fry them.

Name: guajillo chili
Description: One of the more popular Mexican chilies, the guajillo (or dried mirasol chili) has a fruity flavor and medium heat (Scoville heat scale of 2,500 to 5,000 SHU). It's smooth, shiny, and reddish-brown, and it has a tough skin, so it needs to be soaked longer than other chiles.These are commonly used for marinades and adobos.
Substitutions: ancho chili,New Mexico red chili,pasilla chili,cascabel pepper - dried,mirasol pepper ,California chili

Name: guero pepper
Description: These are moderately hot.
Also known as: caloro, caribe, chile guero, goldspike, Sante Fe grande, yellow hot chile

Name: habanero - dried
Description: Don't confuse dried habaneros with the fresh version, which goes by the same name. These extremely hot chiles are wrinkled and orange.

Name: habanero - fresh
Description: These extremely hot orange chiles have a fruity flavor. They're best in the summertime.
Substitutions: Scotch bonnet chili,manzana chili,cayenne pepper - fresh,jalapeno pepper ,Serrano pepper

Name: hair vegetable
Description: The Chinese add this to soups and use it as a garnish.  Look for it in Chinese markets and pharmacies. It grows in the Gobi Desert.
Also known as: black flossy moss, black moss, fat choy, hair seaweed, hair-like vegetable

Name: hardneck garlic
Description: Hardneck garlic retains the stalk in the center of the bulb. They tend to have stronger flavors and do not store as long as softneck garlic. Hardneck garlics include purple stripe, rocambole, porcelain, and others.
Also known as: Asiatic, Creole, porcelain, purple stripe, rocambole, Turban

Name: haricot verts
Description: This is a very thin variety of green bean that's crisp, tender, and expensive.  Don't confuse this with the haricot bean, which is a dry bean.
Also known as: French bean, French filet bean, French green bean

Name: Hass avocado
Description: This is available year-round and has a rich flavor and creamy texture. The skin turns almost black when the avocado is ripe, which can camouflage bad bruises. This is the best variety by far for guacamole, but it turns a bit mushy in salads.

Name: hearts of palm
Description: These are peeled cabbage palm buds, and they're terrific in salads or as a vegetable side dish. You can buy them fresh only in Florida, but the canned version is quite good.

Name: hedgehog mushroom
Description: Hedgehog mushrooms are similar to chanterelles in color and flavor.

Name: hijiki
Description: Hijiki has a mild flavor, so it's a good choice if you want to slip a sea vegetable unobtrusively into your soups and stews in order to fortify them with calcium, iron, and other nutrients.  When rehydrated, it roughly quadruples in size, so a little goes a long way.

Name: Holland bell pepper
Description: These are like bell peppers, only they're sweeter and have thicker walls. They come in different colors.

Name: Holland chili
Description: These are hot.

Name: Hondroelia olives
Description: This is a juicy, meaty olive.

Name: horseradish
Description: This is a very pungent brown root that's usually peeled and grated to make a condiment for meats. Its intense flavor and aroma dissipate quickly when exposed to air, so it should be grated just before serving or mixed with something sour (like vinegar, lemon juice, or beet juice) to lock in the heat. It's easiest to use a blender or food processor to grate it. Fresh horseradish is surprisingly potent, so make sure your kitchen is well ventilated, wear rubber gloves, and don't rub your eyes.

Name: Hubbard squash
Description: This variety has tasty flesh, but it's too large for many families to handle and the rind is hard to cut though. Some grocers cut them into smaller pieces before putting them out.
Substitutions: pumpkin,golden delicious squash,buttercup squash,butternut squash,banana squash,green papaya

Name: huitlacoche
Description: This is a fungus that forms black kernels on ears of corn in damp weather. It's a prized delicacy in Mexico, and tastes a bit like wild mushrooms. You can get it fresh or frozen by mail order, or canned in some Hispanic markets. WARNING: May cause contractions in pregnant women.
Also known as: corn smut, cuitlacoche, huitlacoche Italian brown mushroom, maize mushroom, maizteca mushroom, Mexican truffle

Name: iceberg lettuce
Description: This is prized for its crispness and longevity in the refrigerator, but it's a bit short on flavor and nutrients.
Also known as: cabbage lettuce, crisphead lettuce, head lettuce

Name: Indian bitter melon
Description: This is fairly bitter. Choose melons that are bright green. They turn tough and yellow as they age. You can eat the peels and seeds, or scrape out the seeds to reduce the bitterness.
Also known as: balsam pear, bitter apple, bitter melon, bitter squash, Indian bitter gourd, karela

Name: Italian eggplant
Description: These are smaller than American eggplants, but they're otherwise very similar.

Name: Italian flat bean
Description: These green or yellow beans are like ordinary green beans, but they're flatter.   Select small, brightly colored beans that snap when you break them in half.
Also known as: helda beans, Romano bean, runner bean

Name: jalapeno pepper
Description: These popular chilis have a good amount of heat and rich flavor. Green jalapenos are best in the late summer, while red jalapenos appear in the fall. Canned jalapenos aren't as fiery as fresh. When dried and smoked, this pepper is called a chipotle.
Substitutions: cuaresmeno - fresh,Fresno pepper,guero pepper,melegueta pepper,Serrano pepper  ,yellow wax pepper ,cayenne pepper - fresh

Name: jambu
Description: Jambu is a low growing herb. The leaves are commonly eaten as a vegetable in Brazil. Jambu has a strong but pleasant taste that enhances salads and stews. It has a mild anesthetic affect that can cause numbness in the mouth.

Name: Japanese chili
Description: These small red chilis are hot, and similar to the chile de arbol. Before using them, soak them in warm water for a few minutes.

Name: Japanese cucumber
Description: These are just like English cucumbers, only with bumps. Like English cucumbers, they don't have to be peeled or seeded.

Name: Japanese eggplant
Description: Like other Asian eggplants, Japanese eggplants have thin skins, and a sweet, delicate flavor.

Name: japanese yam
Description: Don't confuse this with yamaimo.
Also known as: Japanese sweet potato, kotobuki, satsuma imo

Name: Jerusalem artichoke
Description: These look like small, knobby potatoes, but they have a crisp texture and an interesting earthy flavor. You can eat them raw, stir-fry them, or bake them like potatoes. It's best not to peel them, but you'll want to scrub off the dirt. If you slice them, dunk them immediately in acidulated water to keep them from discoloring.
Also known as: earth apple, girasole, sunchoke, sunroot, topinambour

Name: jicama
Description: This tan-skinned tuber has a mild, nondescript flavor, but a nice crunchy texture. It's a good, cheap substitute for water chestnuts in stir-fries. Since it doesn't discolor, it's also a great vegetable to serve raw on a crudité platter. Peel it before using.
Also known as: ahipa, Chinese potato (this name also is used for arrow root), Chinese turnip (this name also is used for lo bok), jícama, Mexican potato, Mexican turnip, Mexican yam bean, saa got, yam bean

Name: jute leaf
Description: These are tossed into stews in Africa, the Philippines, and Southeast Asia.
Also known as: Jew mallow, krin-krin, rau day, saluyot, West Africa sorrel

Name: kabocha squash
Description: This orange-fleshed winter squash has a striated green rind. It's sweeter, drier, and less fibrous than other winter squash, and it tastes a bit like sweet potatoes.
Also known as: Japanese pumpkin, Japanese squash, kabachi, nam gwa, sweet mama

Name: Kalamata olives
Description: You can find these popular Greek black olives in most large supermarkets. They're salty and have a rich, fruity flavor. These can be eaten out of hand, or used to make tapenades.

Name: kale
Description: Kale is a kind of cabbage with dark green, wrinkled leaves.  It's prized more for its hardiness than its flavor or delicacy, but it continues to be popular in the South, where it's often cooked as a side dish.  Remove and discard the tough center stalks before cooking.  Varieties include curly kale, dinosaur kale = black cabbage = lacinato kale, and the popular Red Russian kale = ragged jack kale.
Also known as: black cabbage, borecole, cow cabbage, curly kale, dinosaur kale, kail, lacinato kale, ragged jack kale, Red Russian kale
Substitutions: collard greens,broccoli raab,Swiss chard,flowering kale,cabbage,napa cabbage,kohlrabi greens,mustard greens,spinach

Name: Kashmiri red chili dried
Description: This mild Kashmiri chili is used in Indian cooking to add flavor and color.

Name: kershaw squash
Description: Kershaw squash is an heirloom squash. It is mostly grown in the American south. Kershaw squash was cultivated by native Americans.

Name: Kirby cucumber
Description: This short, versatile cucumber is used for both slicing and pickling.  It's small, with bumpy yellow or green skin.  Like the English cucumber, it has a thin skin and inconspicuous seeds.

Name: kittely
Description: Kittely is a small round eggplant. It is used in soups and stews.

Name: kiwano
Description: This melon has a gorgeous orange rind with spikes--poke a stick in it and you'd have a medieval mace for a Halloween costume. The yellow-green flesh has the consistency of jello, and tastes a bit like cucumbers.
Also known as: African horned cucumber, African horned melon, cherie, English tomato, hedged gourd, horned melon, jelly melon, kiwano melon, melano, spiked melon

Name: kohlrabi
Description: A kohlrabi resembles a turnip, only it's sweeter and more delicately flavored. It's light green and sometimes sold with its edible greens attached. It can be eaten raw or cooked. Choose small ones, and peel before using.
Also known as: cabbage turnip, German turnip, stem cabbage, turnip cabbage

Name: kohlrabi greens
Description: These can be cooked just like Swiss chard.  Remove the stems first if they're too thick.

Name: konbu
Description: Like other sea vegetables, konbu is rich in minerals.  It's very popular in Japan, where it's used to flavor dashi, a soup stock.  Konbu is usually sold dried, in strips or sheets. Choose konbu that's very dark, almost black, and don't wipe off the white residue that often appears on the surface; it's very flavorful.
Also known as: dasima, haidai, kelp, kombu, oarweed, sea cabbage, sea tangle, tangle

Name: kontomire
Description: This African green is very hard to find fresh in the United States, and the canned version is terrible.

Name: Kura olives
Description: This Middle Eastern cracked green olive is hard to find in the U.S.

Name: lamuyo pepper
Description: This hard-to-find sweet pepper is smaller and sweeter than its cousin, the bell pepper, with which it's interchangeable.

Name: laver
Description: This protein-rich seaweed is popular in Britain and Japan.  To rehydrate, soak it in water for about an hour, then add it to soups and salads.  Laver is sometimes called nori, but that name is more commonly used for the dark sheets that the Japanese use to wrap sushi, which are made from the same plant.
Also known as: aonori, green laver, nori, parae, purple laver, purple seaweed, redware

Name: leaf lettuce
Description: With their crispness and mild flavor, these lettuces are great in salads and sandwiches.
Also known as: bunching lettuce, cutting lettuce, lechuga, looseleaf lettuce, salad-bowl lettuce

Name: leek
Description: Leeks look like large green onions, and they have a more complex onion flavor. They're often cooked as a vegetable side dish, or used in soups. Be sure to wash them thoroughly before cooking as the leaves are notorious for collecting dirt.

Name: lemon cucumber
Description: This versatile cucumber is sweet and flavorful, and doesn't have much of the chemical that makes other cucumbers bitter and hard to digest. Though it's often served raw, it's also a good pickling cucumber.

Name: lesser galangal
Description: This Indonesian rhizome looks a bit like ginger, only it's smaller and darker. It's hard to find in the U.S., but your best bet is to look in Asian markets. It's sold fresh, frozen, pickled, dried, or powdered. Used the dried or powdered versions only in a pinch.
Also known as: kencur root, kentjur root, lesser galangale, zedoary

Name: lettuce
Description: These are mild salad greens that are always served fresh, either in salads or as garnishes. There are four basic categories: iceberg lettuce, with leaves that grow in a dense "head," leaf lettuce, with loosely gathered leaves, butterhead lettuce, with tender leaves that form a soft head, and romaine lettuce, with closely packed leaves in an elongated head.  Select lettuce that has rich color and crisp, fresh-looking leaves.

Name: Ligurian olives
Description: These small Italian olives are brine-cured.

Name: lobster mushroom
Description: These are actually white mushrooms that have been coated by a red fungus.

Name: lollo rosso
Description: This mild, tender lettuce has ruffled red edges.

Name: long white potato
Description: These oblong potatoes have a medium starch content, and are valued for their versatility.  They're good to keep in the pantry as an all-purpose potato.

Name: lotus root
Description: Slices of the lotus root have a beautiful pattern. The fresh version is available sporadically; if not, the canned version is almost as good. Rinse and drain before using. Look for it in Asian markets.

Name: Lucque olives
Description: These green olives are brine-cured.

Name: Lugano olives
Description: These are salty Italian/Swiss brownish-black olives.

Name: maitake mushroom
Description: This Japanese mushroom is reputed to have numerous health benefits.  It also has a nice, earthy flavor.
Also known as: hen-of-the-woods mushroom, kumotake mushroom, ram's head mushroom, sheep's head mushroom

Name: Malabar spinach
Description: This is cooked much like spinach, but it's a bit slimy like okra.  It occasionally shows up in Asian markets
Also known as: alogbati, Basella alba, Ceylon spinach, kontomire, mong toi, saan choy, slippery vegetable, Vietnamese spinach, vine spinach

Name: malanga
Description: Like taro and cassava, malanga is used in tropical countries in much the same way that potatoes are used in more temperate climates.

Name: manzana chili
Description: This habanero relative is often used in salsas. It has black seeds. These are hot.

Name: Manzanilla olives
Description: These green olives are available in most supermarkets. They're often pitted and stuffed with pimento or garlic. They're often put into martinis.

Name: matsutake mushroom
Description: These are popular in Japan, but they're hard to find fresh in the United States and dried matsutakes aren't nearly as flavorful.  Avoid canned matsutakes, they're even worse than dried.

Name: Mexican avocado
Description: With their small size and shiny black skins, these look like elongated plums.  You can eat them, skin and all

Name: Mexicola avocado
Description: This is a small, black-skinned avocado that's the size and shape of a fig. Since the peel is edible, they can be eaten like a peach. There's a smaller variety, the Mexicola cocktail avocado, that's oblong and virtually seedless. They'd make a great addition to a vegetable platter.

Name: mirasol pepper
Description: Mirasol peppers have a distinctive fruity flavor. These are moderately hot. When dried, these are called Guajillo chiles.

Name: Mission olives
Description: These are the common black ones that are ubiquitous in supermarkets, pizza parlors, and salad bars. They don't have as much character as European black olives.

Name: miyoga
Description: These are flower buds that emerge from a variety of ginger.  They're quite mild.  Look for them in Japanese markets.
Also known as: Japanese ginger, miyoga ginger, myoga, myoga ginger

Name: mizuna
Description: Mizuna has tender leaves and a pleasant, peppery flavor.
Also known as: Japanese greens, Japanese mustard greens, kyona, spider mustard

Name: mora chili
Description: This is a smoked and dried red jalapeno pepper. It's very hot.

Name: morels
Description: Morels are highly prized for their rich, earthy flavor, and also because their caps are hollow, which allows them to be stuffed.   Dried morels are very flavorful, and they're an excellent substitute for fresh in sauces and stews.

Name: morita pepper
Description: Like the larger mora chili, this is a smoked and dried red jalapeno. It's very hot.

Name: Moroccan dry-cured olives
Description: These are shriveled black olives that are somewhat bitter. They're best used for cooking rather than snacking.
Also known as: Moroccan oil-cured olive, Moroccan salt-cured olive

Name: mulato chili
Description: This very popular chili looks like the ancho, but it's darker and sweeter. It's fairly mild and has an earthy flavor.
Also known as: chile mulato , mulato pepper, mulatto chile

Name: mung bean sprouts
Description: These are the large sprouts that are common in supermarkets.  They're crisp and nutty, and they're the best sprouts for stir-frying, though they can also be served raw.  Select bean sprouts that are crisp and white with just a tinge of yellow.  To keep them fresh, rinse them off and immerse them in cold water, then store them in the refrigerator.  They're very perishable, so try to use them within a day or two.  Canned bean sprouts are a very poor substitute for fresh.

Name: mushrooms
Description: Markets stock a variety of cultivated mushrooms, but many people prefer wild mushrooms, which are often more flavorful. Be careful when picking wild mushrooms (some species are poisonous) and always cook them thoroughly, both to release their flavors and to convert their proteins into a more usable form.To prepare fresh mushrooms, first trim off the bottoms of the stems, then wipe them off. Don't rinse or soak them, for they'll absorb water and turn mushy when you cook them. Dried mushrooms are often excellent substitutes for fresh, though some species don't dry well. You can reconstitute dried mushrooms by soaking or simmering them. Don't throw out the soaking liquid--it can add more flavor to your sauce than the mushrooms themselves. You can also pulverize dried mushrooms with a food processor or blender, then use the mushroom powder to flavor sauces and stews.To learn about various varieties of mushrooms, click here.

Name: mustard greens
Description: These are more popular in the South than in the rest of the country.  There are red and green varieties, and both have a peppery bite.  If the greens are too pungent for your taste, you can tame them by blanching them in salted water.

Name: Nafplion green olives
Description: These are green, brine-cured Greek olives. They're somewhat salty.

Name: nameko mushroom
Description: Nameko mushrooms are hard to find fresh, but Asian markets sometimes stock cans or plastic bags of it.  They have a gelatinous texture and the Japanese like to add them to miso soup.
Also known as: butterscotch mushroom, huá zi mó, opyonok, Pholiota nameko

Name: napa cabbage
Description: Like bok choy, napa cabbage is a common ingredient in Asian stir-fries. It can also be used as a milder and more delicate alternative to green cabbage in slaws and other recipes
Also known as: celery cabbage, Chinese cabbage, Chinese celery cabbage, Chinese leaf (leaves), hakusai, michihli, nappa cabbage, Peking cabbage, petsai, shantung cabbage, wong bok

Name: nettles
Description: Nettles have long been used in Europe as a substitute for spinach or kale, but they're tricky to use.  The tips contain formic acid, a nasty irritant that can give you a serious rash on the outside and cause even more damage on the inside. You can remove the formic acid by cooking and/or soaking the nettles, but don't try this unless you know what you're doing.  If you're harvesting your own nettle leaves, select young ones.

Name: New Mexico green chili
Description: These large chilies are similar in size to Anaheims, but they're hotter. New Mexico green chilies peak in the late summer, while the hotter New Mexico red chilies appear in the fall. These are moderately hot.
Also known as: New Mexico chile, New Mexico red chile (when mature)

Name: New Mexico red chili
Description: These chilies have an earthy flavor and resemble the California chili, except they're hotter and more flavorful. They are moderately hot.
Also known as: chiles de ristra, New Mexican chile

Name: new potatoes
Description: The term "new potatoes" is sometimes used to describe all small waxy potatoes, but technically it refers just to immature potatoes harvested in the spring and early summer.  You can tell if a potato is truly new by its skin; immature potatoes have flimsy, parchment-like skins that you can peel off with your fingers.   New potatoes are prized for their high moisture content and creamy texture, and because they can be cooked whole.  They're especially good steamed or roasted.  They're more perishable than other potatoes, so use them within a few days after buying them.
Also known as: baby potatoes, chats, creamers, earlies, potato nuggets

Name: Nicoise olives
Description: A key ingredient in Salade Niçoise, these small purplish-black olives have a distinctive sour flavor. They're great in tapenades.

Name: nopales
Description: The canned version is acceptable substitute for fresh, but it has an inferior texture.
Also known as: nopal, prickly pear cactus leaf, prickly pear cactus pad, prickly pear cactus paddle

Name: Nyon olives
Description: These black olives from France are salt-cured, which makes them wrinkly and more bitter than standard lye-cured American black olives.

Name: oakleaf lettuce
Description: Oakleaf lettuce has crunchy stems and tender leaves.  There are  red and green varieties.

Name: oca potato
Description: Oca potatoes are root vegetables that are popular in New Zealand. They come in a range of colors, inclucing pink, yellow, orange and most commonly, red. Oca can be eaten raw or cooked.

Name: Okinawan purple potato
Description: The flesh of this tropical Asian sweet potato is vivid purple. It's perfect for tempura, but it can also be baked, sauteed, boiled, steamed, or mashed. It is very popular in desserts in the Philippines where it is know as ube.
Also known as: beni imo, Okinawan yam, purple yam, purple yam jam, ube

Name: okra
Description: When cooked, okra exudes a slimy substance, which serves as a wonderful thickener in stews. Unfortunately, that sliminess puts off many diners, but you can minimize it by buying small, fresh okra and by cooking it very briefly. Okra's popular in the South, where they fry it in cornmeal, pickle it (this also gets rid of the sliminess), and use it to thicken their gumbos.
Also known as: bamia, bamie, bhindi, bindi, gombo, gumbo, ladies' fingers, ladyfingers, ochro, okro, quiabo, quingombo

Name: Olives
