Many pie recipes call for instant tapioca instead of tapioca starch, but instant tapioca doesn't dissolve completely and leaves small gelatinous blobs suspended in the liquid. This isn't a problem in a two-crust pies, but the blobs are more noticeable in single-crust pies. Tapioca starch is finely ground so that it dissolves completely, eliminating the gelatinous blob problem. The starch is also sometimes used to thicken soups, stews, and sauces, but the glossy finish looks a bit unnatural in these kinds of dishes. It works quickly, though, so it's a good choice if you want to correct a sauce just before serving it. Some recipes for baked goods also call for tapioca flour because it imparts a chewier texture.
Also known as: almidon de yuca, cassava flour, tapioca flour, yucca starch
Substitutions: Instant flour,instant tapioca,Instant Clearjel,sweet rice flour,corn starch,arrowroot starch,potato starch,rice starch

Name: tarama
Description: Greek markets often carry jars of this pink cod roe. It's often used to make taramasalata, which is tarama mixed with a filler (like bread crumbs), oil, and seasonings.

Name: thickeners
Description:
Thickeners add substance and body to sauces, stews, soups, puddings, pie fillings, and other dishes.

Tips:
Before you add a thickener to a sauce, skim the fat from the top.  Once you've added the thickener, the fat will be harder to remove.
Flour is a good thickener for gravies, gumbos, and stews, since it gives them a smooth, velvety texture.   It's best to mix it with fat first, either by making a roux or beurre manié, or by flouring and frying stew meat before adding a liquid to the pot.  If you wish to cut fat from your diet, you can instead mix the flour with water and add it to the sauce, but you'll need to cook it for quite awhile to get rid of the starchy, raw flour taste.  Sauces thickened with flour become opaque, and they may become become thin again if they're cooked too long or if they're frozen and then thawed.
Starch thickeners like cornstarch are mixed with an equal amount of cold water, then added to warm liquids to thicken them.   They're a good choice if you want a low-fat, neutral-tasting thickener.  They give dishes a glossy sheen, which looks wonderful if you're making a dessert sauce or pie filling, but a bit artificial in a gravy or stew.
If you get lumps in your sauce from a thickener, blend the sauce in a blender or food processor until it's smooth.
Cereal grains like oatmeal, couscous, soup pasta, farina, are often used to thicken soups.  
Reduction is a slow but low-fat way of thickening sauces and concentrating flavors.  Just cook down the sauce in an uncovered pan until it's thickened to your liking.
Meat and fish glaces are a time-consuming--or expensive, if you buy them ready-made--way of thickening and enriching sauces.  They're made by reducing stocks until they're thick and gelatinous. 

A good way to thicken soups or stews is to add grated starchy vegetables, or to purée the vegetables in the sauce.   

Nuts make good, flavorful thickeners for stews, though they're often expensive and high in fat.  Just grind them down to a flour or butter, and add them to the dish. 

Egg yolks add a silky, velvety texture to soups and sauces, but they'll turn into scrambled eggs if they're not introduced carefully into the hot liquid.  
Cream, once reduced, gives sauces a rich texture and flavor as it thickens them, but it's high in fat.  To make a low-fat cream sauce, use evaporated milk mixed with a starch thickener. 
Yogurt is a popular soup thickener in Eastern Europe and the Middle East.

Name: ThickenThin™
Description: This thickener has no calories, fat, or carbohydrates.  It's great for thickening gravies, sauces, and soups, but it won't set up sufficiently to make puddings or custards. A little goes a long way, so use about half as much as you would a starch thickener.

Name: ti leaves
Description: South Pacific islanders use these to wrap food and to line the imu pits in which they roast pigs.

Name: trout caviar
Description: These are great for making hors d'oeuvres.
Substitutions: salmon roe,smoked salmon roe,golden caviar,flying fish roe,caviar,lumpfish roe

Name: vegetable yeast extract
Description: Includes:  Marmite, Vegemite, and Promite.

Name: vesiga
Description: Vesiga is the spinal cord of a European sturgeon. It is considered a delicacy in Russia. Coulibiac is a Russian dish that features vesiga.

Name: water chestnut starch
Description: Asian cooks often dredge foods in this before frying them, because it gives fried foods a crisp, nutty coating. It can also be used as a thickener. Look for it in Asian markets and health food stores. Don't confuse this with chestnut flour.
Also known as: water chestnut flour, water chestnut starch

Name: wax paper
Description: Invented by Thomas Edison, this is paper that's coated with paraffin wax to make it resistant to moisture. To use wax paper as a cake pan liner, place the pan on the paper, trace its outline, then cut it out and place it in the pan.

Name: whipped cream stabilizer
Description: Two brands are Whip It and Whipping Cream Aid.

Name: wine ball
Description: These are balls of brewer's yeast that are sold in Asian markets.  They're used to make wine.

Name: wonton wrappers
Description: Wontons are the Chinese answer to ravioli--small packets of meat encased in a thin noodle wrapper.  The wrappers are made of flour, eggs, and water, and, once filled with meat, can be easily folded and pinched into shape.    While assembling the wontons, keep the stack of wrappers moist by covering them with a damp towel.  You can seal the dumplings with a "glue" made with cornstarch and water.    The wrappers come in different thicknesses.  The thin ones work best in soups, while the thicker ones are best for frying.  Look for stacks of them wrapped in plastic in the refrigerator cases of Asian markets.   Store them in the refrigerator or freezer, but let them come to room temperature before using.
Substitutions: egg roll wrapers,dumpling wrappers,potsticker wrappers,pasta sheet

Name: xanthan
Description: Derived from corn sugar, xanthan gum is used as a thickener, stabilizer, and emulsifier.

Name: yam cake
Description: Yam cakes are made by combining yams, dried prawns and rice flower. Then shaping it and steaming it.

Name: almond oil
Description: Nut oils are best used in cold dishes; heat destroys their delicate flavor.
Also known as: expressed almond oil, huile d'amande, sweet almond oil

Name: annatto oil
Description: Annatto oil adds a bright red color and some flavor to foods. It is prepared by grinding annatto seeds and mixing the powder with oil.
Also known as: achiote oil, annato oil, annatto seed oil

Name: annatto paste
Description: Annatto paste adds a bright red color and some flavor to foods. It is prepared by grinding annatto seeds and mixing the powder with lard.

Name: bacon grease
Description: This is the fat that remains in the pan after cooking bacon. It's very flavorful, but high in cholesterol.

Name: butter
Description: This is a delicious solid fat churned from milk. It's used in baking, frying, and as a spread on toast and muffins. Recipes that call for butter in most better cookbooks are referring to unsalted butter = sweet cream butter = sweet butter. Salted butter doesn't spoil as readily (the salt serves as a preservative). See also the entries for whipped butter and European-style butter.
Also known as: Salted butter, sweet butter, sweet cream butter, unsalted butter

Name: canola oil
Description: Canola oil is a versatile, neutral-tasting oil that is very low in saturated fat.   Puritan is a well-known brand.
Substitutions: corn oil,peanut oil,vegetable oil,cooking spray,grapeseed oil,sunflower oil

Name: caul fat
Description: Look for this in the meat sections of Asian, French, and Italian markets.  Caul fat from pork is considered superior to caul fat from lamb.

Name: clarified butter
Description: This is butter without the milk solids, so it doesn't go rancid or smoke when heated to a high temperature. Look for jars of it in Indian markets.
Also known as: AMF, anhydrous milkfat, butter oil, drawn butter, ghee

Name: cooking spray
Description: includes vegetable oil spray, olive oil spray, and butter-flavored spray.

Name: copha
Description: This is a shortening based on coconut oil that's commonly used in Australia. It's very hard to find in the U.S.

Name: corn oil
Substitutions: canola oil,safflower oil,soybean oil,peanut oil,cooking spray

Name: duck fat
Scientific name:
Anas platyrhynchos domesticus
Anas platyrhynchos domesticus

Name: European-style butter
Description: Plugra  is a domestic brand.  Since European-style butter has a lower moisture content, using it results in better pastries, icings, and sauces.

Name: grapeseed oil
Description: This oil is pricey, but it has the highest smoke point of any oil, which makes it ideal for sautéing or frying over high heat. It's also a good salad oil. Some claim that it reduces the risk of heart disease by reducing LDL (bad cholesterol) levels in the body.
Substitutions: avocado oil,safflower oil,sunflower oil,peanut oil,corn oil,soybean oil

Name: hazelnut oil
Description: Nut oils are best used in cold dishes, as heat destroys their delicate flavor. Store in the refrigerator.

Name: hot chili oil
Description: Chinese cooks sometimes add a drop or so of this to dishes in order to heat them up. Look for small bottles of this in Asian markets and large supermarkets.

Name: lard
Description: Lard is rendered pork fat. It's high in saturated fat, and quite bad for you.  Still, it's the fat of choice for making flaky pie crusts, though it's not as flavorful as butter.  Some pastry chefs combine butter with lard to achieve a balance of flavor and flakiness. Lard is also used for frying since it can reach high temperatures without smoking.  See also the entries for lard leaves and lardo.

Name: lardo
Description: This is unrendered pork fat that fearless Italians slice and serve on bread.

Name: margarine
Description: In addition to regular margarine, supermarkets usually carry diet margarine = lite margarine (with about half the fat and more water and air), soft margarine, whipped margarine (containing up to 50% air).   These diet margarines make wonderful spreads, but they shouldn't be substituted for regular margarine in baked goods.  For more information, visit the Illinois Cooperative Extension Service's Lite Margarine--Substitution for Baking page.
Also known as: diet margarine, lite margarine, oleomargarine, soft margarine, whipped margarine

Name: mustard oil
Description: Mustard oil may be hard to find in the US. Indian markets would be your best bet.

Name: olive oil
Description: ranked from highest to lowest quality; extra-virgin, superfine, fine, virgin, and pure.
Substitutions: almond oil,hazelnut oil,sesame oil,walnut oil,peanut oil,corn oil,cooking spray

Name: palm oil
Description: This bright orange palm oil is a staple in Brazilian cuisine, but very high in saturated fat

Name: peanut oil
Substitutions: corn oil,soybean oil,safflower oil,canola oil,vegetable oil,cooking spray

Name: safflower oil
Substitutions: canola oil,corn oil,soybean oil,peanut oil,cooking spray

Name: sesame oil
Description: includes light sesame oil and stronger dark sesame oil. Sesame oil has a low smoke point and is relatively expensive, so it's not good for frying.

Name: shortening
Description: Shortening can be made from either animal fat or vegetable oil. Crisco is a popular brand.

Name: soybean oil
Substitutions: corn oil,canola oil,safflower oil,peanut oil,cooking spray

Name: suet
Description: It is the hard white fat on the kidneys and loins of cattle, sheep, and other animals, used to make foods including puddings, pastry, and mincemeat. Your butcher will probably give some of this to you for free.

Name: sunflower oil
Substitutions: walnut oil,safflower oil,canola oil,grapeseed oil,corn oil,soybean oil,peanut oil,cooking spray

Name: vegetable oil
Substitutions: corn oil,safflower oil,shortening,cooking spray,canola oil,grapeseed oil,peanut oil

Name: vegetable oil spray
Description: Pam is a well-known brand.

Name: walnut oil
Description: Nut oils are best used in cold dishes; heat destroys their delicate flavor.

Name: yak butter
Description: Butter made from yak milk. Traditionally added to tea in Tibet.

Name: abalone
Description: Asian markets are a good place to find these. Prod them gently before buying to make sure they're alive. The smaller ones are better. Canned or dried abalones are acceptable substitutes for fresh in some dishes. Unopened canned abalone can be stored for up to a year in a dry, cool place. Once opened, it will keep for up to two days if you wrap it well and refrigerate it.
Also known as: awabi, ear shells, loco, muttonfish, muttonshells, paua, sea ears

Name: albacore
Also known as: bintoro, German bonito, longfin tuna, Pacific albacore, shiro maguro, white tuna

Name: American black caviar
Description: If substituting an inferior caviar, consider perking it up with a splash of fresh lemon juice.

Name: anchovies
Description: It's best to get these salted rather than canned.  Rinse the salt off before using.  Unopened canned anchovies can be stored for up to a year in a dry, cool place. Once opened, they will keep for up to two days if you wrap them well and refrigerate them.

Name: arctic char
Description: A trout relative, the arctic char is highly prized for its sweetness and tenderness. It's often roasted or smoked.

Name: ayu
Description: Japanese fishermen tie knots around the necks of cormorants (black sea birds) and have them dive and catch these exquisite fish.  They're very sweet and delicate.

Name: bar clam
Also known as: Atlantic surf clam, hen clam, sea clam, skimmer

Name: basa
Description: The flesh is firm and white and milder than our catfish. This Vietnamese catfish relative has a mild flavor and firm texture.
Also known as: basa catfish, bocourti, China sole, Mekong catfish, Pacific dory, panga, pangas catfish, river cobbler, swai, tra, white roughy

Name: bay scallops
Description: Shopping hints: These are easier to find in the East than in the West. Frozen scallops are a good substitute for fresh.

Name: beluga caviar
Description: In recent years, over-fishing in the Caspian Sea has greatly depleted sturgeon populations. Please consider using caviar and roe from more abundant species until the Caspian Sea sturgeon populations can recover.Beluga caviar is one of the best and priciest of the caviars. The eggs are large and bluish-grey, and slightly sweet. A pasteurized version is available in jars, but fresh caviar is much better. Malossol (lightly salted) beluga is the finest, and the most expensive. If substituting an inferior caviar, consider perking it up with a splash of fresh lemon juice.For substitutions for caviar in general, click here.
Substitutions: hackleback roe,keluga caviar,ossetra caviar,sevruga caviar,paddlefish roe,bowfin roe,lumpfish roe

Name: blackfish
Description: This category includes hogfish and cunner, which are very similar to blackfish.

Name: blood clam
Also known as: blood cockle, bloody clam, clam, blood

Name: blue crab
Description: These are found on the Atlantic coast. They're small, but otherwise similar to Dungeness crabs. When they molt, they're called soft-shelled crabs, a wonderful delicacy that can be eaten shell and all
Also known as: Atlantic blue crab, Chesapeake blue crab, soft-shell crab

Name: bluefin tuna
Description: This is the favorite for sushi. It is the most expensive.

Name: Bombay duck
Description: This is a ten inch fish is native to coastal India. It is eaten fresh or salted and dried. It can have a very powerful smell.
Also known as: bombili, bummalo, loitta, lote, strange fish

Name: bonita
Also known as: bonita tuna, bonito ((incorrectly)), false albacore, little tuna, little tunny

Name: bonito dried
Description: Bonito are related to mackerel, and the Japanese dry them and use them in soups. They're often shaved into thin flakes called bonito flakes or hanakatsuo.

Name: bonito flakes
Description: This includes kezuribushi = kezuri-bushi, a version with smaller flakes.
Also known as: dried bonito flakes, hana-katsuo, hanakatsuo, katsuobushi, kezuri-bushi, kezuribushi

Name: bottarga
Description: This Mediterranean specialty is made from the salted and sun-dried roe of either tuna (bottarga di tonno) or mullet (bottarga di muggine). You usually buy it as a sausage and shave off thin slices for hors d'oeuvres or grate it over pasta, fish, or salads. It's expensive but very tasty.
Also known as: botarega, botargo, boutarque, salted mullet roe, Sardinian caviar

Name: bowfin roe
Description: This has small, very dark olive-green eggs with medium firmness. It's an inexpensive, environmentally responsible alternative to the luxury caviars from the Caspian Sea. Consider perking up the flavor with a splash of fresh lemon juice.
Also known as: American black caviar, black American bowfin caviar, black sturgeon roe, choupique

Name: buffalofish
Description: The buffalo fish is a North American bottom feeding game fish. It is similar to a carp. They are long lived and can grow up to 80 lb. and 4'.
Also known as: bernard buffalo, brown buffalo, gourdhead, ictiobus, marblehead, roundhead

Name: butterfish
Description: The name "butterfish" is sometimes also given to sablefish and to the delicious escolar, which you should read about before buying, since it's also called ex-lax fish.

Name: canal shrimp
Description: These are popular in Japan, where they're often served as tempura.

Name: cape capensis
Also known as: African hake, Cape hake, Cape whiting, shallow-water Cape hake, South African hake

Name: capelin roe
Description: Japanese cooks use these tiny, fluorescent eggs as a topping for sushi.

Name: caviar
Description: Over-fishing in the Caspian Sea has greatly depleted sturgeon populations. Please consider using roe from more abundant species until the Caspian Sea sturgeon populations can recover.Caviar is known for its subtle, buttery flavor, sensuous texture, and high price. It should always be served cold.Just as diamonds are rated according to the four Cs, caviar can be evaluated by the three Fs--flavor, firmness, and freshness. The flavor of caviar depends on the sturgeon's species and habitat, and is variously described as buttery, nutty, sweet, fruity, earthy, briny, and even herbaceous. The firmness of each egg determines how the eggs burst when you squeeze them against the roof of your mouth with your tongue. Fresh caviar is considered much better than the pasteurized version.Varieties: (from highest to lowest price) imperial caviar, beluga caviar, ossetra caviar, and sevruga caviar. Imperial caviar is the rarest and most expensive. Beluga caviar is soft, and almost melts in your mouth. Ossetra and sevruga caviars are relatively firm, and will pop when gently squeezed. Within these categories, malossol, or lightly salted caviar, is of higher quality than pressed caviar = payusnaya.If substituting an inferior caviar, consider perking it up with a splash of fresh lemon juice.Equivalents: 2 tablespoons = 1 ounceFresh caviar lasts just over a year if properly stored, though its shelf-life can be extended with heavy salting. Experts claim that some of the fresh caviar that's being sold at bargain prices over the Internet is well past its prime. The color and size of the eggs--called the bead--can help you (and your guests) identify the different varieties of caviar.
Also known as: Malossol caviar, payusnaya caviar, pressed caviar, sturgeon roe
Substitutions: hackleback roe,paddlefish roe,salmon roe,lumpfish roe,bowfin roe

Name: chum salmon
Also known as: dog salmon, keta salmon, silverbrite salmon

Name: clam
Description: See also pismo clam, soft-shell clam, razor clam, Manila clam, hard-shell clam, bar clam, and geoduck clam. Storage: Unopened canned clams can be stored for up to a year in a dry, cool place. Once opened, it will keep for up to two days if you wrap it well and refrigerate it.

Name: cobia
Also known as: black bonito, black kingfish, black salmon, coalfish, crabeater, lemonfish, ling, sergeant fish

Name: cod
Description: This includes cod cheeks, which are good and inexpensive, cod tongues, cod sounds, which are the cod's air bladders, and scrod = schrod, which are young cod.  See also salt cod.
Also known as: cod cheeks, cod sounds, cod tongues, codling, markets, schrod, scrod, streakers

Name: cod cheeks
Description: cod cheeks, which are good and inexpensive

Name: cod roe
Description: Scandinavian markets sell this in tubes, so that it can be extruded onto crackers and such for hors d'oeuvres. It's relatively inexpensive, but very salty.

Name: coho salmon
Also known as: medium red salmon, silver salmon, silvers

Name: conch
Description: This is popular in Florida and the Caribbean.  In other regions, your best bet is to look in Asian or Italian markets.

Name: crab
Description: Eat fresh crab the day you buy it.  Unopened canned crab can be stored for up to a year in a dry, cool place. Once opened, it will keep for up to two days if you wrap it well and refrigerate it.

Name: crayfish
Description: Crayfish are very popular in Louisiana, where restaurants serve them on large platters along with bowls of melted butter. Buy live ones if you can; if not, large supermarkets sometimes stock frozen whole crayfish or crayfish tails. Get the whole crayfish if possible--most of the flavor resides in the shells. Allow one to two pounds per person.
Also known as: crawdad, crawdaddies, crawfish, craydids, ecrevisse, écrevisse, freshwater lobsters, mudbugs, yabbies

Name: cuttlefish
Description: This is a close relative of squid and octopus. You can sometimes find dried cuttlefish in Asian markets.

Name: dogfish
Description: This commercially fished shark is enjoyed around the world.
Also known as: Cape shark, huss, mud shark, piked dogfish, rock salmon, sea eel, spiny dogfish, spurdog

Name: drums
Description: This category includes yellowfish = yellow croaker (pictured), corvina = spotfin croaker, drum, redfish = red drum, white sea bass, kingfish, weakfish, and spot.   Substitutes:  hake (tastier) OR mullet OR tuna OR red snapper OR pompano.

Name: Dublin Bay prawn
Also known as: Dublin prawn, langoustine, Norway lobster, scampi

Name: Dungeness crab
Description: Found on the Pacific coast, the Dungeness is a large crab highly prized for its sweet meat.

Name: eel
Description: These haven't caught on much in the U.S., but they're highly prized in Europe and Japan for their rich, firm meat and terrific flavor. Freshness is crucial, so always buy live eels. Smaller eels are more tender. This category includes conger eel = conger = anago, which are tough saltwater eels that are sometimes available in fish markets in the spring and summer, elvers = angulas = baby eels, which are about an inch long and very expensive, and freshwater eel = unagi.
Also known as: anago, angulas, baby eels, conger, conger eel, elvers, freshwater eel, unagi

Name: elvers
Description: Elvers are juvenile eels. They are thin and about 2" long. Elvers are a delicacy especially in Spain and Asia. They are caught as they return to freshwater streams after being born in the mid-Atlantic.

Name: escolar
Description: This excellent Hawaiian fish tastes like a buttery halibut. Unfortunately, it contains a natural laxative and eating it can cause serious gastrointestinal distress. Because of this, several governments (though not the US) have either banned its importation or required that it be sold with warning labels.A workaround is to eat only small (four ounces or less) portions of the fish, or to bring a change of clothes if you're dining out.
Also known as: butterfish, ex-lax fish, king tuna, oilfish, Shiro Maguro, snake mackerel, super white tuna, waloo, walu, walu walu

Name: farmed salmon
Description: These are salmon that are raised in pens in the ocean. The wild populations are known as Atlantic salmon.

Name: flying fish roe
Description: These fluorescent orange eggs are wonderfully crunchy and flavorful. The Japanese are particularly fond of them.

Name: golden caviar
Description: This has crunchy, amber-colored eggs and makes a colorful garnish. They're often flavored with various seasonings before they're sold.
Also known as: American golden caviar, whitefish caviar, whitefish roe
Substitutions: capelin roe,flying fish roe,lumpfish roe,salmon roe,trout caviar

Name: green mussel
Also known as: green shell mussel, greenlipped mussel, greenshell mussel, kuku, kutai, mussel, green, New Zealand green mussel
Substitutions: mussels,Prince Edward Island mussel,oyster,soft-shell clam,littleneck clams

Name: grouper
Description: This category includes California sea bass, jewfish, and cabrilla.

Name: hackleback roe
Description: This American caviar comes from farm-raised hacklebacks.

Name: hard-shell clam
Description: Littleneck clams are smaller than cherrystone clams which are smaller than quahog clams = quahaug clams = chowder clams which are smaller than ocean quahog clams = ocean quahaug clams = mahogany clams = black clams.
Also known as: cherrystones, chowder clams, countnecks, hard clam, hardshell clams, littlenecks, peanuts, quahog, round clam, topnecks

Name: herring roe
Description: The Japanese traditionally serve this on New Year's Day. It has an interesting texture, but it's not very flavorful.

Name: imperial caviar
Description: In recent years, over-fishing in the Caspian Sea has greatly depleted sturgeon populations.Please consider using caviar and roe from more abundant species until the Caspian Sea sturgeon populations can recover.For substitutions for caviar in general, click here.
Also known as: golden oscietre, golden ossetra, royal caviar, shah's caviar
Substitutions: ossetra caviar,paddlefish roe,hackleback roe,bowfin roe,lumpfish roe

Name: John Dory
Also known as: Dory, European John Dory, Peter's Fish, St Pierre

Name: Jonah crab
Description: These are found in the coastal waters of New England.

Name: kamaboko
Description: This colorful Japanese specialty is made of a fish paste that's been molded into logs or half-logs.

Name: king crab
Description: These have long, spindly legs and are found off the coast of Alaska and Japan.
Also known as: Alaskan king crab, Japanese king crab, red king crab, Russian crab

Name: kippered black cod
Also known as: Alaska smoked cod, smoked sable, smoked sablefish

Name: lingcod
Also known as: buffalo cod, cultus cod, ling cod

Name: lobster coral
Description: This roe turns a lovely coral color when cooked.

Name: lox
Description: Look for this in the deli section of your grocery stores.

Name: lumpfish roe
Description: Lumpfish roe is relatively cheap; the eggs come in red or black.

Name: mackerel
Description: Unopened canned mackerel can be stored for up to a year in a dry, cool place. Once opened, it will keep for up to two days if you wrap it well and refrigerate it.

Name: mahi-mahi
Description: Though leaner than, say salmon or tuna, mahi-mahi packs a lot of heart-healthy omega-3 fatty acids.

Name: Manila clam
Also known as: Japanese carpet shell, Japanese cockle, Japanese littleneck clam

Name: monkfish
Description: This fish isn't a looker, but it has a flavor and texture that's been compared to lobster and scallops.

Name: monkfish liver
Description: This exquisite Japanese delicacy has the texture and richness of a choice pâté de foie gras. It's usually poached, steamed, or sautéed before serving in order. Look for it in well-stocked Japanese markets.
Also known as: ankimo, foie de lotte, monkfish foie gras

Name: mullet
Description: This category includes red mullet, white mullet, and the fattier black mullet = striped mullet.
Also known as: black mullet, grey mullet, red mullet, striped mullet, white mullet

Name: mussels
Description: Storage: Unopened canned mussels can be stored for up to a year in a dry, cool place. Once opened, it will keep for up to two days if you wrap it well and refrigerate it.

Name: nova
Description: Nova is made by curing salmon through both curing with salt and smoking. It is similar to lox.

Name: orange roughy
Also known as: deep sea perch, red roughy, slimehead

Name: ormer
Description: This is a variety of abalone found in the Mediterain and North Atlantic.

Name: ossetra caviar
Description: In recent years, over-fishing in the Caspian Sea has greatly depleted sturgeon populations. Please consider using caviar and roe from more abundant species until the Caspian Sea sturgeon populations can recover.Ossetra caviar is brown and more strongly flavored than beluga caviar. Don't confuse ordinary ossetra with the rare and expensive golden ossetra = imperial caviar. If substituting an inferior caviar, consider perking it up with a splash of fresh lemon juice.For substitutions for caviar in general, click here.
Also known as: asetra caviar, ocietra caviar, oscietre caviar
Substitutions: sevruga caviar,beluga caviar,paddlefish roe,hackleback roe,bowfin roe,lumpfish roe

Name: oyster
Description: The French like to serve these raw in the shell, with just a squirt of fresh lemon juice, but they can also be fried, grilled, or gently poached. If you eat them raw, you'll need to shuck them first; an oyster knife comes in handy for this. Storage: Unopened canned oysters can be stored for up to a year in a dry, cool place. Once opened, it will keep for up to two days if you wrap it well and refrigerate it.

Name: paddlefish roe
Description: Paddlefish swim in Southern rivers and they're relatives of sturgeons--the fish that produce the world's most expensive and exquisite caviars. Paddlefish roe is very similar to sevruga caviar, only it's cheaper. Since Caspian Sea sturgeon are rapidly becoming depleted from over-fishing, many people are turning to paddlefish roe as a substitute for caviar.

Name: parrotfish
Description: This tropical fish is delicious, but environmentalists worry that overfishing will harm coral reefs, since parrotfish clean them of algae. In addition, parrotfish also convert dead coral into white sand (up to 220 pounds of sand per fish per year) that we all love to walk and play volleyball on.As with all reef fish, parrotfish also contain a toxin called ciguatera, which can cause food poisoning. You can reduce the risk by not eating the fish's head or organs.

Name: peekytoe crabs
Description: These small, highly prized crabs resemble Dungeness crabs, only they're much smaller. It's hard to find whole crabs, but many seafood shops in New England sell peekytoe crab meat.
Also known as: Atlantic rock crab, Maine crabs, mud crabs, rock crabs, sand crabs

Name: perch
Description: This category includes walleye = wall-eyed pike, and Nile perch = Lake Victoria perch.
Also known as: Lake Victoria perch, Nile perch, wall-eyed pike, walleye

Name: periwinkle
Description: These marine snails are better known in Europe and Japan than in the United States. They're great in any clam chowder recipe, though they tend to get tough if overcooked. Look for them in Asian markets.

Name: pilchards
Description: Pilchards belong to the same species as sardines, but they're caught in colder waters and are bigger.

Name: pirarucu
Description: Pirarucu are large (7 feet) fish native to the Amazon basin. Pirarucu meat is mild flavored and firm textured. Overfishing has reduced their numbers. It is unusual in that in needs to breath air.

Name: pismo clam
Description: pismos are highly regarded.

Name: plaice
Also known as: Alaskan plaice, American plaice, European plaice, scale-eye plaice

Name: pollock
Description: Pollock is an important north Pacific groundfish.
Also known as: Alaska pollock, Boston bluefish, Pacific Pollock, walleye pollock

Name: pollock roe
Description: Asian markets sell this inexpensive roe in wooden boxes. It's often baked and served on rice.

Name: pomfret
Description: You can buy frozen pomfret in Asian markets.

Name: porgies
Description: This category includes the scup = fair maid, sea bream, red porgy, sheepshead porgy, shad porgy, whitebone porgy, and jolthead porgy.  Porgies tend to be bony, but they're highly prized for their delicate flavor.
Also known as: fair maid, jolthead porgy, red porgy, scup, sea bream, shad porgy, sheepshead porgy, whitebone porgy

Name: Prince Edward Island mussel
Description: These farmed-raised mussels are sweet and beardless.
Also known as: blue mussel, Island blue mussel, mussels, Prince Edward Island, PEI mussel

Name: quahog
Also known as: chowder clam, hard clam, hard-shell clam, quahaug clam, quahog clam

Name: rainbow runner
Also known as: Hawaiian salmon, kamanu, rainbow yellowtail, Spanish jack

Name: razor clam
Also known as: American jackknife clam, Arctic razor clam, Atlantic jackknife clam, Atlantic razor clam, bamboo clam, Gould's razor shell, Pacific razor clam, razor fish, rosy razor clam, spoot

Name: sablefish
Also known as: beshow, black cod, blue cod, butterfish (incorrectly), candlefish, coal cod, skil, snowfish

Name: salmon
Description:
Species include; coho salmon, chinook salmon, red sockeye, pink salmon, and chum salmon.
Unopened canned salmon can be stored for up to a year in a dry, cool place. Once opened, it will keep for up to two days if you wrap it well and refrigerate it.

Name: salmon roe
Description: These eggs just explode in your mouth. They make wonderful hors d'oeuvres.
Substitutions: smoked salmon roe,trout caviar,golden caviar,flying fish roe,caviar,lumpfish roe

Name: salt cod
Description: Salt cod was traditionally caught and salted by Portuguese fisherman in the North Atlantic. It is popular in Europe and around the Mediterranean. It needs to be soaked in fresh water for one or two days to remove the salt before cooking.
Also known as: bacalao, bacalhau, dried salted codfish, kippfisk (Norway), salt dolly, saltfish

Name: salted herring roe
Description: This is very salty and very expensive.

Name: sardines
Description: Unopened canned sardines can be stored for up to a year in a dry, cool place. Once opened, they will keep for up to two days if you wrap them well and refrigerate them.

Name: scallop roe
Description: This coral-colored roe is expensive and hard to find, but it has a wonderful, delicate flavor. The roe is usually both sold and served with the scallop that produced it.

Name: sea slug
Description: comes dried or fresh

Name: sea urchin roe
Description: Red roe is more expensive than yellow, but the taste is similar.
Also known as: sea eggs, sea urchin corals, uni

Name: sevruga caviar
Description: In recent years, over-fishing in the Caspian Sea has greatly depleted sturgeon populations. Please consider using caviar and roe from more abundant species until the Caspian Sea sturgeon populations can recover.Greenish-gray sevruga has the smallest eggs and strongest flavor of all the caviars. Because of this, it's cheaper than beluga or ossetra, but still quite good. If substituting an inferior caviar, consider perking it up with a splash of fresh lemon juice.For substitutions for caviar in general, click here.
Substitutions: paddlefish roe,hackleback roe,ossetra caviar,beluga caviar,bowfin roe,lumpfish roe

Name: shad roe
Description: You can buy lobes of this roe fresh in the springtime, or in cans during the rest of the year. Canned shad roe is good, but not quite as good as fresh.

Name: shrimp
Description: There are many different species of shrimp, but generally speaking, the larger the shrimp, the tastier. In the US and Britain, large shrimp are called prawns; in India, all shrimp are prawns. Bay shrimp are very small. You can buy shrimp raw (sometimes called green), or cooked. Don't buy cooked shrimp if you plan to serve it warm--they turns rubbery when reheated. Unopened canned shrimp can be stored for up to a year in a dry, cool place. Once opened, it will keep for up to two days if you wrap it well and refrigerate it

Name: skate
Description: Skates are delicious, but many people are put off by their bizarre looks.  Only the wings are edible.  Like their shark relatives, skates have cartilage and tough, sandpapery skin.  One way to loosen the skin is to poach them briefly in a mixture of three parts water, one part vinegar.   After you peel off the skin, the wing can be further poached, or baked or fried.

Name: smelt roe
Description: This is bright orange and moderately crunchy.

Name: smoked sprats
Description: These come in cans packed in oil.  Northern Europeans like them on hearty bread.

Name: smoked whitefish
Description: This is delicious in salads.  Look for it in upscale delis.

Name: snow crab
Description: This is an East Coast version of the king crab.
Also known as: queen crab, rock crab, spider crab, tanner crab

Name: sockeye salmon
Also known as: blueback salmon, kokanee salmon, red salmon

Name: soft-shell clam
Description: steamer Includes: Highly regarded Maine steamers and Long Island steamers, and less esteemed Maryland steamers.
Also known as: Essex clams, Ipswich clams, piss clams, sand gaper, steamer

Name: sole
Description: Includes gray sole, petrale sole, English sole, Dover sole, and Rex sole.
Also known as: Dover sole, English sole, gray sole, petrale sole, Rex sole

Name: spiny eel
Description: In the United States, you're more likely to find these in an aquarium that in a supermarket, but Southeast Asians consider them a delicacy.

Name: sprats
Description: These tiny fish are similar to anchovies and sardines, and often sold in cans. You're supposed to eat the whole thing, including the head and tail.

Name: stone crab
Description: This is found on the East Coast, especially in Florida. Just the claws are harvested. Substitutes: claws of blue crabs

Name: surimi
Description: Imitation crab meat. It is normally made from processed fish meat.
Also known as: crab sticks, imitation seafood, sea legs, seafood sticks

Name: taape
Description: This beautiful fish was introduced to Hawaii in 1958, and it multiplied so quickly that it's now crowding out some native species.  Buying this fish helps prod fishermen to rid Hawaiian waters of this nuisance.  It's a tasty fish, too, though there's concern that some of these fish may carry ciguatera, a toxin that affects certain reef fish.

Name: tarama
Description: Greek markets often carry jars of this pink cod roe. It's often used to make taramasalata, which is tarama mixed with a filler (like bread crumbs), oil, and seasonings.

Name: tilapia
Substitutions: red snapper,Chilean sea bass,flounder,sole,orange roughy,ocean perch

Name: trout caviar
Description: These are great for making hors d'oeuvres.
Substitutions: salmon roe,smoked salmon roe,golden caviar,flying fish roe,caviar,lumpfish roe

Name: tuna
Description: Unopened canned tuna can be stored for up to a year in a dry, cool place. Once opened, it will keep for up to two days if you wrap it well and refrigerate it. Varieties include albacore, bluefin, blackfin, bonito, skipjack = aku, kawakawa, and the leaner yellowfin = bigeye = ahi.
Also known as: ahi (yellowfin), aku (skipjack), albacore, bigeye (yellowfin), blackfin, bluefin, bonito, kawakawa, skipjack, yellowfin

Name: turbot
Description: Turbot is an outstanding fish, but somewhat expensive.

Name: vesiga
Description: Vesiga is the spinal cord of a European sturgeon. It is considered a delicacy in Russia. Coulibiac is a Russian dish that features vesiga.

Name: whiting
Also known as: Carolina whiting, king whiting, sea mullet, southern kingcroaker, southern kingfish

Name: ababai
Description: Ababais resemble small papayas, and can be cooked or grilled without losing their shape. They're hard to find outside of Chile, where they're grown.

Name: abiu
Description: The round smooth yellow abiu fruit has a creamy texture and the sweet flavor of caramel or vanilla. It is native to the Amazon basin. The abiu fruit has a short shelf life.

Name: acai berry
Description: Acai berries are from the acai palm that is native to the Amazon Basin in Brazil. The small round dark purple fruit grows in clusters. Acai berries have a slight bitter taste. Long enjoyed in Brazil Acai berries have become increasing popular world wide over the last several decades. It is high in antioxidants.

Name: acerola
Description: These are very rich in vitamin C, and somewhat acidic. You can eat them out of hand, but they're better suited for making preserves.
Also known as: acerola cherry, Barbados cherry, Puerto Rican cherry, West Indian cherry, wild crepe myrtle

Name: achacha
Description: Achacha fruit is orange and has a sweet tart lemony taste. The fruit is oval and one to two inches in diameter. The achacha tree is native to the Amazon basin.

Name: ackee
Description:
The pulp of this fruit looks and tastes like scrambled eggs when cooked, and Jamaicans like to serve it with salt cod.   Look for cans of it in Caribbean markets.  
Warning:  Only the yellow pulp on ripe ackees is edible.  Eating underripe ackees that haven't opened on their own, or eating the pink portion of ripe ackees, can cause vomiting and death.
Also known as: achee, akee, vegetable brains, vegetable egg

Name: acorn squash
Description: This orange-fleshed winter squash is popular because of its small size--it can be cut in half and baked to make two generous servings. The rind, unfortunately, is quite hard and difficult to cut. To avoid injuring yourself, first slice off both the top and the bottom with a sharp knife, and use the stem end as a base for the more treacherous halving cut. Select acorn squash with as much green on the rind as possible, though most will have a single orange spot on one side.
Substitutions: buttercup squash,butternut squash,banana squash,turban squash,Hubbard squash,pumpkin,green papaya,golden nugget squash

Name: Agrinion olives
Description: This is a large, green Greek olive with very tender flesh.

Name: ají panca chili - dried
Description: This reddish-brown dried chili is fruity, mild, and a little smoky.

Name: ajwa dates
Description: These dark skinned ajwa dates are grown around Medina, Saudi Arabia. They were said to have been a favorite of the prophet Mohammad.

Name: Aleppo olives
Description: This is a black, dry-cured Middle Eastern olive that's hard to find in the United States.

Name: Alphonso olives
Description: This large Chilean olive is cured in a wine or wine vinegar solution, which gives it a beautiful dark purple color and tart flavor. Its flesh is very tender and slightly bitter.

Name: ambrosia apple
Description: Crisp and juicy, this is a great apple for snacking.

Name: ambrosia melon
Description: This looks and tastes like a cantaloupe, but the flesh is a brighter orange.

Name: American eggplant
Description: This is the familiar large, dark purple, pear-shaped variety. Choose small or medium-sized eggplants (these have fewer bitter seeds) with healthy-looking green stems that are firm to the touch, but not too hard. Avoid mushy ones. Store them in the refrigerator.

Name: Amphissa olives
Description: These are dark purple Greek olives that are hard to find in the U.S. They're great for snacking.

Name: Anaheim chili
Description: These large, mild chiles are perfect for chiles rellenos. Mexican cooks also like to dice or purée them, and then add them to sauces, soups, and casseroles. They have a tough skin, but it peels off easily if you first char the chiles over a flame and then steam them in a paper bag for several minutes. Anaheims are available year-round, but they're best in the summer. You can occasionally find red Anaheims, which are riper and slightly hotter. When dried, this pepper is called a chile Colorado.
Also known as: Anaheim chile, Anaheim chili pepper, Anaheim chilli, California green chili, california red chili (when mature and red), chile colorado (when mature and red), chile verde (CHEE-lay VER-day), long green pepper
Substitutions: New Mexico green chili,poblano pepper ,green chile canned

Name: ancho chili
Description: These mild, dried poblano peppers have a sweet, fruity flavor and are a staple in Mexican cuisine. They're brownish-black and wrinkled, and commonly used in adobos, moles, salsas, and various sauces.
Also known as: ancho chile, ancho chino, chile color, chile colorado, dried poblano, pasilla chile (incorrectly), pasilla rojo
Substitutions: mulato chili ,pasilla chili,poblano pepper ,California chili ,New Mexico red chili

Name: angled loofa
Description: A native of Pakistan, this mild vegetable has a slightly bitter edge that pairs well with sweet and acidic ingredients in stir-fry dishes. You can also eat it raw, or dry it to make a loofa sponge.You can leave the peel on, but some people find the flavor off-putting. Remove any large seeds if you wish to cut the bitterness.
Also known as: angled loofah, angled luffa, Chinese loofah, Chinese okra, dish cloth gourd, luffa angled gourd, luffa gourd, ribbed loofah, ridge gourd, ridged gourd, silk gourd, silky gourd, sinkwa towelsponge, sponge gourd, vegetable gourd

Name: Anjou pear
Description: These economical pears aren't as tasty as some of the other varieties, but they're still good for both eating and cooking. The peel stays light green even when the pear is ripe.

Name: apple butter
Description: Apple butter isn't made from real butter. Instead, it's made by cooking apples until the sugar in them caramelizes, turning the sauce a rich brown color. It's used as a spread, and also as a fat-free substitute in many baking recipes.

Name: apple cider
Description: Apple juice and apple cider are very similar, except that all of the apple pulp is filtered out of the juice, while some remains in the cider.

Name: apple green eggplant
Description: These eggplant resemble green apples, and are mild and sweet. You don't need to peel them.

Name: apple jelly
Description: You can use this like any other jelly, but it's often used as a glaze when roasting pork.

Name: apple juice
Description: Apple juice and apple cider are very similar, except that all of the apple pulp is filtered out of the juice, while some remains in the cider.

Name: applesauce
Description: Applesauce is a purée made from cooked apples. It's often flavored with sugar, lemon juice, and spices like cinnamon and allspice. It's often served as an accompaniment to pork, sausages, and potato pancakes. It can also be used as a fat substitute in baking.

Name: apricot
Description: Like other stone fruit, apricots are sweetest--and most prone to bruising--when they're allowed to ripen on the tree.  But unless you can pick your own, you'll probably have to make do with the slightly underripe, more durable apricots sold in markets.  Allow them to soften at room temperature for a few days before eating them.  They're best in the summer.

Name: aprium
Description: This is an apricot/plum cross, with apricot dominating.

Name: Arauco olives
Description: These are large green Spanish olives flavored with rosemary.

Name: Arbequina olives
Description: These are tiny green Spanish olives with a mild, smoky flavor. They're hard to find in the U.S.

Name: Arkansas Black apple
Description: This apple is renown for its long shelf life. It's good for making sauce and baking.

Name: Armenian cucumber
Also known as: snake cucumber, snake melon, This is hard to find, but one of the best-regarded slicing cucumbers.  It's crisp, thin-skinned, and mild-flavored, and it has soft seeds.  Like the English cucumber, it doesn't need to be peeled or seeded.  It's not good for pickling., uri

Name: Asian eggplants
Description: Include Japanese eggplants and Chinese eggplants, have thinner skins and a more delicate flavor than American eggplants, and not as many of the seeds that tend to make eggplants bitter. They're usually more slender than American eggplants, but they vary in size and shape. They range in color from lavender to pink, green, and white.
Also known as: Chinese eggplants, Japanese eggplants, Oriental eggplants

Name: Asian pear
Description: Asian pears are crunchy, juicy, and very fragrant. Growers produce over twenty different varieties in an assortment of sizes and colors. They're often served raw, but they can also be cooked, though they never become as soft as cooked pears.
Also known as: apple pear, Chinese pear, Japanese pear, nashi, nashi pear, Oriental pear, salad pear, sand pear

Name: Atalanta olives
Description: This is a muddy-green Greek olive with soft flesh.

Name: atemoya
Description: This cherimoya-sweetsop cross has sweet custard-like pulp. Look for it in specialty produce markets during the fall

Name: autumn royal grapes
Description: These are large dark purple sweet seedless grapes.

Name: baby kiwifruit
Description: You can eat this tiny kiwifruit hybrid skin and all.

Name: bacon avocado
Description: This sweet, smooth-skinned variety shows up in the middle of winter.  It's not as flavorful as other avocados.

Name: bacuri
Description: Bacuri fruit have thick yellow skins and are about the size of large apple. The bacuri fruit is both sweet and a little sour and is made into condiments and drinks.

Name: Baldwin apple
Description: This is a fairly sweet, all-purpose apple, but it's hard to find.

Name: banana
Description: Most of the bananas you and I have eaten in our lifetimes are the yellow Cavendish bananas. The burro banana = chunkey = chunky is shorter than the Cavendish, and has an interesting lemony flavor. The manzano banana is smaller yet and a bit drier, but it fits nicely into lunch boxes. The red banana has a purple peel and is best used for baking. The plantain is larger than other banana varieties, and is usually fried, baked, or mashed before eating. Yellow bananas with a few dark spots are ripe and ready to eat, while green ones will ripen at room temperature in just a few days. Refrigerating ripe bananas will keep them from getting softy and mushy, though the peels will darken.
Also known as: burro banana, Cavendish bananas, chunkey, chunky, red banana

Name: banana pepper
Description: These sweet, mild peppers with a fruity flavor are easily confused with hotter yellow wax peppers. Sample before using.
Also known as: banana chile, banana chili pepper, banana wax pepper, sweet banana pepper

Name: banana squash
Description: This variety is so large that grocers usually cut into smaller chunks before putting it out.  It's tasty, but its biggest virtue is the beautiful golden color of its flesh.

Name: barhi dates (fresh)
Description: These yellow barhi dates can be peeled and eaten fresh or dried.

Name: Bartlett pear
Description: These are very juicy and great for eating out of hand.  They turn yellow when ripe.

Name: bell pepper
Description: Red and yellow peppers are riper, more flavorful, and pricier than the more common green ones. You can occasionally find bell peppers in other colors as well, like brown, white, pink, orange, and purple.Bell peppers are the perfect size for hollowing out and stuffing, or you can slice them into strips for snacking or dipping.

Name: bergamot orange
Description: This is a small acidic orange, used for its peel. The flesh is too bitter and sour to be eaten raw. Don't confuse it with the bergamot herb.

Name: bilberry
Description: This small, tart berry is the European counterpart to the American blueberry. Bilberries are usually made into preserves.

Name: bitter melon
Description: This bitter vegetable is believed to have medicinal properties and is widely used throughout Asia.
Also known as: ampalaya, balsam pear, bitter apple, bitter cucumber, bitter gourd, bitter squash, Chinese bitter melon, foo gwa, karela

Name: bitter orange juice
Also known as: bigarade orange juice, Seville orange juice, sour orange juice

Name: black currant
Description: These are too tart to eat out of hand, but they're often used to make syrups, preserves, and the liqueur cassis.  Frozen are a good substitute for fresh.

Name: black currant jelly
Description: Black currant jelly is sweeter than more common red currant jelly.

Name: black olives
Description: These are olives that have been allowed to ripen on the tree. American recipes that call for black olives are probably referring to the Mission olive. Other varieties of black olives are the Aleppo, Alphonso, Amphissa, black Cerignola, Gaeta, black Greek, Kalamata, Ligurian, Lugano, Moroccan dry-cured, Niçoise, Nyons, Ponentine, and Royal.

Name: black sapote
Description: This fruit has an olive-green rind and tastes like a papaya that's been sprinkled with cocoa.

Name: blackberry
Description: These would be excellent berries were it not for their rather large seeds.   They're still great for eating out of hand, but cooks often strain out the seeds when making pies and preserves.  Select berries that are free of mold, and as black as possible.  They arrive in markets in the summer.

Name: blood orange
Description: These red-fleshed oranges are more popular in Europe than in the United States. Look for them in the winter and spring.

Name: blueberry
Description: Blueberries are small and sturdy, so they're perfect for tossing into cakes, muffins, cereal bowls, and fruit salads. Like other berries, they also make good preserves and tarts. Select firm, dark berries that have a whitish bloom on them. Keep them refrigerated and wash them just before you eat them.You can find fresh blueberries in the summer, but frozen blueberries are available year-round and work well in many recipes. Frozen berries get a little mushy after they're defrosted, but they'll work well in many recipes. Canned blueberries also work in pies and baked goods, but drain off the liquid and rinse them first.

Name: Bosc pear
Description: This firm and crunchy pear is the best choice for cooking, because it holds its shape nicely. Bosc pears can also be eaten out of hand.

Name: boysenberry
Description: A boysenberry is a cross between a blackberry, a raspberry, and a loganberry. It's more fragile than a blackberry, but it doesn't have the blackberry's conspicuous seeds. Select boysenberries that are dark in color and free of mold.

Name: Braeburn apple
Description: This firm and juicy apple is good for eating out of hand or for baking.

Name: breadfruit
Description: This is the plant that the H.M.S. Bounty was carrying in the South Pacific when its crew mutinied. Captain Bligh's goal had been to transport the seedlings from Tahiti to the Caribbean, so that slaves there would have a ready source of starch and calories. Breadfruit is highly perishable, so fresh ones are hard to find outside the tropics. The canned version is a good substitute. A seeded version is called a breadnut.

Name: Buddha's hand citron
Description: This fragrant fruit has hardly any flesh, but the peel can be candied
Also known as: Buddha's fingers citron, Buddha's hand, fingered citron

Name: bull's horn pepper
Description: This Italian heirloom pepper is shaped like a bull's horn, and many cooks think it's a lot more flavorful than an ordinary bell pepper.
Also known as: Corno Di Toro Pepper, red bull's horn pepper

Name: buttercup squash
Description: With sweet and creamy orange flesh, the buttercup is one of the more highly regarded winter squashes.  The biggest shortcoming is that it tends to be a bit dry.  Choose specimens that are heavy for their size.
Substitutions: butternut squash,acorn squash,Hubbard squash,delicata squash,kabocha squash,pumpkin,green papaya

Name: butternut squash
Description: This variety is very popular because it's so easy to use.  It's small enough to serve a normal family without leftovers, and the rind is thin enough to peel off with a vegetable peeler.  As an added bonus, the flavor is sweet, moist, and pleasantly nutty.
Substitutions: buttercup squash,acorn squash,calabaza,delicata squash,kabocha squash,Hubbard squash,green papaya

Name: cachucha pepper
Description: These small sweet peppers come in different colors and looks like squished bell peppers. They're popular in the Caribbean, where they're often stuffed and roasted.
Also known as: aji cachucha, aji dulce, Ajícito, rocatillo

Name: calabaza
Description: These are popular in Hispanic countries and throughout the Caribbean. They're large, so markets often cut them up before selling them.
Also known as: abóbora, ahuyama, crapaudback, Cuban squash, giraumon, green pumpkin, Jamaican pumpkin, toadback, West Indian pumpkin, zapallo

Name: calamondin
Also known as: calamondin orange, China orange, Panama orange, Philippine lemon, Philippine lime

Name: California chili
Description: These are dried Anaheim chiles, and very mild.

Name: California sugar pear
Description: This small pear is the same size as a Seckel pear, but it's not as juicy and sweet.

Name: Cameo apple
Description: This firm, mildly tart apple is quite versatile. Use Cameos in pies, applesauce, salads, or just eat them out of hand.

Name: Canary melon
Description: These tend to vary in quality, so unless you're good at selecting melons, stick with more idiot-proof varieties like the honeydew or cantaloupe. Canaries should, at a minimum, have bright yellow rinds. They're in season in the fall.

Name: candied angelica
Description: These are used to make decorative flower stems on cakes.

Name: candied apricot
Also known as: abricot glacé, glace apricot, glacéed apricot

Name: candied chestnuts
Description: A French specialty, these are whole chestnuts that are candied in a sugar syrup. They're used to make various desserts.

Name: candied ginger
Description: Candied ginger is ginger that is stored in a sugary syrup, but the name is also sometimes used for crystallized ginger, which is ginger that's been cooked in syrup, then dried out and rolled in sugar. The two are often used interchangeably.

Name: canistel
Description: The canistel fruit is orange/yellow, oval and 2 to 3 inches long. It is sweet with the texture of a hard boiled egg.
Also known as: cupcake fruit, eggfruit, lamut Khamen, laulu, sawo mentega, yellow sapote, zapote amarillo

Name: cantaloupe
Description: These are popular because they're easy to select and very sweet.  Ripe cantaloupes have dull yellow backgrounds with raised netting.  Avoid those with protruding stems, or tears in the rind at the stem end--it's a tell-tale sign that the melon was picked too soon.  When ripe melons are picked, the stem falls off easily, leaving a small, clean depression.  After checking the stem end, flip the melon over and check the blossom end.  It should be fragrant and yield a bit when pressed.   Cantaloupes are cheapest in the summer.
Also known as: muskmelon, netted melon, nutmeg melon, rockmelon

Name: Cape gooseberry
Description: Like its relative the tomatillo, the Cape gooseberry is covered with a papery husk.  The fruit inside looks a bit like a yellow cherry, and tastes like a sweet tomato.  You can eat Cape gooseberries whole, minus the husk, or use them to make very tasty preserves.  They're hard to find in the United States; your best bet is a specialty produce market in the spring.
Also known as: alkekengi, Chinese lantern, golden berry, golden gooseberry, golden husk, ground cherry, husk tomato, physalis, poha, strawberry tomato

Name: Capulin cherry
Also known as: Capuli, Capulin, Panama berry, tropic cherry, tropical cherry

Name: carissa
Description: You won't find these in markets, but these tart plums are great for making preserves.

Name: carosello
Description: There are many varieties of carosellos. They are often referred to as cucumber melons. They are a sweet version of a cucumber. Some varieties are; carosello tondo massafra, fakous, pupuneddhra bianca, carosello leccese and painted serpent.

Name: casaba melon
Description: These aren't as flavorful as other melons, but they have a fairly long shelf life. Since they have thick rinds, it's useless to smell them as a test for ripeness. Look instead at the color (it should be bright yellow), and then check to see if the blossom end yields to gentle pressure.
Substitutions: Santa Claus melon,Cranshaw melon,Spanish melon,Sharlyn melon,cantaloupe

Name: cascabel pepper - dried
Description: These are nicknamed rattle chiles because the seeds rattle when you shake them. They're a rich brown color and moderately hot.
Also known as: bola chile, cascabel chile, chile bola, rattle chile
Substitutions: guajillo chili ,pequin pepper dried,tepin dried,cayenne pepper dried

Name: cashew apple
Description: This Brazilian fruit looks like a squishy apple with an odd-looking stem growing out of it. According to botanists, though, the grayish "stem" is actually the fruit, and it encloses the kidney-shaped cashew nut that we're familiar with. The cashew apple is the yellowish-orange part that's attached to the fruit. This fruit is juicy but somewhat astringent due to a high concentration of tannin. Be careful of the grayish substance that encloses the nut. It contains toxic oils.
Also known as: caju, cajueiro, cashew fruit, marañon, merey

Name: Catarina chili dried
Description: This medium-hot Mexican chili is used to make tamales, marinades, stews and soups. It's got a fruity flavor with just a hint of tobacco.
Also known as: Catarina pepper, chile cora, ladybug chile

Name: cayenne pepper - fresh
Description: These are often used in Cajun recipes.  Green cayennes appear in the summer, while hotter red cayennes come out in the fall. They are very hot.
Also known as: bird pepper, finger chili, ginnie pepper
Substitutions: chile de árbol dried,Thai chili pepper - fresh,habanero - fresh,jalapeno pepper ,Serrano pepper  ,cascabel pepper - dried,pequin pepper dried,tepin dried,Holland chili,cherry pepper

Name: cayenne pepper dried
Description: These are very hot, bright red chilies. Recipes that call for cayenne pepper are likely referring to a ground powder that goes by the same name, or possibly to the fresh version of the pepper.

Name: Cerignola olives
Description: These sweet Italian olives are large enough to stuff. Black Cerignolas are softer than green Cerignolas.

Name: Charantais melon
Description: This is reputed to be one of the best melon varieties of all.

Name: chayote
Description: This mild-flavored squash looks like a wrinkled, pale green pear.  It needs to be cooked before serving, and for a longer time than other summer squash.  You should peel a chayote before cooking it, but don't take the seed out--it's edible and tasty.  Cooked chayotes make good low-fat substitutes for avocados.
Also known as: cho-cho, chocho, choko, christophene, christophine, chuchu, custard marrow, mango squash, mirliton (in the South), pear squash, pepinella, pepinello, sousous, vegetable pear, xoxo, xuxu

Name: cherimoya
Description: This South American tropical fruit is shaped like a pine cone and has a gray-green, scaly skin. The soft white pulp inside has large black (inedible) seeds and tastes like a creamy blend of tropical flavors. Hard cherimoyas should be stored at room temperature until they give a little when squeezed, then they should be refrigerated until they're ready to serve.

Name: cherry
Description: There are three main categories of cherries:  sweet cherries, which are for eating out of hand, sour cherries, which are best suited for making pies, preserves, and sauces, and tart chokecherries.

Name: cherry pepper
Description: Along with pepperoncini, this is a good pickling pepper. They are moderately hot, and range in color from orange to bright red.
Also known as: bird cherry pepper, cherry bell pepper, cherry chile, cherry chili, Creole cherry pepper, hot cherry pepper, Hungarian cherry pepper, pimiento pepper, wiri-wiri

Name: cherry tomato
Description: These are less than an inch in diameter, perfect for adding to salads or crudité platters, or grilling on skewers.  There are both red and yellow varieties.

Name: chilaca pepper
Description: When dried, a chilaca pepper is called a pasilla chile. They are mild.

Name: Chilcostle chili
Description: This hard-to-find and moderately hot Mexican chili is used in soups, stews, tamales, and mole sauces. It imparts a yellowish color to dishes.

Name: chile de árbol dried
Description: Unlike many chilies, these remain bright red even after drying, so they're a favorite for making chili wreaths. They're very hot and somewhat acidic. Don't confuse the dried version with the fresh or powdered versions, which go by the same name.
Also known as: arbol chile, bird's beak chili, chile árbol, rat's tail chili, red chile

Name: Chilhuacle negro chile
Description: This excellent Mexican chili is loaded with flavor but hard to find. It's used to make mole negro and bean dishes. It is moderately hot.

Name: Chinese dates (dried)
Description: When fresh, these fruits are crisp like apples and have a mild, sweet flavor. In the United States, they're most often available dried. Chinese are different than middle eastern palm dates.
Also known as: Chinese jujube (dried), Chinese red date, jujube (dried), red date, senjed

Name: Chinese dates (fresh)
Description: These are usually dried, but you can sometimes find fresh dates in late summer and fall. When you get them home, let them ripen on the counter for awhile until they become soft and sweet. Chinese are different than middle eastern palm dates.

Name: Chinese eggplant
Description: Compared to the familiar American eggplant, Chinese eggplants have thinner skins, a more delicate flavor, and not as many of the seeds that tend to make eggplants bitter.

Name: chipotle negro chile
Description: These are darker, milder versions of the chipotle chile.
Also known as: black chipotle, chipotle mora, mora, red-black chipotle

Name: chipotle pepper
Description: These dried and smoked jalapeño peppers lend a wonderful, complex flavor to sauces. They're usually rehydrated and canned in adobo sauce, but you can also buy them dried in cellophane bags. They are medium hot.
Also known as: chile seco, jalapeno pepper dried, meco, smoked jalapeno pepper

Name: chokecherry
Description: These are too tart for most people to eat out of hand, but they make delicious preserves.

Name: citron
Description: This resembles a large, bumpy lemon. Its thick rind is used to make marmalade, and its zest is a close substitute to lemon zest.

Name: cloudberry
Description: Both the color and flavor of these Scandinavian berries pale in comparison to the raspberry.
Also known as: averin, bakeapple, knotberry, low-bush salmonberry, nordic berry

Name: cloudberry preserves
Description: These preserves are sweet and somewhat mild. Look for them in Scandinavian markets.

Name: coconut
Description: The most common form of coconut in markets is the dry coconut, with a hard brown shell surrounding firm coconut meat with liquid in the center.  Green coconuts = water coconuts are young coconuts with very soft meat inside.  They're more often found in the tropics.   Select coconuts that are free of cracks or mold, that are heavy for their size, and that have lots of water in them when you shake them.  To crack one, hit it along its equator with a blunt instrument, pouring off the water when the first crack appears.

Name: Comice pear
Description: These juicy pears are considered to be the best for eating out of hand, but they're very expensive.

Name: Concord grapes
Description: These dark purple grapes have large seeds. They are tangy and sweet. It is often used to make grape jelly.

Name: Cortland apple
Description: These are all-purpose apples. Since their flesh is slow to brown after it's cut, Cortland apples are especially good in salads. If substituting another variety in a salad, dip it in acidulated water first to keep it from darkening.

Name: Costeño Amarillo
Description: This yellow Mexican chili is used to make soups, stews, and mole sauces. It's fruity and moderately hot and somewhat hard to find.

Name: Cotton Candy™ grapes
Description: These are sweet seedless white table grapes. Some think they taste like cotton candy.

Name: cousa squash
Description: This Middle-Eastern summer squash looks a lot like spaghetti squash, only it has a thin, edible skin. It's similar to zucchini, but its larger size makes it a natural for stuffing.

Name: crab apple
Description: These small apples are too tart to eat raw, but they're loaded with pectin and make great jams and jellies.

Name: cracked Provencal
Description: These aromatic  green olives are marinated in a solution with herbes de Provence.

Name: cranberry
Description: These tart berries are traditionally used to makes sauces and garnishes for Thanksgiving and Christmas dinners.  It's best to buy them at their peak in October and November, and freeze any that you don't use right away.

Name: cranberry juice
Description: See the recipe for Cranberry Juice posted by Veggies Unite!

Name: cranberry sauce
Description: This is a classic accompaniment to Thanksgiving and Christmas dinners. It's made of cranberries that have been cooked with sugar and other flavorings, like orange zest, ginger, port, or maple syrup.

Name: Crane melon
Description: This melon-cantaloupe cross is exceptionally juicy and flavorful, but it's hard to find outside of Sonoma County, California.

Name: Cranshaw melon
Description: This large, popular melon is a cross between the Persian and Casaba melons. The rinds come in two colors: yellow and creamy white. The yellow ones taste better. You can buy Cranshaws while they're still a little underripe and let them sit on the counter for a few days. When fully ripe, a Cranshaw will be fragrant and yield slightly to gentle pressure at its blossom end. They're best in the fall.
Substitutions: casaba melon,Persian melon,Sharlyn melon,Spanish melon,cantaloupe,honeydew melon

Name: crimson seedless grapes
Description: This is a common red seedless grape.

Name: Criterion apple
Description: This is a good apple for eating out of hand, or for making applesauce or pies. Its flesh is slow to brown after it's cut.

Name: crystallized ginger
Description: This is fresh ginger that has been cooked in a sugar solution and then coated with sugar. It's similar to candied ginger, and the two are often used interchangeably.

Name: cuaresmeno - fresh
Description: They are moderately hot.

Name: cubanelle
Description: These sweet, mild peppers are usually sold while yellowish-green. They become hotter and redder as they mature.
Also known as: Cuban pepper, cubanelle pepper, Friarelli, Green cubanelle, Italian frying pepper

Name: cucuzza
Also known as: bottle gourd, calabash, cucuzzi, Italian squash, New Guinea bean, suzza melon, Tasmania bean, zucca

Name: cupuacu
Description: The cupuacu fruit grow on medium sized trees native to the Amazon basin. The fruit is brown skinned with a white pulpy center. Cupuacu has a fruity chocolatey flavor.

Name: currant
Description: These berries are too tart for most people to eat out of hand, but they make terrific preserves and garnishes.   They come in three colors:  red, white, and black. If color's not important, you can use them interchangeably in most recipes, though red and white currants aren't as tart as black.  Don't confuse these berries with the dried fruit of the same name that looks like a small raisin.  You can sometimes find fresh currants in specialty produce markets in the summer.  If not, frozen currants are a good substitute.

Name: currant tomato
Description: These are about half the size of cherry tomatoes.

Name: currants
Description: These dried Zante grapes look like tiny raisins. Don't confuse them with the fresh sour berry that also called a currant.
Also known as: dried Corinth grapes, dried currants, Zante currants, Zante raisins

Name: dates
Description: These are rich in flavor, nutrients, and calories. Medjool dates are richer and meatier than the other Deglet Noor dates. Other varieties include Khalas, sukkary, barhi, medjool, ajwa and kimia.If you plan to chop them, look for cooking dates, date pieces, or pressed dates--they're a lot cheaper than the exquisite dessert dates that are intended to be eaten whole. Don't confuse dates with fresh dates, which are hard to find in supermarkets.To learn about different varieties of dates, click here.

Name: dates (fresh)
Description: Fresh dates are sometimes available at farmer's markets in the late summer.  They're crunchy, and not as sweet as dried dates.

Name: deglet noor dates
Description: These honey sweet translucent deglet noor dates are enjoyed in North Africa. They originated in Algeria.

Name: delicata squash
Description: This is one of the tastier winter squashes, with creamy pulp that tastes a bit like sweet potatoes.  Choose squash that are heavy for their size.

Name: dewberry
Description: These are similar to blackberries, only they're smaller.

Name: donut peach
Description: These squat peaches have white flesh, and a very good flavor.  Use them as you would ordinary peaches.

Name: dragon fruit
Description: This comes from a cactus native to Central and South America, and has a mild flavor. To eat it, either peel it or cut it in half and scoop out the white, polka-dotted pulp with a spoon.Select dragon fruit by pressing it gently. It should give just a little.

Name: dried apple
Description: These are popular additions to trail mixes. They're often treated with sulfur to improve their color and shelf life.

Name: dried apricot
Description: Turkish dried apricots are lighter in color and milder in flavor than other varieties. They're often treated with sulfur to improve their color and shelf life.

Name: dried apricot paste
Description: People in the Middle East usually make a drink out of this fruit leather by putting it into boiling water.  During Ramadan, it's often served before and after the day-long fast.  Look for it in Middle Eastern markets.

Name: dried banana
Description: These usually come in two forms: long spears, which are very sweet and best for cooking, and chips, which are fried in oil, crunchy, and best suited for trail mixes.

Name: dried cantaloupe
Description: These are very sweet and have an intense cantaloupe flavor.

Name: dried carrots
Description: These are used to make muffins and cakes.

Name: dried cherry
Description: These are large and sweet, and they can serve as a refreshing alternative to raisins in many recipes.

Name: dried citrus peel
Description: Begin with orange, lemon, tangerine, or grapefruit peels, scrape off and discard as much of the bitter white pith as possible, and dry what's left in the sun until hard

Name: dried cranberries
Description: With their flashy color and tangy flavor, dried cranberries are a good alternative to raisins in many recipes. Craisins is a well-known brand.

Name: dried eggplant
Description: Look for these in Middle Eastern markets.

Name: dried fig
Description: These are a great source of fiber and calcium. Varieties include the Black Mission fig, which is a good choice for eating out of hand, and the Calimyrna = Turkish = Smyrna fig, which is best for cooking. If your figs become too dry, you can rehydrate them with water. Don't eat the stems.
Also known as: black mission fig, Calimyrna fig, green fig, Smyrna fig, Turkish fig

Name: Dried Fruit
Description: Dried fruit is a terrific snack, but cooks also use it in everything from muffins to stews.  Drying has the obvious advantage of letting us enjoy our favorite fruit when it's out of season, but it also serves to concentrate the fruit's flavor and sugar.  Since high concentrations of sugar ward off bacteria, dried fruit can last up to a year without refrigeration.   If you live in a hot, dry climate, you can dry fruit just by leaving it out in the sun for a few days.  If not, you can use an oven or dehydrator.  Sulfur dioxide is sometimes added to the fruit to improve its shelf life and color.  If you're allergic to it, you can usually find unsulfured dried fruit at health food stores.  In a pinch, you can remove some of the sulfur by boiling treated dried fruit for a minute or so, then draining off the liquid.

Name: dried mango
Description: These are sometimes coated with sugar.

Name: dried mulberries
Description: These are the size of large raisins, and they taste like very dry figs. Look for them in Middle Eastern markets.

Name: dried nectarines
Description: These are similar to dried peaches, but often a bit more expensive. They're often treated with sulfur.

Name: dried papaya
Description: These are sometimes coated with sugar.

Name: dried peach
Description: These are similar to dried apricots, only larger and milder. They're often treated with sulfur.

Name: dried pear
Description: These don't have the cloying sweetness of some dried fruits. They're often gassed with sulfur dioxide in the drying process in order to improve their color and shelf life.

Name: dried persimmon
Description: These often have a white, sugary residue, which is edible.

Name: dried pineapple
Description: These are sometimes coated with sugar.

Name: dried strawberries
Description: These are sweet and chewy, and they're great in trail mixes or granola.

Name: duku
Description: Duku fruit are round, tan and 1 to 2 inches in diameter. The hard shell surrounds a soft fleshy sweet and tart thick flesh. They grow in clusters.
Also known as: langsat, langsat Hutan, longkong, meliaceae, wollongong

Name: durian
Description: The weird and smelly durian has attracted a cult-like following. It's called the King of Fruits by aficionados in Southeast Asia, but Westerners usually don't care much for its mild oniony flavor. Once cut open, the durian eventually gives off such a strong and foul odor that it's banned on Singaporean subways. Look for it in Asian markets. The boiled seeds of the durian are called betons.

Name: Eggplants
Description: This is a spongy, mild-tasting vegetable that's meaty yet low in calories. It's never eaten raw, but it can be baked, grilled, or sautéed. The best eggplants are shiny, firm (but not too hard), and heavy for their size, with bright green stems and unbroken skin. Smaller eggplants tend to have fewer bitter seeds, as do "male" ones with round scars at their blossom (non-stem) end. (The scars on "female" eggplants look like dashes.) Freshness is important, so don't store eggplants for very long.
Also known as: aubergine, berenjena, brinjal, egg apple, garden egg, Guinea squash, melanzane, melongene, patlican

Name: elderberry
Description: These are too tart for most people to eat out of hand, but they make terrific preserves and wine.

Name: Elstar apple
Description: This firm apple is especially good for making applesauce.

Name: empeltre olives
Description: These Spanish black olives are soaked in sherry.

Name: Empire apple
Description: This is a Red Delicious-McIntosh cross that's great for baking or eating out of hand.

Name: English cucumber
Description: This foot-long slicing cucumber is pricier and less flavorful than other varieties, but it has less conspicuous seeds, a thinner skin, and a plastic wrapper--instead of a wax coating--to improve shelf life.  All of this saves preparation time, since there's no need to peel or seed the cucumber before slicing it.  This is a good variety if you focused on looks--you can cut it into round, green trimmed slices.
Also known as: burpless cucumber, English cucumber, European cucumber, gourmet cucumber, greenhouse cucumber, hothouse cucumber, seedless cucumber

Name: feijoa
Description: To eat feijoas, just cut them in half and scoop out the pulp with a spoon.  They also make terrific preserves and syrups.  Look for them in large supermarkets.  If they're hard when you buy them, allow them to ripen at room temperature until they give a bit when you squeeze them, then store them in the refrigerator.

Name: fig
