Description: Varieties include Calimyrna = Smyrna and Kadota, both with green skin and pinkish-white flesh, and the most popular variety, and the Mission fig = black Mission fig, with dark purple skin and pink flesh.  Dried figs are not good substitutes for fresh.
Also known as: black Mission fig, Calimyrna, Kadota, Mission fig, Smyrna

Name: flame seedless grapes
Description: These are common and popular red seedless grapes.

Name: fraises des bois
Description: These small, wild strawberries are either white or red, and have a very intense flavor.
Also known as: alpine strawberries, Carpathian strawberries, fraises de bois, fraises des bois (plural), wild strawberries, wood strawberries

Name: Fresno pepper
Description: These are similar to jalapeno peppers, but with thinner walls. They're great in salsas. Green Fresnos are available in the summer. the hotter red ones come out in the fall.
Also known as: Fresno chile pepper, Fresno chili pepper

Name: Fuerte avocado
Description: This is in season from late fall through spring.  It's not quite as buttery as the Hass avocado, but its flavor is excellent.

Name: Fuji apple
Description: This variety is good for eating out of hand, or for making applesauce or pies.

Name: fuzzy melon
Description: This sweet and mild squash has a fuzzy feel to it.
Also known as: Chi qua, fuzzy gourd, hairy cucumber, hairy melon, moqua, wax gourd

Name: Gaeta olives
Description: These are small, purple Italian olives are either dry-cured (making them black and wrinkled) or brine-cured (making them dark purple and smooth-skinned).

Name: Gala apple
Description: This apple is outstanding for eating out of hand or for baking or making applesauce.
Substitutions: Fuji apple,Golden Delicious apple,Granny Smith apple,honeycrisp apples

Name: Galia melon
Description: This sweet, juicy melon is a honeydew-cantaloupe cross.  Its biggest drawback is its relatively high price.

Name: garden cucumber
Description: You can find these throughout the year at all but the most poorly stocked markets.  The ones you find in supermarkets are usually waxed to hold in moisture and improve shelf-life--these should be peeled or at least scrubbed well before serving.  Unwaxed cucumbers don't need to be peeled, but better cooks often do so since the peels tend to be thick and bitter.  It's also a good idea to remove the seeds from these kinds of cucumbers; just cut them in half lengthwise and scrape them out.   Select cukes that are firm, dark green, and rounded at the tips.
Also known as: field-grown cucumbers, market cucumber, outdoor cucumber, regular cucumber

Name: garden eggs
Description: These are tiny eggplants, the size of an egg or smaller. Their color ranges from white to greenish-yellow.

Name: gherkin cucumber
Description: These small, bumpy greed cucumbers are used to make Gherkin pickles or, if pickled while still small, cornichon pickles.

Name: ghost pepper
Description: Ghost peppers are a very hot (over 1,000,000 scovilles) hybrid between Capsicum chinese and Capsicum frutescens. It is grown and used in northern India.
Also known as: bhut jolokia, king chili, king cobra chili, Tezpur chili

Name: ginger jam
Description: Look for this in Asian grocery stores.

Name: glace cherries
Description: red, green and yellow versions.

Name: globe squash
Description: You can stuff these and bake them, or slice and sauté them.

Name: Golden Delicious apple
Description: This sweet apple is good for eating out of hand, baking, and for making pies. The yellower the better.

Name: golden delicious squash
Description: This is an orange-red variety of Hubbard squash

Name: golden nugget squash
Description: This has a pleasant flavor, but it doesn't have as much flesh as other squashes and the heavy rind makes it hard to cut before cooking.   Select specimens that are heavy for their size, and that have a dull finish.  Those with shiny rinds were probably picked too young, and won't be as sweet.

Name: golden raisin
Description: These are more tart than ordinary raisins.

Name: golden raspberry
Description: This is a blonder, milder version of the red raspberry. Don't confuse it with the Golden Raspberries (Razzies), which are given out to honor each year's worst films and performers.

Name: gooseberry
Description: These large, tart berries are in season only in June and July, but canned gooseberries work well in pies and fools.  American gooseberries are round and about 1/2 inch in diameter, while European gooseberries are oblong, and about twice the size of American gooseberries.  They're very acidic, and so they're great with roasted meats, like goose.  The freshest gooseberries are covered with fuzz.

Name: Granny Smith apple
Description: This is a firm, tart apple that's good for baking, making pies, and eating out of hand. They tend to have thick skins, so you might want to peel them before serving.

Name: grape juice
Description: This category includes red grape juice, white grape juice, and sparkling grape juice.
Also known as: red grape juice, sparkling grape juice, white grape juice

Name: grapefruit
Description: A grapefruit is a large, slightly tart kind of citrus fruit. The rind is yellow, though often tinged with green or red. Grapefruits are categorized by the color of their pulp: red, pink, or "white" (actually honey-colored). The color of the pulp doesn't affect the flavor. When buying grapefruit, select specimens that are smaller, thin-skinned, and heavy for their size. Some varieties are seedless. They're best in the winter and spring.

Name: grapefruit juice
Description: This comes either sweetened or unsweetened.

Name: grapes
Description: Many varieties of grapes are turned into wine, vinegar, jelly, and raisins, but table grapes are for eating out of hand.  They're classified by their color--red, green, and blue--and by whether they have seeds or not.  Seedless varieties are popular because they're easy to eat, but often the seeded varieties offer more flavor and better value.

Name: grated coconut
Description: Bags of grated coconuts are usually stored among the baking supplies in larger markets. Varieties include dried or desiccated coconut, flaked, angel flake, moist, sweetened and unsweetened, toasted and untoasted, and macaroon coconut.To make your own: To grate, peel off the brown skin, then grate the white flesh with a grater, food processor, or vegetable peeler. To toast, spread unsweetened grated coconut on a baking sheet and bake in a 350°F oven until coconut is golden (about 5 minutes).
Also known as: coconut meat, desiccated (more finely ground), dried coconut, flaked coconut, grated coconut, shredded coconut

Name: Gravenstein apple
Description: This is a good, all-purpose apple, but it's best suited for making applesauce and pies.

Name: Greek black olives
Description: A generic black Greek olive is large, dark purple and brine-cured. Popular varieties include Kalamata, Amphissa, and Royal.

Name: Greek green olives
Description: Napfilion and Ionian olives are the most common types of green Greek olives.

Name: green almonds
Description: Middle Eastern cooks use these in stews and desserts.

Name: green goddess eggplant
Description: This has a very mild flavor.

Name: green olives
Description: Green olives are picked from the tree before they're completely ripened. The most common variety is the Manzanilla olive, which is often pitted and stuffed. Other green olives varieties include the Agrinion, Arauco, Arbequina, Atalanta, green Cerignola, cracked Provençal, Kura, Lucque, Nafplion, Picholine, Sevillano, and Sicilian.

Name: green papaya
Description: Southeast Asian cooks like to shred these into salads.

Name: green tomato
Description: These are picked before they turn red. Southerners like to fry them.

Name: guajillo chili
Description: One of the more popular Mexican chilies, the guajillo (or dried mirasol chili) has a fruity flavor and medium heat (Scoville heat scale of 2,500 to 5,000 SHU). It's smooth, shiny, and reddish-brown, and it has a tough skin, so it needs to be soaked longer than other chiles.These are commonly used for marinades and adobos.
Substitutions: ancho chili,New Mexico red chili,pasilla chili,cascabel pepper - dried,mirasol pepper ,California chili

Name: guava
Description: These bruise easily, so markets usually sell them while they're still hard and green. Allow them to ripen at room temperature until they become yellow and very aromatic, then either eat or refrigerate them. The peel and seeds can be eaten along with the juicy pulp, but some people remove them.

Name: guero pepper
Description: These are moderately hot.
Also known as: caloro, caribe, chile guero, goldspike, Sante Fe grande, yellow hot chile

Name: habanero - dried
Description: Don't confuse dried habaneros with the fresh version, which goes by the same name. These extremely hot chiles are wrinkled and orange.

Name: habanero - fresh
Description: These extremely hot orange chiles have a fruity flavor. They're best in the summertime.
Substitutions: Scotch bonnet chili,manzana chili,cayenne pepper - fresh,jalapeno pepper ,Serrano pepper

Name: halawi dates
Description: These amber-colored sweet chewy halawi dates are grown extensively in Iraq.

Name: Hass avocado
Description: This is available year-round and has a rich flavor and creamy texture. The skin turns almost black when the avocado is ripe, which can camouflage bad bruises. This is the best variety by far for guacamole, but it turns a bit mushy in salads.

Name: Holland bell pepper
Description: These are like bell peppers, only they're sweeter and have thicker walls. They come in different colors.

Name: Holland chili
Description: These are hot.

Name: Hondroelia olives
Description: This is a juicy, meaty olive.

Name: honeyball melon
Description: This is just like a honeydew melon, only it's smaller, rounder, and covered with netting.

Name: honeydew melon
Description: These large, choice melons have either green or orange flesh. As honeydews ripen, they turn from green to creamy white to yellow. Avoid green ones, but a creamy white one will (unlike other melons) ripen on your counter in a few days. A perfectly ripe honeydew will yield just a bit to pressure at the blossom end and have a sticky, velvety rind.

Name: Hubbard squash
Description: This variety has tasty flesh, but it's too large for many families to handle and the rind is hard to cut though. Some grocers cut them into smaller pieces before putting them out.
Substitutions: pumpkin,golden delicious squash,buttercup squash,butternut squash,banana squash,green papaya

Name: huckleberry
Description: These are similar to blueberries, and they're great for making preserves and syrups.  Some specialty markets carry them in the summer.

Name: ilama
Description: Ilama are hard to find outside of Mexico or Guatamala. There are two types of Ilama fruit; white and pink.

Name: Indian bitter melon
Description: This is fairly bitter. Choose melons that are bright green. They turn tough and yellow as they age. You can eat the peels and seeds, or scrape out the seeds to reduce the bitterness.
Also known as: balsam pear, bitter apple, bitter melon, bitter squash, Indian bitter gourd, karela

Name: Italian eggplant
Description: These are smaller than American eggplants, but they're otherwise very similar.

Name: jaboticaba
Description: These resemble large, dark purple grapes, and they're very popular in Brazil. You can eat them like grapes, though you'll have to contend with thick, tart skins. You can also make delicious jams, jellies, and wines from them.

Name: jabuticaba
Description: Jabuticaba fruit is grape like about 1 to 2 inches in diameter. Under the thick skin is the sweet pink or white flesh.

Name: jackfruit
Description: This is the largest tree-borne fruit in the world--it weighs up to 100 pounds. It's hard to find fresh in the United States, but Asian markets sometimes stock canned jackfruit. The yellowish pulp tastes a bit like banana. The seeds can be boiled and eaten. Watch out for the sap--it can stain your clothes.

Name: jalapeno pepper
Description: These popular chilis have a good amount of heat and rich flavor. Green jalapenos are best in the late summer, while red jalapenos appear in the fall. Canned jalapenos aren't as fiery as fresh. When dried and smoked, this pepper is called a chipotle.
Substitutions: cuaresmeno - fresh,Fresno pepper,guero pepper,melegueta pepper,Serrano pepper  ,yellow wax pepper ,cayenne pepper - fresh

Name: Japanese chili
Description: These small red chilis are hot, and similar to the chile de arbol. Before using them, soak them in warm water for a few minutes.

Name: Japanese cucumber
Description: These are just like English cucumbers, only with bumps. Like English cucumbers, they don't have to be peeled or seeded.

Name: Japanese eggplant
Description: Like other Asian eggplants, Japanese eggplants have thin skins, and a sweet, delicate flavor.

Name: Jonagold apple
Description: This crisp, juicy apple is a Jonathan-Golden Delicious cross. It's a bit tart and good for eating out of hand.

Name: Jonathan apple
Description: This tart apple is good for eating out of hand, though it has a fairly thick peel.

Name: juneberry
Description: These are very similar to blueberries.
Also known as: chuckley pear, saskatoon, serviceberry, shadberry, shadbush, sugarplum

Name: kabocha squash
Description: This orange-fleshed winter squash has a striated green rind. It's sweeter, drier, and less fibrous than other winter squash, and it tastes a bit like sweet potatoes.
Also known as: Japanese pumpkin, Japanese squash, kabachi, nam gwa, sweet mama

Name: Kadota fig
Description: This has green skin and pinkish-white flesh.

Name: kaffir lime
Description: Thai cooks use these golf ball-sized limes to give their dishes a unique aromatic flavor. Kaffir limes have very little juice, usually just the zest is used. The leaves are also used in Thai cooking.
Also known as: jeruk purut, leech lime, limau purut, magrood, makroot, makrut, Mauritius papeda, Thai lime

Name: kalamansi
Description: The very sour kalamansi looks like a small round lime and tastes like a cross between a lemon and a mandarin orange. It's very popular in the Philippines.
Also known as: calamansi, calamansi lime, kalamansi lime, musk lime, musklime

Name: kalamansi juice
Also known as: calamansi juice, musk lime juice, musklime juice
Substitutions: kalamansi juice,mandarin orange juice,key lime juice,calamondin juice,lemon juice

Name: Kalamata olives
Description: You can find these popular Greek black olives in most large supermarkets. They're salty and have a rich, fruity flavor. These can be eaten out of hand, or used to make tapenades.

Name: Kashmiri red chili dried
Description: This mild Kashmiri chili is used in Indian cooking to add flavor and color.

Name: keriberry
Description: These large berries taste like a cross between blackberries and raspberries.

Name: kershaw squash
Description: Kershaw squash is an heirloom squash. It is mostly grown in the American south. Kershaw squash was cultivated by native Americans.

Name: key lime
Description: These are smaller and more acidic than the more common Persian limes.
Also known as: bartender's lime, Florida key lime, Mexican lime, Omani lime, West Indian lime

Name: key lime juice
Description: Freshly squeezed lime juice is vastly superior to what you'll find in bottles. Key limes and bottled key lime juice are widely available in the Southeast, and in specialty markets elsewhere. Liquor stores sometimes carry Rose's lime juice, which is sweetened key lime juice.

Name: khalas dates
Description: Khalas dates originated in Saudi Arabia.

Name: kharbouza melon
Description: This is a very crunchy, mildly sweet melon.

Name: kimia dates
Description: These dark kimia dates are grown widely in southern Iran. They are moist and soft.

Name: Kirby cucumber
Description: This short, versatile cucumber is used for both slicing and pickling.  It's small, with bumpy yellow or green skin.  Like the English cucumber, it has a thin skin and inconspicuous seeds.

Name: kittely
Description: Kittely is a small round eggplant. It is used in soups and stews.

Name: kiwano
Description: This melon has a gorgeous orange rind with spikes--poke a stick in it and you'd have a medieval mace for a Halloween costume. The yellow-green flesh has the consistency of jello, and tastes a bit like cucumbers.
Also known as: African horned cucumber, African horned melon, cherie, English tomato, hedged gourd, horned melon, jelly melon, kiwano melon, melano, spiked melon

Name: kiwi fruit
Description: This small, oblong fruit is has fuzzy brown skin and beautiful green flesh dotted with edible black seeds. It tastes like a cross between gooseberries and strawberries. It's very versatile--you can eat it as a snack, blend it into sauces or sorbets, or peel and slice it as a garnish. It also contains an enzyme that tenderizes meat. Select kiwis that are hard, and allow them to ripen at room temperature for a few days.
Also known as: Chinese gooseberry, kiwi, kiwifruit, monkey peach, yang-tao

Name: kokum
Description: This Indian souring agent is made from dried mangosteen peels. It's often used in fish dishes. Look for it in Indian markets.

Name: kumquat
Description: These look like grape-sized oranges, and they can be eaten whole. The flavor is a bit sour and very intense.  They peak in the winter months.

Name: Kura olives
Description: This Middle Eastern cracked green olive is hard to find in the U.S.

Name: Lady apple
Description: These are very small apples, and usually used for decoration.

Name: lamuyo pepper
Description: This hard-to-find sweet pepper is smaller and sweeter than its cousin, the bell pepper, with which it's interchangeable.

Name: langsat
Description: This sweet and sour fruit from Southeast Asia looks like a small potato. Don't eat the bitter seed inside.

Name: lemon
Description: This very sour citrus fruit is rarely eaten out of hand, but it's widely used for its juice, rind, and zest.  Varieties include the Eureka lemon, which is what you're most likely to find in markets, the Lisbon lemon, which shows up in the winter and is smaller and smoother than the Eureka, and the trendy Meyer lemon, which is much sweeter and pricier than an ordinary lemon. When buying lemons, select specimens that are smaller, thin-skinned, and heavy for their size.

Name: lemon cucumber
Description: This versatile cucumber is sweet and flavorful, and doesn't have much of the chemical that makes other cucumbers bitter and hard to digest. Though it's often served raw, it's also a good pickling cucumber.

Name: lemon juice
Description: Freshly squeezed lemon juice tastes much better than bottled juice.

Name: lemon marmalade
Description: This is made by boiling the fruit and peel of lemons with sugar, pectin, and water. It manages to be bitter, sour, and sweet all at once, which many people find delightful.

Name: lighter Bake
Description: This is a mixture of pureed prunes and apples that serves as a fat substitute in baking.

Name: Ligurian olives
Description: These small Italian olives are brine-cured.

Name: lime
Description: These tart green fruits are similar to lemons, but they're more acidic and have their own unique flavor. Varieties include the common Persian lime = Tahiti lime and the smaller, less juicy, and more acidic Florida key lime = key lime = Mexican lime. When buying limes, select specimens that are dark green, smaller, thin-skinned, and heavy for their size.

Name: limequat
Description: This is a cross between a lime and a kumquat.  It's similar in size and shape to a kumquat, but with a green or yellow-green skin.  It has a strong lime flavor.

Name: lingonberry
Description: These tart relatives of the cranberry grow only in cold climates. They're often made into jams, juices, sauces, syrups, or compotes. Scandinavians like to serve sweetened lingonberries with game.

Name: litchi
Description: his popular Chinese fruit is about the size of a walnut, with a bumpy red shell encasing white translucent pulp that's similar in texture to a grape. The flavor is sweet, exotic, and very juicy. Don't eat the shell or the seed. Fresh litchis are available from May to July.  If you can't find them, canned litchis are a good substitute.  Don't confuse fresh litchis with litchi nuts, which are sun-dried litchis that have a much different texture.

Name: litchi nut
Description: These are sun-dried litchis. The outer shells are brown and the meat inside looks like a large raisin. Look for them in Asian markets.
Also known as: leechee nut, lichee nut, lichi nut, lychee nut

Name: loganberry
Description: These are like blackberries, only they're dark red when ripe and more acidic.  They're especially good in pies and preserves.

Name: longan
Description: Longans are very similar to lychees and rambutans. You can buy them fresh (in the summer), dried or canned.

Name: loquat
Description: These are popular in Asia, where they're eaten raw and cooked into sauces that accompany meat. They bruise very easily, which may explain their rarity in American markets
Also known as: Chinese plum, Japanese medlar, Japanese plum, nespolo, pipa

Name: Lucque olives
Description: These green olives are brine-cured.

Name: Lugano olives
Description: These are salty Italian/Swiss brownish-black olives.

Name: mabolo
Description: These look like rust-colored fuzzy apples.

Name: Macoun apple
Description: This juicy apple is good for eating out of hand.

Name: mamey sapote
Description: These are about the size of a large sweet potato. The flesh is salmon-colored, with a sweet, berry-like flavor. They're great for eating out of hand, or for making fruit salads or smoothies. Markets often sell them while they're still hard and underripe, so you need to set them on the counter for a few days until they yield when gently squeezed. Peel them and remove the seeds before serving.

Name: mandarin orange
Description: These have a pleasant enough flavor, but their big asset is that they come out of their peels and segment easily, so you can eat them in your good clothes. Varieties include the popular tangerine, the seedy but juicy honey tangerine = Murcott, the satsuma orange, the sweet and tiny clementine orange, and the seedy and orange-flavored temple orange.

Name: mango
Description: It's always a challenge to eat a mango. The pulp clings desperately to both peel and seed, and it can turn into a mushy mess by the time you free it. Despite this, the mango is one of the most popular fruits in the world. It's sweet and juicy, and it has a wonderful, distinctive flavor. Select richly colored, firm mangoes, then let them ripen at home for a few days. Frozen mangoes are good substitutes for fresh.

Name: mangosteen
Description: Some claim that this is the most delicious fruit on the planet, though it's hard to find in the United States. It's about the size of a tomato, and has a leathery, mottled skin.

Name: manzana chili
Description: This habanero relative is often used in salsas. It has black seeds. These are hot.

Name: Manzanilla olives
Description: These green olives are available in most supermarkets. They're often pitted and stuffed with pimento or garlic. They're often put into martinis.

Name: marang
Description: Marang is similar to jackfruit and durian. It has a strong but sweet taste. Marang is native to Borneo and Mindanao.
Also known as: green pedalai, johey oak, kiran, madang, terap, timadang

Name: maraschino cherry
Description: These sugar-soaked and dyed cherries come in two colors: red (almond flavored) or green (mint flavored). Cooks usually use them to garnish desserts and drinks.

Name: marionberry
Description: After Washington, D.C., mayor Marion Barry was arrested for possessing cocaine in 1989, marion berry jam enjoyed brief popularity as a novelty item.

Name: McIntosh apple
Description: These soft apples are great for snacking or for making applesauce, but don't bake them or put them in pies.

Name: medjool dates
Description: These large sweet medjool dates are very popular. If picked early they are called rutab dates. They originated in Tafilalt, Morocco but are enjoyed around the world.
Also known as: Majhul, Medjool, rhutab medjool, rutab medjool

Name: Mexican avocado
Description: With their small size and shiny black skins, these look like elongated plums.  You can eat them, skin and all

Name: Mexicola avocado
Description: This is a small, black-skinned avocado that's the size and shape of a fig. Since the peel is edible, they can be eaten like a peach. There's a smaller variety, the Mexicola cocktail avocado, that's oblong and virtually seedless. They'd make a great addition to a vegetable platter.

Name: Meyer lemon
Description: This is sweeter than an ordinary lemon, and highly prized by gourmet chefs.

Name: mincemeat
Description: Mincemeat is made with dried fruit, nuts, citrus peel, spices, and sometimes brandy, rum, or some other liquor. It used to be made with meat as well, and ready-made jars of it sometimes contain beef suet. It's often used for holiday pies.

Name: mint-flavored apple jelly
Description: This is sometimes served with lamb, veal, or game.

Name: mirasol pepper
Description: Mirasol peppers have a distinctive fruity flavor. These are moderately hot. When dried, these are called Guajillo chiles.

Name: Mission olives
Description: These are the common black ones that are ubiquitous in supermarkets, pizza parlors, and salad bars. They don't have as much character as European black olives.

Name: monstera
Description: You'll probably have to go to Florida to find this bizarre tropical fruit. It looks like a banana covered with green scales, which buckle and separate as the fruit ripens. Beneath the scales are kernels of pulp, which you scrape off like corn from a cob. The kernels have a pleasant tropical flavor and creamy texture. Wait until the scales separate before eating the kernels--unripe monsteras can irritate your mouth.

Name: Moon Drop® grapes
Description: These dark purple elongated sweet seedless grapes are unusually shaped and well regarded.

Name: mora chili
Description: This is a smoked and dried red jalapeno pepper. It's very hot.

Name: morita pepper
Description: Like the larger mora chili, this is a smoked and dried red jalapeno. It's very hot.

Name: Moroccan dry-cured olives
Description: These are shriveled black olives that are somewhat bitter. They're best used for cooking rather than snacking.
Also known as: Moroccan oil-cured olive, Moroccan salt-cured olive

Name: moya
Description: The family of moyas includes atemoya, cherimoya, soursop, and sweetsop, all of which can be used interchangeably. All these fruits have scaly peels and hard black seeds, which you need to remove before eating.

Name: mulato chili
Description: This very popular chili looks like the ancho, but it's darker and sweeter. It's fairly mild and has an earthy flavor.
Also known as: chile mulato , mulato pepper, mulatto chile

Name: mulberry
Description: These are so fragile that almost no markets carry them.

Name: muscadine grapes
Description: Muscadine grapes are native to the American Southeast. The flesh is sweet but the skin is tart. It is easy to remove the skin.

Name: muscadine jelly
Description: Made from muscadine grapes, this is a redder, tarter version of grape jelly.

Name: muscat raisins
Description: These are large and very sweet.

Name: Mutsu apple
Description: This is a very juicy, crisp, all-purpose apple.

Name: Nafplion green olives
Description: These are green, brine-cured Greek olives. They're somewhat salty.

Name: nectarine
Description: Nectarines resemble peaches, but they're sweeter and more nutritious.  They're best if they're allowed to ripen on the tree.  Unfortunately, tree-ripened nectarines bruise easily, so most growers scrimp on flavor and pick and market them while they're still slightly underripe.  After buying nectarines, you're supposed to let them ripen for a couple of days at room temperature before eating them.  This makes them softer and juicier, but not sweeter.  Avoid buying nectarines that are too hard or that have green spots--a sign they were picked way too soon--or those that are bruised.  The superior freestone varieties arrive in June and July; the cling varieties that come later aren't as good.

Name: New Mexico green chili
Description: These large chilies are similar in size to Anaheims, but they're hotter. New Mexico green chilies peak in the late summer, while the hotter New Mexico red chilies appear in the fall. These are moderately hot.
Also known as: New Mexico chile, New Mexico red chile (when mature)

Name: New Mexico red chili
Description: These chilies have an earthy flavor and resemble the California chili, except they're hotter and more flavorful. They are moderately hot.
Also known as: chiles de ristra, New Mexican chile

Name: Nicoise olives
Description: A key ingredient in Salade Niçoise, these small purplish-black olives have a distinctive sour flavor. They're great in tapenades.

Name: Northern Spy apple
Description: These tart, firm apples are terrific in pies, but they're hard to find.

Name: Nyon olives
Description: These black olives from France are salt-cured, which makes them wrinkly and more bitter than standard lye-cured American black olives.

Name: Ogen melon
Description: This melon hails from Israel, and it's very highly regarded by melon fans.

Name: olallieberry
Description: This cross between a youngberry and a loganberry is black and fairly sweet.

Name: Olives
Description: A staple of Mediterranean cuisines, olives are most often eaten out of hand, though cooks also use them to flavor everything from pizzas to martinis.  Raw olives must be cured before they can be eaten, and the curing medium--usually lye, brine, or salt--affects their flavor and texture.  So too does the olive's degree of ripeness when it's picked.  Green olives are picked while unripe, which makes them denser and more bitter than brown or black olives, which stay on the tree until fully ripened.   Olives become bitter if they're cooked too long, so always add them to hot dishes at the last minute.   Opened cans or jars of olives should be refrigerated, but some olives can be stored at room temperature if they're submerged in brine or olive oil.

Name: Onza roja chili
Description: These are used in sauces and soups. They're hot.

Name: opo squash
Description: This is a mild squash, similar to zucchini.
Also known as: bottle gourd, calabash, cucuzza, long squash, New Guinea bean, snake gourd

Name: orange
Description: Most American oranges are produced in Florida and California. Florida oranges are juicier, and better suited to squeezing, while California oranges segment more easily and are better for eating out of hand. The best oranges are smaller, thin-skinned, and heavy for their size.

Name: orange marmalade
Description: This is made by boiling the fruit and peel of oranges with sugar, pectin, and water. It manages to be bitter, sour, and sweet all at once, which many people find delightful.

Name: Otaheite gooseberry
Description: This tart fruit looks and tastes like a gooseberry.
Also known as: arbari, cheremai, grosella, Malay gooseberry, star gooseberry, starberry

Name: papaya
Description: With their subtle tropical flavor, papayas are wonderful in fruit salads, puréed fruit drinks, or even shish kabobs.  They're also good for you and easy to peel and seed.  Papayas from Hawaii are more common and more flavorful than those from Mexico. Yellow ones that yield to gentle pressure are ready to eat, and should be refrigerated. Green ones will ripen at room temperature in just a few days.
Also known as: fruta bomba, lechosa, papaw, pawpaw (in Australia), tree melon

Name: pasilla chili
Description: This is the dried version of the chilaca chili. It's mild, long, black, and wrinkled, and a standard ingredient in mole sauces. Ancho chilies are sometimes mislabeled as pasillas.
Also known as: chile mixe, chile negro, chile pasilla, pasilla negro, pasilla pepper

Name: passion fruit
Description: This nutritious, aromatic fruit has a tart, sweet flavor. The sweet purple variety is the most common, but you can also find yellow passion fruit (sometimes called golden passion fruit), which is more acidic, and a giant version that has a more subtle flavor.Choose fruit that have wrinkled skins (indicating that they're ripe) and heavy for their size. To eat one, cut it in half and scoop out the pulp. You can eat the small seeds, but some people remove them.
Also known as: granadilla, maracudja, maracuja, passion-fruit, passionfruit, purple granadilla, red granadilla, yellow granadilla

Name: pattypan squash
Description: These have a pleasant, nutty flavor. They're small enough to grill whole, but lots of recipes call for them to be hollowed out, stuffed, and baked. There are green and yellow varieties; yellow ones are sometimes called sunburst squash.
Also known as: custard squash, cymling, granny squash, peter pan squash, scallop, scalloped squash, sunburst squash, white bush squash, white squash

Name: pawpaw
Description: Real pawpaws are native to North America, and have green peels, orange flesh, and taste like a blend of tropical fruit. They're hard to find in markets, though, since they must be eaten within a few days of being picked. Pawpaws continue to ripen after they're picked, and should be eaten only when they yield to a gentle squeeze, like a ripe avocado.Australians use the name pawpaw for the papaya, while others use it for the cherimoya.
Also known as: American papaw, Appalachian banana, hillbilly banana, hillbilly mango, Indiana banana, Kentucky banana, Michigan banana, papaw, paw paw, paw-paw, poor man’s banana, prairie banana, Quaker delight

Name: pea eggplants
Description: These tiny Thai eggplants are quite bitter. They're sold in clusters and look like large green peas. You can find them fresh in Thai markets, or buy them pickled in jars.
Also known as: baby Thai eggplants makua puong, makheau phuang

Name: peach
Description: Most of the peaches that are sold in markets are freestone, and de-fuzzed by the grower. Select peaches that are colorful and free of bruises. After you get them home, let them ripen at room temperature for a day or so until they become softer. They're best and cheapest in the summer.

Name: pepino
Description: These are juicy and have a mild melon flavor.  You can eat the peel if you like.
Also known as: mellowfruit, melon pear, melon shrub, pear melon, pepino melon, sweet cucumber, treemelon

Name: pequin pepper dried
Description: These small red peppers are very hot.
Also known as: bird pepper, chile congo, chile de monte, chile pequín, chiltepe, piquin chile, piquin pepper, piquín peppers
Substitutions: chile de árbol dried,tepin dried,cayenne pepper dried,cascabel pepper - dried

Name: Persian cucumber
Description: This is very similar to a Japanese cucumber.

Name: Persian melon
Description: These are large, round melons.  They're excellent when vine-ripened, but mediocre when not.  Avoid Persian melons that have green backgrounds below the netting--they were picked too early.  Also avoid those with protruding stems, or tears in the rind at the stem end--it's a tell-tale sign that the melon was picked too soon.  When ripe melons are picked, the stem falls off easily, leaving a small, clean depression.  They peak in the summer months.

Name: persimmon
Description: There are two varieties:  the dark orange, acorn-shaped Hachiya and the light orange, tomato-shaped Fuyu.  Many people have sworn off persimmons for life after biting into an underripe, astringent Hachiya.  But if you wait  until it's ripened to a soft, shriveled mess, you can spoon out its exquisitely sweet and delicate pulp.  Fuyus aren't as flavorful, but they're more idiot-proof in that you can eat them while they're still firm and not get your mouth in a pucker.

Name: Picholine olives
Description: Picholines are green, torpedo-shaped olives that are brine-cured. Those made in Provence are marinated with coriander and herbes de Provence, while American picholines are soaked in citric acid. They make great martini olives.
Substitutions: Lucque olives,Cerignola olives,green olives,caper berry,cocktail onion

Name: pimento
Description: Pimentos are often sold roasted and peeled in cans or jars, or used to stuff green olives.

Name: pineapple
Description: Pineapples are juicy, mildly acidic, and very versatile. They can be squeezed for juice, sliced on cakes, skewered and grilled, or eaten raw without adornment. Select only ripe pineapples that give a little when you squeeze them. Hard, unripe pineapples stop becoming sweeter once they're picked. A new variety, the golden pineapple, is sweeter, juicier, and richer in vitamin C than ordinary pineapples. A white pineapple also has been developed. Canned pineapple is an acceptable substitute for fresh in many recipes.

Name: Pink Lady apple
Description: This is a cross between a Golden Delicious and a Lady William.  It's sweet and crisp, and good in salads and pies.

Name: Pinkerton avocado
Description: These peel easily and their flavor is excellent.  One of the best varieties.

Name: Pippin apple
Description: This is a firm, tart apple that's great for pies, baking, and applesauce.

Name: piri piri pepper dried
Description: These are insanely hot tiny peppers.
Also known as: African red devil, bird's-eye chili, peri peri pepper, pili pili

Name: plantain
Description: These look just like large green bananas, and they're usually cooked before eating. Hispanic and Caribbean use them like potatoes, either frying them or boiling them in stews. Different recipes may call for plantains in varying stages of ripeness, with their skins either green, yellow, or black. A green plantain will first turn yellow and then black if allowed to ripen at room temperature. As it ripens, the pulp becomes sweeter and less starchy.
Also known as: Adam's fig, cooking banana, macho banana, platano, platano macho

Name: plum
Description: Plums are juicier than other stone fruits, and have a longer growing season.  There are many varieties, some sweet, some acidic, and some best suited for drying into prunes.  They're often eaten out of hand, but they also work well in cobblers, compotes, and tarts.

Name: pluot
Description: This is a plum/apricot cross, with plum dominating.

Name: poblano pepper
Description: These mild, heart-shaped peppers are large and have very thick walls, which make them great for stuffing. They're best in the summer. When dried, this pepper is called an Ancho chili.
Substitutions: Anaheim chili,bell pepper,green chile canned,Serrano pepper

Name: pome Fruit
Description: The family of pome fruits include apples, pears, quinces, Asian pears, and loquats.

Name: pomegranate
Description: Cut through the pomegranate's leathery skin, and you'll find hundreds of pretty kernels, each with a tiny seed surrounded by ruby red pulp.  You can eat the kernels, seeds and all, and they're great as garnishes or sprinkled in salads.  You can also press the kernels for juice and strain out the seeds.  Wear an apron when working with pomegranates; the juice can stain your clothes.  They arrive in markets in the late summer and early fall.

Name: pomegranate juice
Description: Don't confuse this unsweetened juice with grenadine, which is a heavy, sweet syrup. Look for it in health food stores and Middle Eastern markets. Knudsen is a well-regarded brand.

Name: pomelo
Description: This has a very thick peel, so you have to work to get at the pulp. Many people think it's worth the trouble, for a pomelo is milder and sweeter than its closest substitute, the grapefruit.

Name: Ponentine olives
Description: These are mild Italian brine-cured black olives.

Name: prickly pear
Description: The pulp of these cactus fruits is a brilliant red or, occasionally, a yellowish green, and it tastes a bit like watered-down watermelon. Cooks exploit the color by adding slices of the pulp to fruit salads, or by puréeing it and straining out the seeds. They're quite popular in Hispanic countries and around the Mediterranean.
Also known as: barbary fig, cactus pear, Indian fig, Indian pear, tuna

Name: prune
Description: In a marketing makeover, producers are starting to call these dried plums instead of prunes.  Whatever you call them, they're sweet and just loaded with dietary fiber, iron, and other nutrients.  You can eat them whole, chop them into sauces and stews, or make a compote out of them.

Name: pumpkin
Description: Use the small sugar pumpkin = pie pumpkin for pies; the larger jack o'lantern pumpkin is too watery.  Canned pumpkin purée is convenient and a good substitute for fresh.
Also known as: jack o'lantern pumpkin (large), pie pumpkin (small), sugar pumpkin (small)
Substitutions: Hubbard squash,calabaza,butternut squash,buttercup squash,acorn squash,sweet potato

Name: puréed prunes
Also known as: lekvar, prune butter, prune lekvar, prune puree, prune purée, pureed prunes

Name: puya chili dried
Description: This is similar to the guajillo chile, only smaller and more potent. It has a fruity flavor that's good in salsas and stews. They are fairly hot.

Name: quince
Description: This pleasantly tart fruit needs to be cooked before eating. Quinces are high in pectin, so they're commonly used to make jams and jellies. Some cooks simply bake them like apples. They come into season from August to December.
Substitutions: Asian pear,crab apple,Granny Smith apple,Pippin apple,Rhode Island greening

Name: quince paste
Description: This is a Spanish and South American delicacy that's similar to quince jam, only thick enough to cut into slices. It's terrific which cheese or nuts.

Name: raisins
Description: The common raisins we see on supermarket shelves are usually dried Thompson seedless grapes. Golden raisins are amber in color and somewhat tart--many cooks prefer them over ordinary raisins for baking and cooking. Muscat raisins are dark and very sweet, and they work well in fruitcakes. Currants are about one-quarter the size of ordinary raisins, and are typically used in baked goods. Store raisins in the refrigerator after you open the package.
Substitutions: prune,dried cranberries,dried apricot,dates,dried cherry,chocolate chips,nuts,dried fig

Name: rambutan
Description: These are similar to litchees and longans, but they're covered with soft spines. Peel before using.

Name: rangpur lime
Description: This is similar to a mandarin orange, only more acidic.

Name: raspberry
Description: It's a real challenge to get these hollow, fragile berries to consumers before they spoil, so you'll have to pay a high price for those that make it.   Many don't, so check them carefully for mildew before you buy them.  A good alternative is to buy them frozen.

Name: raw green olives
Description: These are for the rare cook who's intrepid enough to cure olives from scratch. Do not eat them raw.

Name: red Anjou pear
Description: Very similar to a green Anjou pear.

Name: red Bartlett pear
Description: This tastes just like a yellow Bartlett, but it's more attractive and more expensive.

Name: red currant
Description: With their brilliant coloring, red currants make terrific garnishes.   They're also pleasantly tart, and often used to make jellies, syrups, and wine.  Fresh ones are available in some markets during the summer, but frozen currants are acceptable substitutes for fresh in many recipes.

Name: red currant jelly
Description: Red currant jelly is tart and often served with lamb and venison.

Name: red delicious apple
Description: These sweet, soft apples are good for eating out of hand, but don't bake them or use them in pies. Avoid buying them in the summer; they sometimes get mushy.
Substitutions: Golden Delicious apple,Gala apple,Fuji apple,honeycrisp apples

Name: red globe grapes
Description: These are large red seeded grapes.
Substitutions: flame seedless grapes,Thompson seedless grapes,autumn royal grapes

Name: Reed avocado
Description: This large, roundish avocado slips easily from the peel, and has excellent flavor and texture. It will stay firm even when ripe, so it's not a good choice if you're making guacamole.

Name: Rhode Island greening
Description: These are especially good for baking.

Name: rocotillo pepper
Description: This is a small, sweet, mild pepper that looks like someone stepped on it. It's fruity-tasting like a habanero, only not nearly as hot.

Name: rocoto chili
Description: These very hot chiles look like tiny bell peppers and have black seeds. They have an interesting fruity flavor.

Name: Rome apple
Description: These are best used for baking and for making applesauce. They don't work well in pies.
Also known as: Gillett's seedling, red rome, Rome Beauty apple

Name: Rosa Bianca eggplant
Description: This Italian heirloom eggplant has sweet, mild flesh and a creamy texture. They're hard to find, but knowing cooks scoop them up whenever they're in season.

Name: rose apple
Description: These rose or green fruits are pear-shaped and are said to taste like rose water. The seeds are poisonous.

Name: rosella
Description: This is grown in Africa.

Name: royal olives
Description: This is large brown Greek olive is brine-cured.
Also known as: Greek royal olive, Royal Victoria olive, Victoria olive

Name: salak
Description: These are about the size of a plum and are covered with brown scales.

Name: Santa Claus melon
Description: This is distinguished mostly by its long shelf life--you can store an uncut Santa Claus melon for several months. They have thick rinds, so don't bother smelling them for ripeness--they don't give off much of an aroma.

Name: sapodilla
Description: This fruit looks like a bald, brown kiwi fruit.

Name: sapote
Description: This is a family of sweet, tropical fruits. Varieties include the black sapote = chocolate pudding fruit, the brown-skinned, pink-fleshed mamey sapote = mammee = mamey, and the white sapote = zapote blanco.
Also known as: black sapote, Mexican custard apple, sapota

Name: sauce tomato
Description: This tomato isn't as juicy as other tomatoes, which gives it a more concentrated flavor that works well in sauces and stews.  These are also the best tomatoes for drying.  You may want to remove the bitter seeds before cooking these tomatoes, but save the gel that surrounds the seeds--it's rich in flavor.  Varieties include the roma tomato = Italian tomato = Italian plum tomato and saladette tomato.  Sauce tomatoes are most flavorful in the summer.  During the rest of the year, many cooks prefer canned tomatoes over the bland and mealy fresh tomatoes they usually find in markets.
Also known as: Italian plum tomato, Italian tomato, paste tomato, plum tomato, roma tomato, saladette tomato

Name: scallopini
Description: This is like a pattypan squash, only it's greener and rounder.

Name: Scotch bonnet chili
Description: This extremely hot pepper is almost indistinguishable from the habanero, except that it's a bit smaller and has a fruitier flavor. It's popular in the Caribbean.

Name: Seckel pear
Description: These are small pears with red and green skins.  They're very sweet and juicy and they'd be absolutely perfect if only the skins weren't a bit too thick.

Name: Serrano pepper
Description: These have thin walls, so they don't need to be charred, steamed, and peeled before using. They are moderately hot. When dried, this is called a chile seco.

Name: Sevillano olive
Description: This is a large, green, brine-cured olive.

Name: Seville orange
Description: These are too bitter to eat out of hand, but they make a wonderful orange marmalade and the sour juice is perfect for certain mixed drinks.
Also known as: bigarade orange, bitter orange, marmalade orange, sour orange

Name: Sharlyn melon
Description: When ripe, this has an orange background with green netting.  It's very perishable, so don't wait more than two days after getting it home to eat it.

Name: shishito chili
Description: This Japanese chile is very sweet and mild with a grassy flavor. It's about two inches long.

Name: Sicilian eggplants
Description: These are large with purple stripes. They have thin skins and a subtle flavor.

Name: Sicilian olive
Description: These are large, green, sour olives that are usually marinated with herbs.  They sometimes pitted and stuffed with pimento, garlic, or jalapeño pepper.

Name: Sierra Beauty apple
Description: This is a juicy, crisp and somewhat tart apple.  It doesn't hold its shape well when cooked, but it's great for eating out of hand.

Name: slicing tomato
Description: These large tomatoes are best for sandwiches and grilling. Varieties include the beefstake tomato and oxheart tomato.  The red varieties tend to be more acidic than the yellow.
Also known as: beefstake tomato, globe tomato, oxheart tomato

Name: soncoya
Description: Soncoya is a somewhat obscure tropical fruit in the Annona genus. It is similar to the soursop and ilama.

Name: sour cherry
Description: While sweet cherries are best for eating out of hand, knowing cooks turn to sour cherries for pie fillings, sauces, soups, and jams.  Popular varieties include the Montmorency, Morello, and Early Richmond.  Sour cherries don't transport well, so they're difficult to find fresh.  Canned sour cherries, though, are almost as good.  If you want, boost their flavor a bit by adding one tablespoon of Kirschwasser per cup.
Also known as: pie cherry, red cherry, tart cherry

Name: sour prunes
Description: Look for these in Middle Eastern markets.

Name: soursop
Description: This large, dark green fruit is covered with soft prickles. The pulp has a slightly acidic, tropical flavor. Don't eat the seeds or peel.

Name: Southern rose apple
Description: This is a good apple for eating out of hand.

Name: spaghetti squash
Description: After it's cooked, you can dig a fork into the flesh of a spaghetti squash and pull out long yellow strands that resemble spaghetti.  Though they taste like squash, the "noodles" can serve as a low-calorie substitute for pasta.

Name: Spanish melon
Description: These are delicious melons, but it's hard to know when they're fully ripe. Unlike most other melons, a ripe Spanish melon will have a green rind and be firm at the blossom end.
Also known as: Elche honeydew, Green Tendral melon, melon Piel de Sapo

Name: Spartan apple
Description: This is a cross between the McIntosh and Pippin apples.  It's a good all-purpose apple.

Name: star apple
Description: These are similar to star fruit, only with purple skins.

Name: star fruit
Description: Star fruit have a clean, crisp texture, and they make terrific star-shaped garnishes when sliced.  They're also easy to use, since they don't need to be peeled or seeded, and they're slow to discolor.  Some varieties are sweet, some are sour.  Try to avoid ones that have brown spots or streaks.
Also known as: carambola, Chinese star fruit, five corners, five-angled fruit, starfruit, tree melon

Name: Stone Fruit
Description: The family of stone fruits includes cherries, plums, apricots, nectarines, and peaches.   They all arrive in the summer, though you can sometimes find pricey imports during the off-season.  Stone fruits don't become sweeter after they're picked, but growers often harvest them while they're still a bit underripe so that they won't bruise during transit.  At the market, select specimens that have the color, if not the softness, of fully ripened fruit, then take them home and let them soften at room temperature for a few days.

Name: strawberry
Description: Strawberries aren't as fragile as other berries, so they don't need the special handling that makes most berries so expensive.  The best time to buy them is in the spring, but you can find them throughout the year, though the price might be higher and the quality lower.  Select berries that have fully ripened to a dark red.

Name: sukkary dates
Description: Sukkary dates are golden yellow, dry, soft and sweet. They are commonly grown in Saudi Arabia.

Name: summer squash
Description: Unlike winter squash, summer squash can be eaten rind, seeds, and all. The different varieties vary in size, shape, and color, but they can be used interchangeably in recipes. Select summer squash that are small and firm.

Name: sun-dried tomatoes
Description: Dried tomatoes have a richer, more concentrated flavor than ordinary tomatoes. They're great for snacking, or tossing in salads or sauces or on pizzas. Dried tomatoes usually come either dry or packed in oil. If they're hard and dry, steep them in boiling water for about five minutes before using them.

Name: Sundowner apple
Description: Like the Pink Lady apple, this is a a cross between a Golden Delicious and a Lady Williams.  It's very good for eating out of hand.

Name: sweet cherry
Description: These appear in the summer, with the popular and exquisite Bing cherries arriving in June and July.  Other varieties have the virtue of arriving before or after the Bings, but they're often not nearly as tasty.  Select cherries that are large, deeply colored, and firm.

Name: sweet dumpling squash
Description: Sweet dumpling squash are fairly small, so you can cut them in half, bake them, and serve each half as an individual portion.  The flesh is sweeter and drier than that of other winter squash, and the peel is soft enough to be eaten.

Name: sweet gooseberry
Description: These are similar to gooseberries, but they have a red blush and are much sweeter.

Name: sweetsop
Description: This sweet tropical fruit looks a bit like a small cherimoya. It's great for eating of hand or for making shakes. It's available in the fall, but it's hard to find outside of Florida.

Name: tamarillo
Description: This fruit is notable more for its ravishing beauty than its flavor. It's about the size of a oblong plum, with a smooth peel that can be purple, red, orange, or yellow, with the yellow variety tending to be a bit sweeter. Slicing it in half reveals black or orange flesh (the darker the peel, the darker the flesh) surrounding a nest of seeds. It's more acidic than sweet, and tastes a bit like a tomato. It's best if it's peeled and cooked before eating.

Name: tamarind
Description: The pulp from the tamarind pod is used as a souring agent in Latin America, India, the Middle East, Africa, and Asia. To extract the pulp, shell the pods, put them in a saucepan, then add enough water to completely cover the pulp. Simmer for about half an hour, then strain out and discard the seeds. It's a nuisance to do this, so many cooks simply buy the extracted pulp in bricks, jars, cans, powders, or bottles. There's also a sweet tamarind, which looks like the sour variety and is used primarily to make drinks.

Name: tamarind juice
Also known as: tamarind nectar, tamarind sauce, tamarind water

Name: tangelo
Description: There are several different varieties of tangelos, each a cross between a tangerine and another citrus fruit.  The Mineola, a tangerine-grapefruit cross, is especially popular.  Look for them in markets from late fall through winter.

Name: tapereba
Description: Tapereba is the yellow fruit of the mombin tree. The fruit is eaten fresh or made into juice.
Also known as: amra, cajá, ciruela, hog plum, jobo, makok , mombin, taperebá , yellow mombin

Name: tatume squash
Description: This Mexican variety looks like a pale zucchini, but it's a tad sweeter.

Name: teardrop tomato
Description: Like cherry tomatoes, these are great in salads and on crudité platters.

Name: tepin dried
Description: These look a bit like large dried cranberries.  They're also sold fresh. They are very hot.
Also known as: bird’s eye, chiltecpin, chiltepin, chiltpin, Indian pepper, tepín
Substitutions: pequin pepper dried,cascabel pepper - dried,cayenne pepper dried

Name: Thai chili pepper - fresh
Description: These are extremely hot.
Also known as: bird pepper, prik chi fa, Thai bird chile, Thai chile pepper, Thai jalapeno, Thai pepper
Substitutions: chile de árbol dried,cayenne pepper - fresh,jalapeno pepper ,Serrano pepper

Name: Thai eggplant
Description: These golf-ball sized eggplants are more bitter than American eggplants. They come in different colors, but they're usually green with yellow or white striations. They're often used in hot chile or curry dishes. Remove the bitter seeds before using.
Also known as: Thai Green, Thai Purple, Thai White, Thai Yellow

Name: Thompson seedless grapes
Description: This is a sweet green table grape. It is also commonly used for making raisins.
Also known as: kishmish, Lady de Coverly, sultana, sultanina, sultanine

Name: tinda
Also known as: apple gourd, Indian baby pumpkin, Indian squash, Punjabi tinda, round melon

Name: toddy palm seeds
Description: These are seeds from the toddy or jaggery palm.  Sap from the same tree is used to make jaggery (a kind of sugar), wine, and vinegar.  You have to cook them before you can eat them.   People in Indian and Southeast Asia roast and split the seeds, then suck out the yellow gelatinous pulp inside.  It's available frozen or canned in Indian and Southeast Asian markets.  Be careful if you pick your own:  the red fruit surrounding the seeds contains oxalic acid, which can burn your skin and do even more damage if eaten.
Also known as: loog than (Thai), Plalmyra plam seeds, tad gola

Name: tomato juice
Description: To make your own: See the Tomato Juice Recipe posted on Recipesource.com.

Name: turban squash
Description: This squash has a gorgeous rind, but ho-hum flavor.  It makes a good centerpiece, or you can hollow it out and use it as a spectacular soup tureen.

Name: Turkish green pepper
Description: These are long, green, and hot chili peppers. Turks like to grill them and serve them with meat. Don't confuse this fresh pepper with the spice called Turkish pepper.

Name: ugli fruit
Description:
This grapefruit-mandarin cross looks like a grapefruit in an ill-fitting suit. It's sweet and juicy, though, and simple to eat since the peel comes off easily and the fruit pulls apart into tidy segments that are virtually seedless. 
Americans pronounce the name "ugly," but in Jamaica, where it's grown, it's pronounced "HOO-glee." Some marketers have tried calling it "Uniq fruit®," but the name hasn't caught on much. 
Ugli fruit are available from December through April.  Most specimens are much uglier than the one pictured here, but don't let that deter you. Select fruits that are heavy for their size, and that give a little when you press them.

Name: urfa biber
Description: This is a dried ground chili pepper used in Turkey on meat dishes. It is medium spicy and has a smoky flavor.

Name: V-8 Juice
Description: To make your own:  See the Mitch's V-6 Vegetable Juice Cocktail Recipe posted on Fabulousfoods.com.

Name: vine tomato
Description: For best flavor, tomatoes should stay on the vine until they're fully ripened.  This is a tall order for growers, who prefer to pick tomatoes while they're still green and sturdy, and then gas them with ethylene until they turn red.  Vine tomatoes, on the other hand, are picked after they begin to "break" or turn red, which allows them to develop fuller flavor.  Expect to pay more for the special handling required to bring these to market.

Name: watermelon
Description: There are about 50 varieties of watermelon on the market. They all taste about the same, but they vary in size, flesh color, and in whether they are seeded or seedless. Picnic melons are largest, while icebox melons are round and compact. Many stores also carry yellow-fleshed, white-fleshed, and seedless melons. The rind should be heavy for its size, and free of bruises, soft spots, or cuts. To check for ripeness, look at the pale side of the melon (where it rested while it was growing)--it should be yellow, not white. If your market sells halved watermelons, inspect the flesh--it should be firm, brightly colored, and free of white streaks. Seeded watermelons should have dark brown or black seeds. To store, wrap watermelon slices loosely in plastic and refrigerate for up to two days. Uncut watermelon can be stored at room temperature (preferably in a cool spot) for up to two weeks.
Also known as: icebox melons, Picnic melons, seedless melons, white-fleshed melons, yellow-fleshed melons

Name: white eggplant
Description: This eggplant comes in different shapes and sizes and, except for the exterior color, is interchangeable with their purple cousins, the American eggplant and the Italian eggplant.

Name: white sapote
Description: This tropical fruit has sweet, creamy pulp that's wonderful in fruit salads or shakes. They arrive in the summer. Since they bruise easily when ripe, they're usually sold while they're still hard. Take them home and let them ripen on the counter for a few days until they yield to a gentle squeeze. Remove the peel and seeds before serving.
Also known as: casimiroa, custard apple, matasano, zapote blanco

Name: Winesap
Description: This tart apple is great for eating out of hand or for making cider.  It keeps for a relatively long time.

Name: winter melon
Description: This Asian squash-like fruit has a mild flavor similar to a cucumber. It should be peeled, seeded, and cooked before eating. Don't confuse it with sweet melons like Honeydews or cantaloupes, which sometimes also go by the name "winter melons."
Also known as: ash gourd, ash pumpkin, Chinese preserving melon, Chinese winter melon, tallow gourd, wax gourd, white gourd, winter gourd

Name: Winter Nellis pear
Description: These are especially good for baking.

Name: winter squash
Description: Winter squash come in many sizes and shapes, but all have hard outer rinds that surround sweet, often orange flesh. Winter squash arrive late in the growing season and they have a long shelf life, so they've long been a staple in winter and spring, when other vegetables are harder to come by. Unlike summer squash, winter squash must be cooked. They're usually baked or steamed, and then sometimes puréed. Select squash that are heavy for their size.

Name: xcatic chili
Description: These fresh yellow peppers are long, curved, and very hot.
Also known as: chile xkatik, xcat'ic pepper, xcatic chile

Name: yellow melon
Description: These melons are small, about the size of medium papaya. They taste like cantaloupe, but with firmer flesh.
Also known as: chameh melon, dua gan, golden melon, Japanese cantaloupe, Korean melon, sun jewel

Name: yellow squash
Description: This category includes yellow straight-neck squash and yellow crookneck squash. They're interchangeable with zucchini.
Also known as: crookneck squash, yellow crookneck squash, yellow straightneck squash

Name: yellow wax pepper
Description: These are easily confused with milder banana peppers. Sample before using. They are moderately hot.
Also known as: hot Hungarian wax pepper, Hungarian wax chile pepper, Hungarian wax chili pepper, Hungarian wax pepper

Name: York Imperial
Description: These are especially good for baking.

Name: youngberry
Description: This is closely related to the blackberry.

Name: Zante grapes
Description: These clusters of tiny grapes are often used as a garnish.
Also known as: champagne grapes, Corinth raisins, Zante currants

Name: zucchini
Description: America's most popular summer squash, zucchini can be served raw, sautéed, baked, grilled, and even shredded and baked in a cake. Green zucchini is the most popular, but some grocers also carry a bright yellow variety. There's also a globe-shaped round zucchini that's easy to stuff.
Also known as: baby marrow, courgette, Italian marrow squash

Name: acini di pepe
Description: Acini di pepe ("peppercorns") are a type of Italian soup pasta. They're very tiny, and usually served in broths. They're a classic ingredient in Italian wedding soup.

Name: acorn starch
Description: Look for this in Korean markets.

Name: agar
Description: Since gelatin is made from animal tissue, many vegetarians rely upon this seaweed derivative as a substitute.  Like ordinary gelatin, agar is flavorless and becomes gelatinous when it's dissolved in water, heated, and then cooled.   Agar, though, gels more firmly than gelatin, and it sets and melts at a higher temperature--it can even set at room temperature.  Agar, like gelatin, is full of protein (though incomplete), but it also contains the rich array of minerals one would expect from seaweed.   To use agar, just soak it in the liquid for about 15 minutes, bring it to a gentle boil, then simmer while stirring until it's completely dissolved.  The liquid will gel as it cools.  Acids weakens agar's gelling power, so if you're firming an acidic liquid, use more.  Like gelatin, agar will break down if exposed to the enzymes of certain raw fruits, like kiwi fruit, papayas, pineapple, peaches, mangos, guavas, and figs.  Cooking these fruits, though, destroys the enzymes.  If you plan to add any of these fruits to a gelatin salad, it's a good idea to buy them in cans, since all canned fruit is pre-cooked.   Agar comes in flakes, powder, or bars.
Also known as: agar agar, agar-agar, angel's hair, Chinese gelatin, Chinese isinglass, dai choy goh, Japanese gelatin, Japanese isinglass, kanten, vegetable gelatin

Name: agar noodles
Description: These are strips of agar agar gelatin, which are usually served cold in a salad. Before using, soak them in boiling water until they're soft.

Name: agnolotti
Description: Italian for "priests' caps," agnolotti are small, stuffed crescents of egg-dough pasta that are usually filled with roasted meat, cheese, mushrooms, and/or spinach. A specialty of Italy's Piedmont region, they're great in a broth or pasta salad.

Name: all-purpose flour
Description: Bleached and unbleached versions of all-purpose flour can be used interchangeably, though bleached flour is whiter and has less vitamin E than unbleached.
Also known as: all purpose flour, flour, plain flour (Britain)
Substitutions: whole wheat flour,self-rising flour,pastry flour,cake flour,cake flour,barley flour,buckwheat flour,oat flour,rice flour,corn flour,millet flour,potato flour,soy flour,rice flour,wheat germ,amaranth flour,spelt flour,kamut flour,matzo meal,potato starch,bread flour,whole wheat flour,rye flour,rye flour,rye flour,triticale flour,barley flour,rice flour,buckwheat flour,corn flour,millet flour,oat flour,potato flour,soy flour,soya flour,quinoa flour,rice flour,wheat germ,amaranth flour,spelt flour,kamut flour,water chestnut flour,corn starch,tapioca starch

Name: almond meal
Description: Specialty stores carry this, but you can get it for less at Middle Eastern markets.

Name: alphabets
Description: These tiny pasta shapes are usually served in a broth or very light soup.

Name: amorini
Description: These tiny pasta shapes are usually served in a broth or very light soup.

Name: anelli
Description: This variety of Italian pasta consists of small rings.  It's used in soups and pasta salads.  A tiny version is called anellini.

Name: anellini
Description: These are shaped like rings, and used as a soup pasta.

Name: angel hair pasta
Description: Angel hair pasta is like spaghetti, only the rods are very thin.  It's usually served in a broth or with very thin and delicate sauces.
Also known as: angel's hair pasta, angel-hair pasta, capelli d'angelo, fine hair

Name: arrowroot starch
Description:
This starch thickener has several advantages over cornstarch. It has a more neutral flavor, so it's a good thickener for delicately flavored sauces. It also works at a lower temperature, and tolerates acidic ingredients and prolonged cooking better. And while sauces thickened with cornstarch turn into a spongy mess if they're frozen, those made with arrowroot can be frozen and thawed with impunity. The downside is that arrowroot is pricier than cornstarch, and it's not a good thickener for dairy-based sauces, since it turns them slimy. 
Arrowroot also imparts a shiny gloss to foods, and while it can make a dessert sauce glow spectacularly, it can make a meat sauce look eerie and fake. To thicken with arrowroot, mix it with an equal amount of cold water, then whisk the slurry into a hot liquid for about 30 seconds. Look for it in Asian markets and health food stores. Equivalents: One tablespoon thickens one cup of liquid. Substitutes: tapioca starch (very similar) OR Instant ClearJel® OR cornstarch (Cornstarch doesn't impart as glossy a finish and can leave a starchy taste if undercooked.) OR kudzu powder OR potato starch OR rice starch OR flour (Flour makes an opaque sauce, imparts a floury taste, and can easily turn lumpy. Use twice as much flour as arrowroot.)
Substitutions: tapioca starch,Instant Clearjel,corn starch,kudzu powder,potato starch,flour,rice starch

Name: arrowroot vermicelli
Description: These slender white Asian noodles are made from arrowroot starch.  They resemble bean threads.

Name: Asian noodles
Description: Until recently, the U.S. government required a noodle to contain flour, water, and eggs to be rightly called a noodle. Since most Asian noodles aren't made with eggs, this left them without much of an identity. The FDA permitted names like "alimentary paste" and "imitation noodles," but Asian noodle producers--from the birthplace of the noodle no less--could not use the n-word. The government finally relented, and we can now use the name "Asian noodles."

Name: Asian rice noodles
Description: Rice noodles are made with rice flour, and are especially popular in Southeast Asia.   It's easy to find dried rice noodles in large supermarkets, but you'll probably have to visit an Asian market to find them fresh.   Rice noodles should be soaked in hot water before using.  When they're soft and transparent, drain them and…

Name: Asian wheat noodles
Description: These are made with wheat flour, salt, water, and sometimes eggs and flavorings.   Always cook wheat noodles in plenty of boiling water.  Some Asian cooks recommend cooking them until they're al dente (cooked through, but still firm), while others suggest cooking them a bit longer to make them softer.  Rinse the noodles in cold water after they're done and let them drain.  Toss them about to prevent them from sticking together, then fry them, or add them to your stir-fry or soup.  Supermarkets often carry several varieties of dried Asian noodles, which can be stored indefinitely.  Asian markets often carry fresh noodles, which can be kept for two or three days in your refrigerator.

Name: aspic powder
Description: This is used to make a gelatinous glaze for cold meat, fish, or vegetables.  When finished, the dish is said to be served "in aspic."   Commercial aspic powder is made of gelatin, salt, and other flavorings.  It also comes in sheets, called aspic leaves.

Name: astri
Description: These tiny pasta shapes are usually served in a broth or very light soup.

Name: avena
Description: These tiny pasta shapes are usually served in a broth or very light soup.

Name: bajri flour
Description: Poor farmers in India and Pakistan use this millet flour to make bread and griddle cakes.  It's gluten-free.  Look for it in India markets.

Name: bamboo leaves
Description: Southeast Asians use these to wrap and tie rice packets before steaming.  They're hard to find fresh, but Asian markets often carry dried leaves in plastic bags. Soak them in warm water before using to prevent them from cracking.

Name: banana leaves
Description: People in the tropics use these huge leaves to line cooking pits and to wrap everything from pigs to rice.  The leaves impart a subtle anise fragrance to food and protect it while it's cooking.  Frozen leaves--once thawed--work just fine.  Boil the leaves before using them to keep them from cracking.  Look for banana leaves among the frozen foods in Asian, Hispanic, or specialty markets.
Substitutions: aluminum foil,parchment paper,corn husks,hoja santa leaves,ti leaves

Name: barley flour
Description: other nonwheat flour  Notes:  To see how to substitute other flours for wheat flours when making yeast breads, see the listing under all-purpose flour.

Name: barquette
Description: This is a small round or oval pastry shell that's usually topped with sweet or savory fillings.

Name: bavettine
Description: These are long rods, narrower than linguine but wider than spaghetti. They're best with light, delicate sauces.

Name: bean curd skin noodles
Description: These Chinese noodles are made from yuba, the skin that forms on soy milk when it's heated. They're chewy and very nutritious.

Name: bean threads
Description: These slender, gelatinous noodles are widely used throughout China and Southeast Asia.  They're made from mung beans and almost flavorless, though they readily absorb other flavors.   They're commonly used in soups, stir-fries, salads, desserts, and even drinks.  Before using, soak them in hot water until they're soft and transparent (about 15 minutes), then add them to boiling water and cook them for no more than a minute.  Rinse them in cold water and drain.  The dried noodles can also be deep fried to make a crunchy garnish or bed for sauces.
Also known as: bai fun, bean thread vermicelli, bun tao, bun tau, cellophane noodles, Chinese vermicelli, crystal noodles, fan si, fen si, fen szu, fun see, glass noodles, green bean thread noodles, invisible noodles, jelly noodles, mung  bean threads, mung pea noodles, pancit sotanghon, peastarch noodles, pekyasan, powdered silk noodles, sai fun, saifun, shining noodles, silver noodles, slippery noodles, sohoon, soo hoon, su boon, su un, tanghoon, translucent noodles, transparent noodles, transparent vermicelli, tung boon, vermicelli noodles, woon sen

Name: beurre manié
Description: This flour-butter mixture is used to correct overly thin sauces at the last minute.  To make it, blend equal weights of butter and flour, then knead them together.  After you whisk it into a sauce, let it cook for no more than a minute or two, since sauces thickened with flour pick up a starchy taste after they've cooked for a few minutes.

Name: bigoli
Description: This Venetian pasta resembles thick spaghetti, only it has a rough surface to better absorb flavorful sauces. It's good with shellfish, beans, or hearty meat sauces.

Name: biscuit mix
Description: Use this mix to make biscuits as well as pancakes and other baked goods.  Bisquick is a well-known brand.   To make biscuits from biscuit mix, combine 2 parts biscuit mix with 1 part water, roll out on floured surface, cut into biscuits, and bake for about 10 minutes at 425º.

Name: black pasta
Description: This is pasta flavored with squid or cuttlefish ink, which turns it black.  It's best served with shellfish.

Name: blue atole flour
Description: This is blue cornmeal that's been roasted. It's cooked and served for breakfast much like oatmeal.

Name: bread dough
Description: You can make this yourself, or buy ready-made dough in the frozen foods sections of your supermarket.  In addition to baking them into bread, you can use them to make breadsticks, pizza dough, buns, rolls, and bagels.

Name: bread flour
Description:
This flour has a high level of gluten, which gives bread more structure.  Don't confuse it with gluten flour (also called vital wheat gluten), which is pure gluten and used as a bread additive or to make seitan.
To see how to substitute other flours when making yeast breads, see the listing under all-purpose flour.
Also known as: hard-wheat flour, high-gluten flour, strong flour

Name: buckwheat flour
Description: This is a low-gluten gray flour that's great in pancakes and pastas. To see how to substitute other flours for wheat flours when making yeast breads, see the listing under all-purpose flour

Name: cake flour
Description: Includes:   self-rising cake flour   These substitutions will perform better if you also do this:  (1) Mix the batter as little as possible. (2) Separate eggs, beat the whites, and fold them into the batter.

Name: calamaretti
Description: These look like rings of squid ("calamari" in Italian).  They're great with sauces.

Name: cannelloni
Description: Cannelloni ("big reeds" in Italian) are large pasta tubes that are usually stuffed with a meat or cheese filling, covered in sauce, and baked. The name is also used for the finished casserole.

Name: canneroni
Description: Canneroni ("big reeds" in Italian) are small, short tubes of pasta.

Name: cannolicchi
Description: These are short, grooved tubes of pasta.

Name: capellini
Description: These are thin rods of Italian pasta, just a bit thicker than angel hair pasta.  They're normally served in a broth or with a very light sauce.

Name: cappelletti
Description: These are two-inch squares of Italian pasta that are stuffed with filling, and then folded into the shape of a hat. They're usually served with a light sauce, or in a broth or pasta salad.

Name: carrageen
Description: This purple seaweed can be cooked as a nutritious vegetable, but cooks are often more interested in the liquid it cooks in, for it thickens like gelatin when it cools.   It's widely used in the British Isles to make puddings and molded gelatin desserts, or to thicken soups.  A carrageen extract, called carrageenan, is used commercially to make ice cream, jelly, and other things.  To use the dried seaweed as a thickener, first rinse it carefully, then soak it in water until it swells.  Next add the carrageen to the liquid you wish to set, boil the liquid for about 10 minutes, then strain out and discard the carrageen.  Look for dried carrageen in health food stores.

Name: casarecce
Description: Casarecci means "homemade" in Italian, and these short lengths of rolled and twisted Italian pasta are great at trapping sauces.

Name: cashew flour
Description: This is hard to find.

Name: cassava flour
Description: Brazilians use this as a thickener for stews. Look for it in Hispanic markets.
Also known as: casabe, farinha de mandioca, manioc flour

Name: cavatappi
Description: This is a type of Italian pasta shaped like a short, slender corkscrew.

Name: cavatelli
Description: Cavatelli has two meanings.  It usually refers to small pasta shells that resemble tiny hot dog buns and are often served with thick, chunky sauces or in pasta salads.   The name is less commonly used for a type of dumpling made with ricotta cheese.

Name: chapati flour
Description: This is a blend of wheat and malted barley flours used to make chapatis.  Look for it in Indian markets.

Name: chestnut flour
Description: Italian use chestnut flour to make rich desserts, and sometimes breads and pasta. It also makes terrific pancakes. Don't confuse it with water chestnut flour, which is used in Asian cuisine.
Also known as: farina di castagne, roasted chestnut flour, sweet chestnut flour

Name: chickpea flour
Description: Look for this in Indian markets or health food stores.
Also known as: besan (flour), chana flour, cici flour, garbanzo bean flour, gram flour

Name: Chinese egg noodles
Description: These wheat noodles are made with eggs, which adds flavor, color, and body.   They're often used to make chow mein (in which the cooked noodles are formed into a pancake and fried on both sides) and lo mein (in which the noodles are stir-fried along with the other ingredients).   Chow mein noodles are usually cut a bit thinner than lo mein noodles, but the two can be used interchangeably.  Chinese egg noodles are available both fresh and dried; and some are flavored with shrimp.  Cook fresh noodles in boiling water for about 3 minutes, dried for about 5 minutes.  Don't confuse these with fried chow mein noodles, which are used in Americanized Chinese dishes, particularly Chinese chicken salad.
